story:
Dear Friends & Family,

Thank you in advance for considering my fundraiser. I know everyone is counting pennies just as I am so anything you can do is appreciated. A portion of each purchase will go toward funding a trip to Spain with some faculty and friends via Western Connecticut State University. This is an amazing opportunity for travel, experience, and some additional college credits toward my Biology degree. During the trip we will travel to Madrid, San Sebastian, Barcelona & we'll even get to see a bit of France while we are "in the area".  All funds raised over the $5000 needed for the trip I will put toward a grant for the Spanish department to award to another deserving student.

 

A Little About Me (only because they insist I write this): I currently work two jobs while trying to balance a full time student work load and adult responsibilities (bills, pets, jobs, etc). It is ever challenging, but I know this is an amazing opportunity & many are not able to go back to school so I recognize my blessings. I am doing my very best to get the most out of my time in school & feel that this educational trip will really add to that experience. 

Thank you so much for all of your help!

Safe travels! 

Lil

story:
All we keep hearing these days is “Detroit is bankrupt…” but those of us here on the ground level don’t pay much attention, because we all know that it is the organizations, local businesses and individuals who rally together to keep this city moving and are committed to improving the Detroit community.

Since 1994, Vanguard Community Development Corporation is one of the many organizations affecting change in the city of Detroit. The organization was founded by Bishop Edgar Vann, II, to facilitate the revitalization of the physical, social, and economic fabric of The North End neighborhood. In the 19 years of dedicated service in the neighborhood, we have been able to serve nearly 100,000 families and their children and have invested over $60 million to build affordable housing. 

Footprints to Prosperity is designed to service home-based providers and caregivers of children from birth to age 5 in our community who want to learn more about how children learn best. We offer these individuals, (who could be single mothers or fathers, grandparents, aunts or uncles, cousins, etc.) free resources as well as additional support and evaluation tools to ensure milestones are reached. Our goal with this program is to produce children who are Kindergarten ready!

The Barriers We Face

Many times, the work needed in Detroit can be accomplished with very little or even no money. But sometimes, in order to make a large impact, there is a cost. This is especially true when it comes to educating our children. We all know what happens when budgets are cut and programming is lost. But did you know that the most formative years of a child’s education begins before they are of kindergarten age? And that getting them started on the right path by age 3 will greatly reduce potential setbacks in the future? According to a 2012 report prepared by The Skillman Foundation and Data Driven Detroit, parents of Detroit children under the age of 5 years old, of which 62.7% live below the poverty line, have too few options available for high quality care for their children. The same report estimates there are only 301 childcare centers in Detroit to serve approximately 50,000 children under the age of 5 years old. The lack of options, coupled with affordability and transportation concerns, usually means most children are care for by family members or other providers in an unregulated home-based setting. Here are some additional statistics that demonstrate more barriers we are trying to overcome:

  • While 90% of brain development occurs by age 3, children who are not in quality child care are not as likely to receive early learning experiences that foster brain development
  • Children that live in poverty are exposed to 40,000 less words that children that come from middle class backgrounds
  • 80% of all births in Detroit are to single women
  • 34% of all births in Detroit are to women without a high school diploma or GED
  • In 2011 45,000 children in the city of Detroit received child care subsidy assistance for early childhood needs

What We Need

The United Way of SE Michigan has committed $175,000 which needs to be matched EVERY YEAR. We have been able to secure a large portion the match for this year, but we are not quite there yet. This campaign is to raise $25k and we are choosing to opt for the flexible campaign because even if we don’t make the goal (or if exceed it), we will still be able to use the money to:

  • set up early learning hubs with books, toys and create healthy play spaces
  • make resources and educational training materials available to home-based providers to improve professional development
  • provide incentives for parents and providers for participating in the program.
  • Control and develop and implement a rigorous evaluation tool to ensure the program is successful

This is YOUR chance to affect significant change in the life of a child in Detroit.

By donating even just $3 to this campaign, you can help more children in our community meet important educational milestones. Did you know that by age 3:

  • A baby's brain has reached almost 90 percent of its adult size.
  • A child have a vocabulary of over 1000 words.
  • A toddler stay engaged in one activity for 8-9 minutes.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, we completely understand but that doesn’t mean you can’t help us out! Tell your friends, tell your family, make a phone call, send a text or an email, post about it on Facebook, Twitter, your blog…all we ask is that you SHARE this important campaign so we can all work towards a common goal of securing a positive future for the children of Detroit!

story:
REWARDING POLITENESS AND COMPOSTURE .....HOW CAN WE CHANGE A BAD SITUATION IN TO A POSITIVE ONE .. 

The courteous Dunkin’ Donuts employee who endured the unhinged rantings of that crazy female customer is an 18-year-old who just graduated from a Florida high school and earns around $8 an hour serving Coolattas and Munchkins to patrons at the Fort Lauderdale eatery.

In a TSG interview, Abid Adar said that he and another employee were the only ones working at the North Federal Highway store Friday night when Taylor Chapman, 27, and her friends placed an order at the drive-thru window.

After Adar’s coworker was slow to provide Chapman with a receipt, she argued that her group’s food should be free, per a store policy that guarantees a customer’s order will be comped if they are not given a receipt.

Adar’s coworker Nithi--who was manning the drive-thru window--explained to Chapman that she would have to speak with a manager the next day about the refund request. Chapman returned to Dunkin’ Donuts the following morning ready to precipitate a confrontation, which she subsequently filmed with her iPhone.

As seen on the video, Adar remains polite and composed in the face of Chapman’s unrelenting boorishness. “I’ll give you your order free. Whatever you ordered yesterday I can give it to you for free,” he tells Chapman. “Whatever you want, I’ll get it for you.”

The teenager (pictured in the above screen grab) never responds in kind to Chapman’s vulgarities or provocations. “I’m very sorry about that,” he replied when she complained about her purported mistreatment at the Dunkin’ Donuts, which is about 2.5 miles from the Oakland Park apartment Chapman shares with her boyfriend. Asked about his cool demeanor, Adar said, “We were just trying to be nice.”

For her part, Chapman spewed a steady stream of insults and inanities. She called Nithi a “complete cunt sand nigger whore” while also remarking, “I just want my bacon crispy and my people to be nice.”

Adar told TSG that while he was aware of the video Chapman shot--and later posted online--he had not viewed it. He learned of the video’s existence when a former coworker of Chapman’s (who had seen the video on her Facebook page) called Dunkin’ Donuts and "apologized for her behavior.”

The teenager, who said he had never encountered a customer as belligerent as Chapman, began frequenting Dunkin’ Donuts about three years ago, when he would help out his mother, who worked at the eatery. In the fall, Adar--who wants to be a doctor--begins attending Florida Atlantic University in Fort Lauderdale.

Taken from the smoking gun website "http://www.thesmokinggun.com/buster/viral-video/polite-dunkin-donuts-worker-768402 

========= THIS WAS THE STORY THAT PROMPTED ME TO MAKE SOMETHING POSITIVE OUT OF SUCH AMOUNT OF HATE AND ABUSE =======

I Do not know Abid Adar personally, yet his courteous demeanor and polite attitute during the course of the situation that made him a "viral sensation" made an impact on the way I think about situations like this, and made me challenge myself to take action and not let it pass by or simply promt me to give a "like" on my facebook page.

As I watched the video for the 3rd time, and counting the grossly amount of bad words used by that woman in her rant, it only occur to me that no one, under no circumstance should be addressed in the way she did, to Abid and his co-worker. Her words filled with an unfounded hatred and misrepresented logic made me wonder if her retoric was the result of a momentary hate-the-world episode or simply the use of some illegal drug early in the morning.

In my personal opinion, instead of focusing on the bad and perpetuating the silent violence, lack of tolerance and self-entitlement of some humans, like the counterpart in the video in question, it was time to do something different and act on it , and the best way to reward Abid's attitute and composture is trying to give him a hand to make his wish of becoming a doctor a reality, and give a lesson to those who think is right to treat others with disrespect, just for the color of their skin or their heritage.

After fighting with my own concience and schedule for over an hour, deciding if I wanted to take on the task of raising $ 25,000 dollars for a complete stranger to help him achieve his dream, I read the article one more time and the following paragraph - gave me the answer:

"The teenager, who said he had never encountered a customer as belligerent as Chapman, began frequenting Dunkin’ Donuts about three years ago, when he would help out his mother, who worked at the eatery"

Help out his mother - was the part that added the ingredient missing for me to take on in this little campain, a young man that sacrifices his time to help mom at her work, deserves not only my respect but also from  those who belive in the principle of family and the moral fiber that our mothers always try engrave in our minds and personalities.

Abid story is yet to be written, and for a young man working for $ 8 bucks an hour, Med School seems to be a hard, yet attainable goal , but comes with great sacrifices and effort, yet the task is clear, raising money for a kid that had a bad break with a customer at his job is hard to sell, because it happens every day, but most of us, never come in contact with any stories of the likes of Abid's - because most of them are not "viral".

I would like to seek the help of those who came in contact to Abid's story in one way or the other  TO ACT ON IT , and help this young man with a donation towards his tuition or future education expenses, and let him know that WE are more, the decent, good people, and turn this episode into something positive. 

I will keep updates on the progress and will share it with all, all the funds raised will be provided to Abid's for his tution and college expenses, as a gesture of integrity, kindess and decency that he showed all of us.

Share the link, with anyone who belives in respect for all and integrity ! 

Thank you !

story:
My campaign is about bringing children back outside.  My dream is to become a mentor for children, youth, teens, young adults and adults in “Deep Nature Connection”.  “Deep Nature Connection”  is connection with nature, with others, and with yourself.  To do this, I am attending Twin Eagles Wilderness School for a 9 month Immersion program that will give me the tools, and the experience to bring “Deep Nature Connection” to my community. 

“Give a man a fish and you will feed him for a day, teach a man to fish and feed him for a lifetime, teach a man to teach others how to fish and you will feed his community forever.”  These words perfectly describe what my goals are with Deep Nature Connection. 

I have been attending Twin Eagles for 7 years working from an attendee at their summer camps to an assistant instructor at those same summer camps.  I feel who I am today has been largely influenced by my opportunity to be in nature as I grew up. Now I want to be trained to be a mentor and leader so that I can bring the life changing experiences I have had and that I watch campers at Twin Eagles have year after year back to my community.

I am asking for donations from like minded people who love nature and feel the immense impact it can have in our lives.  The donations will help me pay the tuition to attend the Twin Eagles Wilderness School Immersion Program  so that I can get the training and experience to follow my dream of spreading  Deep Nature Connection.
( http://www.twineagles.org/wilderness-immersion.htm )

Even if I don't reach my goal, every dollar donated will bring me one dollar closer to completing my 9 month Immersion course at Twin Eagles Wilderness School.

Why me and who am I?  I am 19 years old.  I recently traveled to China where I taught English as a second language in Harbin (a city of 9 million in north east China).  I taught at 2 Universities, class size ranging from a few seniors practicing their English with me to lecturing in front of 200 to 300 students.  I also privately tutored young children just beginning to learn English.  The very competitive conditions that these students had to live in appeared to limit their maturity and self growth.  It made me realize how lucky I was to be raised spending so much time in the outdoors and nature.  I am inspired more than ever to give American kids the opportunity to experience nature on a regular basis.

"Plant an oak tree, even though you will never see it grow to its full height in your life time, your great grandchildren will be able to swing from its branches."  My mentor once told me this.  Even though I won't see the full impact of my work, I know the next 7 generations can feel the benefits.

Another way that you can help is just by spending time outside.  Sometimes its hard to be in nature, you may have to drive far to find it.   But take you niece or nephew, family, or your friends, and just go for  a hike.  Nature brings out the best in all of us, and if everyone took just one hike, our world would be that much better. 

Thanks so much for taking your time to get to know me, and please share my story. Indigogo share tools or here: igg.me/at/no-child-left-inside

story:
Why we started

We started because we were tired of lack of privacy and purpose on the largest social networks. FULLfrnt is designed to help users learning, do stuff and discovery new things... rather than help advertisers to collect more information about us. --> Our mission is to use technology to facilitate a new society for better people.

How it is going

The only way to keep FULLfrnt completely independent and focused on us, the users, is to make it a pay platform. FULLfrnt will also be itself a member of the new society, re-investing as much as it is necessary to achieve our grand vision. We are investing $10,000 ourselves to kickstart the project (marketing, design, backend development, legal, etc.). --> Now we need $3,500 more to fund the app development for mobiles and tablets.

Launching this summer

We have come a long way since we started four months ago. We believe we can change the world for better, with a simple app: it is proven that we people are indeed happier when we learn something new, help somebody or find inspiration in something around us. FULLfrnt is just about facilitating these simple things. --> If you feel like us, even more important than funding, is spreading the word.

And here is the link to our blog.

story:
So here we go!

My name is Nicole Palomba and I am a storyteller. I graduated from Chapman University with a BFA in Theatre Performance in 2010. Since graduation I have been pursuing my passion for theatre and community outreach in various performance and volunteer endeavors culminating in my latest journey- an internship in Ghana. It has been a dream of mine to go to Africa since I began my studies at Chapman, and an even longer dream to use theatre to change the world. Theatre is more than a medium, it has the potential to be a tool for change and a springboard for people to grow into who they have always been to afraid or ill-equipped to become. This internship is a drama therapy training at an Autism Center in Accra, Ghana. The people at this center have by no fault of their own the tools to communicate their own stories and I cannot wait to provide them the opportunity. 

The Bottom Line...

Getting down to business...I am looking to fundraise $5000 to help cover my own medical costs, airfare and program costs as well as school supplies I plan to bring with me. I have to get several rounds of shots as well as pills as well as visa application fees. Any extra money will be donated straight to the Autism Awareness and Care Center. 

Program Costs IN EUROS $2000

Flights $2000

Misc. Medical and Visa $1500

So what's in it for you?

Great question. Although this campaign does not have a concrete product at the end of it, I can offer you some inspirational and hearwarming PERKS! once I arrive.

$25- A MAILED photo and thank you letter from Ghana with the students. 

$100- Sponsor of the day shout-outs on the blog and a thank you letter from Ghana. 

$200- Photo Album (once I return) and personalized thank you from the students and myself as well as a video shout out and thank you letter from Ghana. 

 

 

In Essence...

The most important outcome of this trip is awareness for the autistic community in Accra and the emphasis and understanding of drama therapy as a tool for communication. Even if you cannot donate, please spread the word or pass on the links- the more people who understand and are interested, the stronger the chances are that we can make a louder difference in Accra. We all have a difficult time expressing ourselves and handling our lives, but most of us were blessed with the capacities to verbalize our struggle in some way. That is the gift I am trying to give to the people at AACT. Theatre has always had a healing power; we can use someone else's words to reveal our own struggle, which is a simple gift we can perpetuate together.
story_txt:
So here we go!
My name is Nicole Palomba and I am a storyteller. I graduated from Chapman University with a BFA in Theatre Performance in 2010. Since graduation I have been pursuing my passion for theatre and community outreach in various performance and volunteer endeavors culminating in my latest journey- an internship in Ghana. It has been a dream of mine to go to Africa since I began my studies at Chapman, and an even longer dream to use theatre to change the world. Theatre is more than a medium, it has the potential to be a tool for change and a springboard for people to grow into who they have always been to afraid or ill-equipped to become. This internship is a drama therapy training at an Autism Center in Accra, Ghana. The people at this center have by no fault of their own the tools to communicate their own stories and I cannot wait to provide them the opportunity. 
The Bottom Line...
Getting down to business...I am looking to fundraise $5000 to help cover my own medical costs, airfare and program costs as well as school supplies I plan to bring with me. I have to get several rounds of shots as well as pills as well as visa application fees. Any extra money will be donated straight to the Autism Awareness and Care Center. 
Program Costs IN EUROS $2000
Flights $2000
Misc. Medical and Visa $1500
So what's in it for you?
Great question. Although this campaign does not have a concrete product at the end of it, I can offer you some inspirational and hearwarming PERKS! once I arrive.
$25- A MAILED photo and thank you letter from Ghana with the students. 
$100- Sponsor of the day shout-outs on the blog and a thank you letter from Ghana. 
$200- Photo Album (once I return) and personalized thank you from the students and myself as well as a video shout out and thank you letter from Ghana. 
 
 
In Essence...
The most important outcome of this trip is awareness for the autistic community in Accra and the emphasis and understanding of drama therapy as a tool for communication. Even if you cannot donate, please spread the word or pass on the links- the more people who understand and are interested, the stronger the chances are that we can make a louder difference in Accra. We all have a difficult time expressing ourselves and handling our lives, but most of us were blessed with the capacities to verbalize our struggle in some way. That is the gift I am trying to give to the people at AACT. Theatre has always had a healing power; we can use someone else's words to reveal our own struggle, which is a simple gift we can perpetuate together.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kristin. I have been working as a Licensed Practical Nurse in British Columbia, Canada for the last 3 years and I am currently enrolled in the second year of a Bachelor of Nursing program. I am truly passionate about the health and wellness of individuals and communities not only here at home, but on a global level as well. That is why I was extremely excited to recently learn that I had been selected to volunteer in South Africa in August of 2013 with International Student Volunteers (ISV).

International Student Volunteers is a volunteer and travel organization based in the USA. ISV volunteers have contributed more than 2 million hours of volunteer work across six continents. ISV is a world leader in student volunteer initiatives. Many members of the U.S. Congress endorse ISV, and the U.S. Center for Citizen Diplomacy in conjunction with the U.S. State Department recently selected ISV as one of the top ten international voluntary service organizations. ISV also recently received the award for “Outstanding Volunteer Project” at the 2011 World Youth and Student Travel Conference. ISV believes in responsible travel, sustainable projects and making a difference while traveling abroad. For more information about ISV, please visit www.isvolunteers.org.

While on my community development project, I’ll learn about the socio-economic challenges of people living in developing countries and communities, which will strengthen my understanding of the world at large and lead me on a path of humanitarian efforts to impact our world for years to come. Past ISV volunteers have worked with children in orphanages and rescue centers, and built schools, medical facilities and community gardens, among other assignments. With your help, I will be able to broaden my cultural and social awareness, as well as improve the quality of life for disadvantaged families and children.

The ISV program also has a strong educational component, and I am really looking forward to learning about the global issues facing other countries, and how I can help. In addition, I will be receiving academic credit for independant study through my University.

 I am so grateful to have an opportunity to assist others in the world, but, as you may know, international travel can be somewhat costly. This is why I’m asking for your help. I would be grateful donations of any amount that you could provide. Your donation will go toward my program cost of 3795.00$ and airfare costs of 2215.00$. The program cost includes accommodations, most meals, project materials and support, ground transportation, and tour guidance.

Please know that any support you can offer will go a long way toward changing the lives of others, including mine. If you are unable to make a financial contribution, you can still help! Spread the word and make others aware of my cause by word of mouth, phone, email, and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

I greatly appreciate your consideration.

story:
My name is Tracie Benjamin.  I am 30 years young and reside in Portland, Oregon.  Below is my story.

On a dark January Morning, I was laying in bed, wishing I didn't have to go to work that day.  I rolled onto my side and happened to feel a little bump on the left side of my left breast... I had never felt this before.  I asked my boyfriend to feel it, and he stated he had never felt that before either.  Deep down I had this gut feeling that something was not right.

I had just put in my two week notice at work and was in the midst of starting up another business.  My insurance was going to drop and I was left with the option to have a breast exam at planned parenthood.  The doctor there referred me to have some imaging done, however she told me she didn't think it was cancer.  To have an ultra-sound and a diagnostic mammogram was around $1,000.....money I didn't have to spend at that time.  I began looking online and found the BCC program...a program funded by the Susan G Komen Foundation.  After obtaining all documentation required, I went in for a breast exam by an appointed doctor who could directly enroll me in this program if she felt my lump was suspicious. This was now early April.  She stated it was a solid mass and I should have a mammogram.  I was then enrolled in the program and scheduled for a mammogram on Thursday April 11th.  I will forever be thankful for Susan G Komen, they provided me the imaging that saved my life.

I was nervous and worried that morning.  I had never had a mammogram or ultra sound before and was terrified from stories I had heard.  Come to find, none of them were true.  It wasn't until I was called back for the ultra-sound that I was faced with reality of my situation.  The tech took many images and then the radiologist came in.  I remember her words, 'Well Tracie, looks like we found something'. After that, everything became fuzzy.  Your mind starts to race.  It’s like a cloth is pulled over your face and it becomes hard to focus, even on the simple things like reading a text message.  I remember asking her what were the chances it was cancer, and she said 'highly likely'.  I was told to come back the following day for a biopsy, which would confirm if it was cancer.

I left the hospital in complete shock that day, tears streaming from my face and utter confusion.  I immediately phoned my boyfriend.  He told me not to stress out, as we didn't know anything was certain.  I tried my best to do this, but you can't ignore the feelings you encounter.  The next day I returned for my biopsy.  I have always been afraid of needles, and I quickly realized I needed to conquer this fear, as this was not going to be the last time.  As I mentioned before, I had the gut feeling something was wrong. I gripped the nurses arm while the doctor took 3 samples from each suspicious spot, you would have thought I was giving birth by how tight I was holding onto her arm!  Before long, it was done.  Phew!  The rest of the day I was spoiled at home, as I wasn’t supposed to do anything but rest.

Our weekend was great and quick as always....then, it was Monday.

Monday afternoon my doctor called and left me a voicemail.  She said she wanted to discuss my results...right then, I knew it wasn't good news.  I was diagnosed that afternoon with two spots of invasive breast cancer in my left breast. I did not shed a tear, as I had been mentally preparing myself for this by assuming the worst.  I took the pro-active approach and asked, 'what's next'.  I wanted the cancer out of my body and I wanted to get back to my regular life as soon as possible.  However battling cancer is a process, there are many important steps you must take.  You must stay strong and trust the professionals to fix you.

The next few months were full of appointments.  Surgery consultations, Oncology appointments, Fertility appointments and etc.  Everyone was so nice, supportive and caring.  My fears were lessened and I kept my positive and carefree outlook throughout this entire process so far!  It makes a HUGE DIFFERENCE if you can stay positive :) 

I am now 4 weeks past my bilateral mastectomy.  When my oncologist told me I needed chemotherapy, so many thoughts ran through my head.  How would this effect my daily life?  Would this effect my ability to have children?  I was told chemo can make women sterile.  This made my heart drop.  I have always wanted children, my own children, and now this?!  I was then referred to Oregon Reproductive Medicine.  I went through with an extreme fast-track fertility program to freeze my eggs.  I had my egg retrieval on 6/13/13.  63 eggs were retrieved, with 49 being mature enough to freeze.  I feel so blessed that they were able to obtain so many and that my body reacted well to all the medication and hormones.

Now , I have 8 rounds of chemo ahead of me.  I am nervous, anxious and all of the above.  My bill for Oregon Reproductive Medicine just arrived and I owe $3,000.  I am simply hoping that people will read my story and know that even a $5 donation helps! 100% of money donated will fund my bill with Oregon Reproductive Medicine.

I thank you for reading my story and for possibly donating towards my egg retrieval.  Feel free to reach out to me at anytime.

Best,

Tracie Benjamin

Tracie.benjamin@gmail.com

story:
When you visualize your time at York College, what do you picture in your mind? Is it sitting on the steps of McGehee for a devotional, or late nights in Thomas Hall? For many former YC students our Panther Pride was built on the floor of the Freeman Center, cheering on our athletic teams or showing club pride participating in intramural sports.

The Freeman Center is the gathering place of past, present, and future YC Panthers, and it needs our attention. 


Representatives from the classes of 2005, 2006, and 2007 proposed the idea to athletic director Jared Stark to raise money to refinish the gym floor. The photo (above) is what the gym floor looked like a few weeks ago. Thanks to the support of two wonderful local businesses, YC athletics, and the vision of a few alumni, this (below) is what the floor looks like now.


York College has done a great job of updating the Freeman Center in recent years, and the $15,000 raised for the new floor certainly brings it closer to completion. Now we want to raise an additional $15,000 to complete the project. With the help of York College alumni and friends we can do it. 

With a total of $30,000 we can complete the funding for the gym floor, provide state-of-the-art digital scoring tables, add recognition banners, and put money towards a new sound system.

Please help us help York College!

story:
Description:

Rafael Yashinsky, 15 years old.  Found close to $2,000 dollars walking home from the bus stop yesterday (Dec 13th).  From the moment he found it he only wanted to return it to the police (he does admit thinking about keeping it for about a millisecond).  The police will spend 30 days trying to find the owner, if not under Michigan law, he is entitled to keep it.  He is only interested in donating that money to charity in the unlikely case that the owner is not found.  I think the Internet should reward Rafael's generous heart and soul.  He is one of the nicest and most genuine people I know.  His birthday happens to be Dec 25th so let's work together an try to raise a nice reward for this amazing example for us all.  Maybe he can use this money for his college in a few years. 

facebook URL:

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10152799602081002&set=a.10150275682701002.374497.115222941001&type=1&theater


currently at over 12,000 likes on fb and growing!!!

Short Summary:

Troy High School Student – Rafael Yashinsky, age 15, was walking home after school and found an envelope sitting in the snow next to the sidewalk on the North end of Troy.

The envelope contained a large sum of cash in large denominations. Rafael immediately took the envelope and cash home to advise his parents and then brought the money to the Troy Police Department.

As Rafael's uncle I knew I wanted to find a way to reward Rafael for his honesty and integrity, and I thought you, the Internet, might want to join me.  This campaign is an effort to reward Rafael for his kindness and honesty, and also show him how special we think he is.  His efforts may result in saving someone's Christmas (Rafael's birthday) , and I for one think we should show him how much people appreciate his honesty.

Rafael has said that he only did what he would want someone else to do if they found his money.  I believe that by kicking in even a buck or two that we can show him just how great we think his act was.

Ideally we could raise the same amount of money that we Rafael turned in. ($2000.)  I believe it would be an amazing way to show that sometimes the universe works to reward you for your good deeds.  I cannot do it by myself, but if 1 out of every 100 people who liked his story on facebook gave 2 dollars, he could have as much money as would have gotten if he did the wrong thing, maybe more ;-).

Your small act could show, demonstrate to Rafael and the world that humanity has not lost its way.  You can encourage other around you to do the right thing the next time they find something of great value.  If the people who could afford to donate just a dollar or two all did, together we could make a big statement heard all around the world.

If you can't afford to donate, please consider sharing this campaign with your friends.  Indiegogo has tools to make it super easy.  This story is the perfect antidote to the materialism that is easy to get caught up in this time of year.  It will warm almost anyone's heart. Thank you for taking the time to read this.  Merry Christmas, Happy Holidays, and a Happy Healthy New Year!!!!

story:
Dear Philly Circus supporters,

As most of you know, I am a teacher and the Aerial Program Coordinator, and the Teacher Training Coordinator, as well as the Workshop liaison at the Philadelphia School of Circus Arts in Philadelphia, PA.

I am honored and thrilled to have been invited back this year to the annual Circus Instructor Gathering. Held January 2-6, it will be 4 days of discussion, guest speakers, and aerial teacher training amongst North America's finest and most dedicated Aerial Instructors. We all take off our teacher hats and geek out on the best ways to teach and spot skills, how to inspire our students and give them performance techniques, breaking down anatomy and injury prevention, and discuss how to best lead our schools in the safest and best way possible.

This year the gathering is held in Chicago. Chicago is expensive, and I've done a lot of work to get my costs down, but from now until the end of January I'd love to try and find support to help me pay, and recover from having to take time off work and pay for this trip.


I'm trying to raise $850 to cover my hotel $350 with tax, plane ticket (if I can get it soon- $350 from southwest airlines, and transportation around Chi town- $ taxi rides and public transportation, as well as split renting a van if needed.) Indigogo also takes a bit of change,  and I really only need $800 to make this happen. If you can support me throught paypal, mark transactions as a gift.

I love bringing back all this amazing knowledge to my fellow instructors and students of PSCA. I have helped grow our current curriculum up from 15 classes a week to well over 80 classes per week! I work really hard to get our facility the equipment and classes it needs and help all of our teachers to be training extensively on the material you need to know to grow into strong and confident students.

I'd really appreciate your support, and I would love to be able to pay it all forward on my return.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Any amount will do! Don't have $25 or $50? Even $10 can add up and help me get there.
  • Pass along to fellow friends and Philly Circus supporters!

THANK YOU!

Want to know what I will be learning while there? Here is the list of discussions and skill shares this year:

  • Creative improvisational tools
  • teaching boys/boys in the air
  • performance opportunities for students
  • trapeze/lya skill share
  • Rope share and backward drops!
  • Dance Trapeze
  • Teaching international students/teaching internationally
  • Creative partnering in duo work or group work
  • Teaching trapeze in lines
  • Silk brain- thinking of ways to challenge students to know their wraps and ins and outs of aerial silk
  • Managing staff- policies and relationships between staff and students
  • Freelance instructors discussion
  • Teaching without demoing- for injured and aging instructors
  • Anatomy of the aerialist- looking at anatomy and injury prevention
  • Teaching Mommies to be- how to teach safely for pregnant women.



SO much great stuff that I got to schedule! :)
I really don't want to miss the opportunity to bring all this stuff back and get our staff and students, I am so excited about all these topics.

Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
Any amount will do! Don't have $25 or $50? Even $10 can add up and help me get there. 
Pass along to fellow friends and Philly Circus supporters!
THANK YOU!Want to know what I will be learning while there? Here is the list of discussions and skill shares this year:
Creative improvisational tools
teaching boys/boys in the air
performance opportunities for students
trapeze/lya skill share
Rope share and backward drops! 

Dance Trapeze 
Teaching international students/teaching internationally
Creative partnering in duo work or group work
Teaching trapeze in lines
Silk brain- thinking of ways to challenge students to know their wraps and ins and outs of aerial silk

Managing staff- policies and relationships between staff and students
Freelance instructors discussion
Teaching without demoing- for injured and aging instructors
Anatomy of the aerialist- looking at anatomy and injury prevention
Teaching Mommies to be- how to teach safely for pregnant women.

SO much great stuff that I got to schedule! :)I really don't want to miss the opportunity to bring all this stuff back and get our staff and students, I am so excited about all these topics.

story:
Gross National Happiness Centre - Bhutan

Help me to help connect and raise the funds to build the GNH Centre in Bhutan. 

- A Centre designed to help inspire, demonstrate and exhibit a new model for sustainable development! With programmes offering a unique opportunity to live, explore and experience the GNH philosophy in daily life, reflecting on how to implement this in our own context in a practical way, providing inspirational and motivational experiences that transform all who engage with the Centre, through a deep commitment and engagement with contemplative, mindful living.

Hello & thank you so much for taking the time out to read this. - I am Andrew Martin and I am based in the UK and am responsible for the global fundraising activities of the GNH Centre - Gross National Happiness Centre - to be built in Bhutan. 

The purpose of this initial short campaign is to raise the funds to support my attendance, presentation and other fundraising activities at the Nexus Youth Summit in Australia in October 2013 (coming back via Bhutan to follow up and launch a new website)

Her Royal Highness Ashi Kezang Choden Wangchuck - The President of our board - will be making a video to be shown and I will then be presenting the GNH Centre Project at the Summit, as well as attending a series of fundraising meetings and events with interested donors in Australia. 

                                                  *********************

What is GNH?

In 1972 His Majesty Jigme Singye Wangchuck, the 4th King of Bhutan, challenged the conventional materialistic notion of human development with his now famous declaration “Gross National Happiness is more important than Gross Domestic Product”

Since that time this pioneering vision has guided Bhutan’s development and policy formation. Unique among the community of nations, it is a balanced ‘middle path’ in which equitable socio-economic development is integrated with environmental conservation, cultural promotion and good governance. 


This is a fabulous link to hear the GNH Centre Programme Director explain GNH and the Bhutan experiment at Schumacher College

Ha Vinh Tho - The Bhutan experiment: Gross National Happiness (GNH)Dr. Ha Vinh Tho is the Program Development Coordinator of the Gross National Happiness (GNH) Centre in Bhutan. He talks about his work in Bhutan an...


What is The GNH Centre Project?

To build a Gross National Happiness Centre with the purpose of demonstrating in a concrete and practical manner that GNH – namely, responsible  sustainable development – really works. It will fulfil a growing need for both the nation and the wider global community to understand what GNH means to an individual in daily life, and to show how it can play a key role in bringing about a new model and blueprint for society,

Catering for 300 participants on site, the Centre will offer transformative learning programmes deeply embedded in GNH principles. It will attract Bhutanese and foreigners who wish to learn and experience how to bring GNH values and practices into their own context, and how to serve their families, neighbours, and country with genuine purpose, compassion, joy, and effectiveness. Its benefit therefore is not only to Bhutan and its citizens, but also to a world seeking a viable alternative to dominant materialistic and consumerist patterns.

                                              *********************

What We Need?

We have been privileged to be invited to present at the prestigious Nexus Youth Summit in Australia at the end of October. (http://nexusyouthsummit.org/australia/) - The Nexus organisation is an international network of more than 1000 young investors, philanthropists, social entrepreneurs, influencers, and allies who work to increase and improve philanthropy and social impact investing !

With a total of over $15m required to build the Centre and deliver amazing programmes, we need to be able to meet, present and connect to organisations and individuals who care and believe in creating a better world and have the means to support this. It is therefore essential that we maximise opportunities we have been given such as our invite to the Nexus Youth Summit to play our role in enabling this to happen.

As nearly all of the funds received by the Centre to date have been used to support the local office and to run amazing and successful programmes already we do not have any funds to support fundraising activities for the building project...!! 

I am therefore asking for funds to cover the cost of travel to Australia and accommodation for the x3 days of the event and a return via Bhutan for a follow up with the team and to supervise the launch of our new website. ( I will be organising and attending other fundraising events while in Australia and will be gratefully accommodated during that time by some very good friends!) 

For your info...here are links to just a few of the incredible programmes delivered already by the GNH Centre ( Otto Scharmer - Global Wellbeing & GNH Lab - http://www.blog.ottoscharmer.com/?p=486 / - 1st International programme - http://havinhtho.blogspot.co.uk/2013/06/looking-back-at-gnh-international.html  - Youth Mindfulness Workshops  https://www.facebook.com/media/set/set=a.414854091912839.99390.213743322023918&type=1 )


What you get? The Impact

Apart from some beautiful gifts from Bhutan, and the love thanks and gratitude of the whole GNH Centre team, your support in helping us to raise funds will be absolutely invaluable in the delivery of this amazing project which is so necessary and vital for humanity... and helps us all to play a role in helping to make....

........Happiness the order of the world today!

On a practical note I will provide all donors who request it a full breakdown of exactly how each $ - Dollar is spent (& with receipts), with any funds left over going directly into the GNH Centre's building fund!

I will also be setting up a Blog for the trip and will provide you with the link so you can follow the trip and progress. 

For any further information or questions please contact me at: andrew@business-at-its-best.co

Other ways you can help

If you are unable to donate and contribute financially then please help by spreading the word and the message of the GNH Centre.. Visit the website and our FB & Twitter pages, follow our work and share with your friends....(Nb we are in the process of developing a brand new website which will go live in November..watch out for this)

Additional Links

https://www.facebook.com/GNHCentre

https://twitter.com/GNHCentreBhutan

www.bhutanstudies.org.bt

http://www.gnhbhutan.org

http://havinhtho.blogspot.ca

And above all else know and receive our gratitude, love and support for you all....!

The $15 million question ?

If you are personally able, or if you have any links, or connections who you think would be willing to support the full building and development project of the GNH Centre on a bigger scale, then please contact me at: andrew@business-at-its-best.co 

With serious interest I will be able to send you further details regarding the breakdown of the project, stages, architectural plans, business plan etc...

As I say for further info please contact me : andrew@business-at-its-best.co

Thank you... Love & Hugs to you all!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, This is Joshua Aaron. Thank you all for being such amazing fans and for your support throughout the years. Today, I need your help. I am standing with KultureCity to raise money to help the thousands of children with autism and their families throughout the US and the world.

My mission today is to raise at least $5000 to help these children and their families. I know that with YOUR help, we can reach this goal and raise much more than that.

BE A HERO, join me on my mission and give to this worthy cause! You also get some great perks to boot!

Perks

There are great perks like my limited edition hero:KULTURE TShirt.

In addition to this, you can also choose personalized autographed Cds, TShirts, guitars and so much more.

You can also have me record a personal song for you, have a skype call with me and also a brand new digital download of my new song "Shalom".

Or if you just want to support families and children with autism, you could pick the KultureCity Every Heart Has A Voice TShirt:

So choose wisely and remember, that this all goes towards an amazing cause.


What is KultureCity?

KultureCity is a non-profit organization with the mission to create a world where all individuals with autism and their families are accepted and treated equally.  Where other non-profits promote awareness, we encourage acceptance and provide tangible help to families with autism everywhere.

Children with autism and their families in general, live in a world where they have to fight for their rights. The right to be educated, to be employed, and even to be fundamentally accepted as a member of society.

KultureCity is trying to change that.


How will the money be used?

The money will be used to help fund KultureCity projects.  

Some of these projects are as follows:

 1) Toys AUcross America is their toy-giving project to children on the spectrum throughout the United States.  

2) TABLET:kulture is their Ipad giving project that provides free Ipads to children on the spectrum.  

3) therapy:KULTURE pays for therapy for ASD children in the community who cannot afford it.  

4) ourhope:KULTURE is their international initiative that funds the only special needs orphanagein Jinja, Uganda.  

 5) heart:KULTURE provides free art and music camps, free nights at the zoo and the science center and also free holiday parties to all special needs children and their families.

 6) blanket:KULTURE provides free weighted blankets to ASD children throughout the United States.

7) bouq:KULTURE provides encouragement, support and resources to mothers' of special needs children through services centered on empowerment, education and advocacy.

KultureCity's Impact

This is their one year impact for 2014:

1827 Toys Delivered

993 Kids In our free heart:KULTURE events 

231 Ipads gifted

98 weighted blankets given

￼32 families saved from financial ruin

9 children provided with free therapy

2 autism friendly restaurants created

1 special needs orphanage in Jinja, Uganda

SO JOIN ME, AND BE A HERO TODAY.

story:
Short Summary

In Cebu, Philippines on Mactan island there is a group of bikers who have been contributing to various activities helping children in the surrounding area and throughout other areas as far south as Mindanao. Such activities have included school materials(books, pencils, pens, paper, drawing materials, chairs, computers, etc...) and medical supplies focused soley on children.

I became involved with this “gang” last year. After understanding what it is they do I decided to get involved by contributing a few laptops to a SOS School(http://www.sos-schools.org/) in the area. Now they are turning to the internet to expand their reach for donations since the local community and expat community is limited to basically the same contributors.

We are looking for those of you who are passionate bikers that can donate whatever amount to a group of bikers helping impoverished children who need your assistance. We simply needs the donations and after that we can do the rest. And even if you are not a biker, please donate just the same!

What We Need & What You Get

We need a total of $3,500 that will go towards the following:

  • School materials - books, pencils, pens, paper, drawing materials, chairs, computers, etc...

  • Medical kits and supplies for children

  • Fresh water supply system for a school in Bayawan(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayawan)

With the funds that are given the bikers will purchase the proper supplies and distribute them to the impoverished areas and most importantly spend time with the children. There is nothing better than a burly, tattoo laden biker riding on a grumbling motorcycle with help and care to these children in need. It really is a great way to make use of any extra money that you can spare.

If we do not reach our goal we will simply have less to give to the children. Of course we will try our best to make up for it by seeking more contributions from the locals and local expats in the community but we would love to reach our goal with our first campaign. We will post videos from this first campaing and hopefully have more campaigns to follow here on Indiegogo.

The Impact

Although the Philippines economy is one of the strongest in Asia, money is not trickling down to the poorest of the poor. They continue to need our assistance, and not only assistance but that helping hand and friendly smile that let's them know there are those who care about them and their well being. We feel that your contribution goes far with us due to the delivery of the supplies needed by the children and the care with which it is done.

Like I mentioned, are many projects in the past that have been funded and completed. This group knows how to facilitate this type of operation. We will display a video of the happy children as they receive the gifts that are made possible by your donation. Our hope is that we can continue to use this same system of collecting online donations so that our reach and impact is even greater with large projects and contributions. Please help us start off on the right foot with your simple donation.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to contribute please get the word out so that others can become involved. You can use the various Indiegogo share tools. Tweet it, post it on Facebook, whatever you can do to help would be great!

story:
Namaste ya'll!

 Thank you for taking the time to check out my campaign!

I’m Angélica De Jesús, a recent grad, outreach worker, and nerdy yogini raising $2,300 to fund my journey to becoming a yoga instructor.

Interested in helping me get closer to implementing intersectionally inclusive, body positive, and economically accessible yoga&meditation classes within community service programs here in RVA? Read on!

 Meet the Fundraiser

I began practicing yoga in high school as a means to manage anxiety and stress. Since that first sunrise practice, around seven years ago, yoga has provided me with the inner strength to navigate through life’s challenges and personal obstacles. Even during very difficult times, my practice has given me the peace to continue working to achieve my dreams.

One of my biggest dreams has been to empower others in my community to have the option of beginning their own practice and experiencing the power of yoga in their own right.


Step One : Reaching Out

Yoga is great. The word itself holds so much meaning. Yoga originates from the Sanskrit yuj, and is rooted in the idea of unity.
Unity of body and mind. Unity of outer and inner self.
Unity of the individual and their neighbors.

Community.
Awesome right?

Nevertheless, in my few years of practice i've recognized that yoga classes are often inaccessable to a signifcant numer of folks. Drawing on those principles of unity, I have begun a journey to closing some of the demographic gaps.  

 I’ve recently partnered with the Daily Planet, a clinic offering holistic healthcare services to the homeless, at-risk homeless and underserved community of Richmond City, to bring meditation classes to their patient population. Now I’d like to expand upon that project by offering free yoga classes. And thats just the first step!

 

 Step Two: Get certified!

4025 Yoga, the local studio where I’ll be getting my yoga teacher certification, or RYT225, has granted me a work-study position, greatly reducing my tuition, but I need your support to get the rest of the way.

  • $1700 will go towards paying off my tuition (originally $3500)
  • $450 will go towards required studio hours
    • 30hrs @ 4025 yoga ($10/class)
    • 30hrs @ various community classes (~ $5/class)
  • $150 will go towards educational materials and supplies (i.e. books, DVD’s, lectures, etc)

$2,300 is a lot of money, but with your help that goal can be met! And there are plenty of perks to pick from; every donation is reciprocated by a little something from me. I work hard (making/sending things) for the money! ^-^

Step Three: Reaching Further

Completing the training will enable me to bring a full yoga class to the Daily Planet patients and staff.  I will also be able to move forward with plans to bring classes to at-risk youth, mental health clinics, social service workers, and to a broader spectrum of the community here in Richmond. In addition, I plan on hosting a body positive yoga-workshop for young women, and classes in Spanish!

My main goal is to empower people in our community, people who often do not have access to many health resources, to take their health into their hands, and get what they need to fulfill their own goals and dreams.

 

 Step Together: Support the cause

 Whether you make a donation or spread the word, any and all support is greatly appreciated. Thank you so much for visiting my campaign and for becoming a part of the movement to empower our communities to become happier, healthier places.

Again, $2,300 is a lot, but with all ya'lls help, it is completely possible.

feel free to shoot me an email (dejesusa115@gmail.com) or hit me up on twitter if you have any questions, comments, or other ideas! thank you in advanced for your support!

Namaste
(and may the force be with you!)

Shout out to my friend Bree El for helping me with the video; couldn't have done it without you. Check her out!

*please note: Here is a link for tiny chat, an online conference resource. In addition all perks which offer free yoga classes will be avaible after I receive my certification.  thanks again!

Yoga is great. The word itself holds so much meaning. Yoga originates from the Sanskrit yuj, and is rooted in the idea of unity.  Unity of body and mind. Unity of outer and inner self. Unity of the individual and their neighbors.
Community. Awesome right?
Nevertheless, in my few years of practice i've recognized that yoga classes are often inaccessable to a signifcant numer of folks. Drawing on those principles of unity, I have begun a journey to closing some of the demographic gaps.  
 I’ve recently partnered with the Daily Planet, a clinic offering holistic healthcare services to the homeless, at-risk homeless and underserved community of Richmond City, to bring meditation classes to their patient population. Now I’d like to expand upon that project by offering free yoga classes. And thats just the first step!
 
 Step Two: Get certified!
4025 Yoga, the local studio where I’ll be getting my yoga teacher certification, or RYT225, has granted me a work-study position, greatly reducing my tuition, but I need your support to get the rest of the way.

$1700 will go towards paying off my tuition (originally $3500)
$450 will go towards required studio hours

30hrs @ 4025 yoga ($10/class)
30hrs @ various community classes (~ $5/class)


$150 will go towards educational materials and supplies (i.e. books, DVD’s, lectures, etc)
$2,300 is a lot of money, but with your help that goal can be met! And there are plenty of perks to pick from; every donation is reciprocated by a little something from me. I work hard (making/sending things) for the money! ^-^
Step Three: Reaching Further 
Completing the training will enable me to bring a full yoga class to the Daily Planet patients and staff.  I will also be able to move forward with plans to bring classes to at-risk youth, mental health clinics, social service workers, and to a broader spectrum of the community here in Richmond. In addition, I plan on hosting a body positive yoga-workshop for young women, and classes in Spanish!
My main goal is to empower people in our community, people who often do not have access to many health resources, to take their health into their hands, and get what they need to fulfill their own goals and dreams.
 
 Step Together: Support the cause
 Whether you make a donation or spread the word, any and all support is greatly appreciated. Thank you so much for visiting my campaign and for becoming a part of the movement to empower our communities to become happier, healthier places.
Again, $2,300 is a lot, but with all ya'lls help, it is completely possible.
feel free to shoot me an email (dejesusa115@gmail.com) or hit me up on twitter if you have any questions, comments, or other ideas! thank you in advanced for your support!
Namaste (and may the force be with you!)
Shout out to my friend Bree El for helping me with the video; couldn't have done it without you. Check her out!
*please note: Here is a link for tiny chat, an online conference resource. In addition all perks which offer free yoga classes will be avaible after I receive my certification.  thanks again!

story:
Short Summary

On January 9, 2013, teachers at Garfield High School in Seattle unanimously announced their intention to boycott the Measures of Academic Progress (MAP) test.  They also published a letter describing their reasons for engaging in the boycott.  Since the initial announcement of a boycott by Garfield High School teachers, a number of other schools in Seattle have joined the boycott, including Ballard High School, The Center School, Chief Sealth International High School, and Orca K-8 School.  Educators, professors, parents, and community members across the country have written in support of the boycott.  Thousands of people have signed an online petition to the Superintendent of Seattle Public Schools.

What We Need

The Seattle School District originally threatened MAP test boycotting teachers with a 10 day suspension with out pay.  Since then they have backed off that threat verbally although nothing has been rescinded in writing.  What was made clear was that there would be "consequences" for our boycott.  We hope we won't have to raise money for suspended teachers, but we are waiting to find out what the consequences will be. For right now, our effort will be focused on raising funds to publicize the boycott and organize broader solidarity.

Although we have set a minimum goal of $1000, we hope to raise as much as possible.  The more funds we have, the more we will be able to do to build this campaign and support the participating teachers.

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Call, email, and write to Seattle Public Schools Superintendent José L. Banda to let him know that you support the boycott and to demand that the participating teachers receive no disciplinary action.

Superintendent José L. Banda
(206) 252-0180
superintendent@seattleschools.org
Office of the Superintendent
MS: 32-150
P.O. Box 34165
Seattle, WA 98124-1165

2. Sign the online petitions:

  • Change.org: Seattle Public Schools: Support Seattle teachers refusing to administer the MAP!
  • SignOn.org: Petition to cancel the MAP® test in Seattle Public Schools
  • SignOn.org: Support the Seattle Teachers’ Standardized Test Boycott

3. If you are part of a union or other organization, propose a solidarity resolution.  You can see examples of resolutions and letters of support here.  Email scrapthemap@yahoo.com so we can add it to our website.

4. If you are an educator, add your name to the solidarity letter written by Brian Jones and Wayne Au by emailing your name and affiliation to GHSstatement@gmail.com.

5. If you are a National Board Certified Teacher, add your name to the solidarity letter by emailing ericmuhs@comcast.net.

story:
Crewton Ramone's House Of Math

Crewton Ramone is the alter ego of a pissed off math tutor. The state of mathematics education in this country is atrocious. In the 22+ years I've been at this I've seen things get worse not better. I spend my time working on my website and on products and it is getting to the point where it is self supporting. I want to make more and better apps, pdfs, videos and webpages that teach math or help you help your kids learn and more importantly ENJOY math. I also want to train other to train others to teach math this way.

  • I am a former mastertrainer with a company called Mortensen Math. I want to take manipulative based learning to the next level. I teach algebra to 5 year olds.
  • They say many are striking at the branches few strike at the root. The root of many of our problems begin with mathematics. This method allows very young students to grasp mathematics and have fun while doing it.
  • Imagine a country where competence in mathematics is not the exception but the rule. This is what we can achieve if more people were trained using this method for teaching mathematics.

I need to be able to focus on building more and better web pages, making better videos and math apps that are cool and fun  instead of just making a living and paying bills. This will simply accelerate the process. My website is at the point where it almost supports me...but it doesn't support a team, YET.  Search the internet for Crewton Ramone...I think you can see I've been busy. I am in year three of a ten year plan. Things are going well but too slowly.


Here is a slightly longer pitch video.

Here is an even longer pitch video talking about the big picture and what I can do with this funding. I also want to point out the last time I had 400.00 in donations I turned it into a new hard drive, a camera another 200+ videos, and App and Cool Counting Book.

Equipment and Professionals

The idea is to teach as many people math as posible using the incredible technology that is at our disposal. The more people who learn math the more money we will make. In order to do this effectively I need to be able to hire people who can do the things I can't do or don't have the time to learn so I can focus on the math.

$50,000.00 will buy better equipment. Pay some of my living expenses so I can get a little studio together and so I can focus on the math and building lessons/ pages apps books for a year or so and really get this thing off the ground.

Currently the video camera I use to make my vids is a $67.00 Fujifilm JX 250. I would like to get a better video camera and a microphone for about 500.00. I need a new laptop with a better webcam.

I need to be able to PAY people to make the apps I want. Currently I have one half built app on iTunes and they guy who made it basically worked for FREE. I could have apps that teach math through algebra in short order using virtual manipulatives if I could afford to pay people to build them. In return these would make money the demand is there.

I need to pay illustraitors. I have one book so far that I have created I could make many more but these things take time and money. So far it has gotten very good reviews. I can make more and better...and make them an actual hard cover one day in addition to digital media.

These products will be awesome and fun. Most math products, books and games are basically lame and boring. They have to be FUN and easy and AFFORDABLE.

I need to make more and better instructional videos. This requires money and time I have many but they need to be better with editing and music and effects. To start I want to make a 7-10 hour long Algebra course with some editing and minor effects available for download and on DVD. I have a list of people waiting for me to do this who will buy it once it is created. Production to perfection. I have no illusions that the first ones will need improving but they can be better than my youtube videos are now.

I have oportunities to work with important people but sometimes it requires "face time" this requires some small travel. I am working with (very preliminary stages) a producer that has several Emmeys for edcational shows on PBS under his belt he is excited! We will need 'executive producers' I am told this means people with money but that is another project. Meantime, even a pilot requires money.

I need money for Trade Marks.

I need more exposure for the stuff I have already built. When people come to my website if they are in my target market (people with young kids and teachers)  they tend to stay and read and even buy stuff. People are amazed that more people are not aware of my website and all the FREE stuff it offers. Some carefully placed ads could bring traffic and that traffic will bring money. Simple math. Law of large numbers. Currently my website gets about 1000 hits per day. It could easily be 10x that with some smart guerella marketing and web campaigns.  Right now my marketing is exactly ZERO. Just organic web traffic.

Steven Covey Taught me "no margin, no mssion." The idea is to make a company that is self sustaining so I don't have to ask for more funding, and over the next 7 years build a company and a team. I offer loads of stuff for free so people can see how good it is and then they can support the work with a password or purchase of materials. Many people have told me if I had a video course they would buy it. All I have to do is make them. The snowball is ready to roll it just needs a little push.

Let's face it we have some problems facing humanity. Many of these problems can be solved by pateint problem solvers who have the ability to do math and science.

Competence in mathematics allows freedom and the ability to understand the world around you. I don't expect everybody to become an engineer or scientist but if they want to travel that path math doesn't stop them. Too many people go to college and get a degree based on how little math they need to take to get it. True story. You know it. Too many women are locked out of science and engineering because of math.

Waiting for government or an education system that isn't fully aware of the why of problem even though we can look around and see that the average person can barely do algebra much less calculus even after TWELVE YEARS of education isn't working. The change will come from the private sector; when people learn to teach their own kids at an early age, and teachers learn how to make math fun.

You can help by just spreading the word.

I know some people want to help but can't.

Spread the word about this campaign, but even just hitting the like button on my blog posts or linking my pages on your blog or social media makes a huge difference. This helps me rank in search engine results so people who are looking for help can find me. Check out this four year old playing math. You don't have to donate money to help just help spread the word about my website to people you know with young kids...preschool on up. If you know any Angel Investors or people who fund projects like this so much the better but really just spread the word: turns out math is EZ.

You can find me on both FaceBook and Twitter.

 

Also as I launch this and proof read the above I notice is all "I": "I need", "I want" etc I need to turn that "I" into "we." With a team WE will make a difference.

story:
In the past we have worked with a small cooperative in the state of Veracruz (Mexico) helping the villagers to sell the local vanilla that they produce. We are really happy with our achievements to date and want to keep helping small communities and cooperatives within Mexico.

This time we want to help several low-income villages in the Valley of Perote (Mexico). We aim to work with them, showing them how to build and maintain Adobe Stoves which do not require the use of petrol or gas.

 

 

These particular stoves also use less firewood and prevent several of the health issues associated with traditional firewood cooking that is common in the area. They prove extremely beneficial to the local villagers and not to mention the environment. Not only do they reduce the expenses and health issues among the local people, they also lessen the need for cutting down trees in the area, helping to contribute to a lowered carbon footprint.

So far we have built 80 stoves like these all over the country (Mexico) and we have been able to see the great impact they have for low income families. This time we want to take the next step and build at least 100 more of them in poor communities in preparation for this coming winter. 

 

 

The estimated cost of each stove is $500 USD, which includes the building materials, labour costs, and the transportation of the materials and the people involved in this task within the local communities.

Each adobe stove can easily last up to 20 years with no maintenance at all and if they are routinely maintained they can even last longer and the benefits that these can cause in the families located in the Valley of Perote are priceless.

 

 

Our goal is to build 100 stoves this winter, but if we can afford more of them, we will build them in other communities in the area. Our intention is to give as much help as we can, and with your donations this solution to a common situation can reach even more people.

 

 

Mexico is very diverse country with a rich culture. A magical place where you can find the most beautiful natural wonders you have ever seen, the most amazing and breathtaking cities alongside the most welcoming people. It boasts incredible hidden villages and small towns incomparable to any other place.

Despite the extreme beauty and great richness of the country, some of its people suffer from extreme poverty; the Valley of Perote  is one of the poorest places in the state of Veracruz. The temperatures go below 0°C during winter and people who live in all the small communities in the region traditionally cook outside using firewood. Cooking with firewood can cause several health issues in the lungs and is directly related with many kinds of cancer. 

 

 

We want to introduce this system to the villagers as it can drastically reduce their expenses, there is no need to set the fire outside since smoke will be extracted by using a small "chimney" on the stoves, the heat is optimized as well as the input of oxygen; hence the use of firewood is reduced.

 

 

This is just a small step to help them go some way to having a better life, there is much to be done, but we want to start with something simple.

 

 

 

 

If you are near the area, feel free to join us and build the stoves with the villagers! If you are in any part of Mexico and know any way in which we can help a community, contact us and we can work out a plan. Don't forget to spread the word and share this cause with your friends and family!

story:
Power U Youth has been sitting in at Governor Rick Scott's office for 2 weeks to demand that he call a special legislative session to end racial profiling, repeal Florida's Stand Your Ground law, End the School-to-Prison Pipeline, and enact Trayvon's Law.

Youth leaders from around the country have converged at the capital to speak their truths about school pushout and have organized in their communities against racist zero tolerance policies targeting youth of color.  

We are in need of funds to keep the momentum and campaign going in Tallahassee. Elementary, middle, and high school students from Power U Center for Social Change have slept in the capital because they are tired of being racially profiled and consistently pushed into the Juvenile Justice system.

They demand that Miami Schools implement Restortative Justice Now! Please support the youth of Miami and all of Florida's youth to end the School-to-Prison Pipeline so there will never be any more cases like Trayvon Martin's! Thank you for your contributions! You can learn more about our campaign at www.poweru.org.
