story:
We are five college students with very different goals and very different dreams, but we all have one dream in common: We want to study abroad this summer!

New experiences unleash potential, and the London/Paris study abroad trip will expand our dedication to learning and will drive us to reach out, try new ideas, and pay it forward! You can help unleash our potential by making a donation today. 5 students, 5 lives, 5 new chances to pay it forward. Even $10 helps!

Donate today!

  • A LITTLE SOMETHING ABOUT US:  We are learners for life!  All five of us attend Georgia Highlands College, which has five campuses spread across Northwest Georgia.  Also, we are undeniably passionate about school, and we are just infinitely stellar people.  More about us below!
  • YOU CAN CHANGE OUR LIVES:  This campaign goes a long way in helping us with funds.  Unfortunately, it costs a pretty penny to travel to Europe and back. Fortunately, your contribution of $10 or $100 will go a long way to helping us reach our goal!  Any little bit helps.  Be sure to check out the fun perks. Grab one before they disappear!
  • ONCE AGAIN:  We are so lucky to get to go on this trip.  This trip is the end of our Western Civilization II course where we will be on the beaches of Normandy for the 70th anniversary of D-Day!  How cool is that?  To be at the epicenter of such a major modern historical event is a gift in itself.  We want to take you with us.  By donating, you are helping us not only go to Europe, but we will document it that way you can experience the journey, too! 

    Where is the money going?

We are asking for $7,500. All of this goes directly to our trip to help us cover the costs of:

  1. Flight Expenses 
  2. Travel Insurance
  3. Basic Room and board  for the time that we will be there - This does not include a number of our meals
  4. The cost of the course that we will be taking while abroad

Why does it all matter anyway?

  • This trip will contribute to our education and expand our views on our ever changing global world.  America is falling behind in world leadership, but you can help us change that!  By contributing, you are building future leaders who have a better understanding of our world. 
  • If you have ever traveled, you know firsthand how it opens up your eyes to new possibilities and expands your view of problems that we still face as a human family.  Help us get out of Rome, Georgia and spread our wings!

Some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Tell your friends and family to join in on the fun.
  • See if the company you work for would like to contribute!
  • SHARE ONLINE:  Use the social media tools up top to help us spread the word!

     Twitter                     ::                    Facebook                      ::                     Our Blog

College is a time for learning and expanding your knowledge. However, college is also a time for personal growth. As it has taught me so much about myself. I can only imagine what London, Paris, and Normandy have in store. 

I also look forward to learning about the different cultures as I may need those experiences when I enter the nursing field. 
By donating , not only will you be helping me but you will be pouring into the life of my little one. As she will learn that there is more to life than her surroundings. 
Your contributions will allow me to use my personal growth in my career as I lend a helping hand as a result of you paying it forward!

Studying abroad, for me, is less about wanting to get away from home and more about a desire to add to my abilities and gain experiences that will change my life now and will continue to inspire me as I pursue my academic and career goals. 

As a computer science major and someone who plans to work in the field of technology, the experience of studying abroad and opening myself up to other cultures is priceless. Technology is a powerful force that affects us all, and an accurate understanding of human nature and culture is essential in shaping the course of future technology for everyone's benefit. Your donation is going to make this life changing experience all the more closer to reality for me.

Hi, my name is Jamie and I eat chocolate for breakfast, lunch, and dinner… Just kidding, but I do crave it 24/7! I also have a 24/7 craving for adventure and learning. All my life I have moved around from place to place and gained so much in doing so. 

I am one of five children. I’m actually the second of the five. Likewise, I am one of five in a group of college students who are raising money to study abroad! I’m only 19 right now, but I know traveling is one of my passions and indeed needed for me to really learn. I’m about half way through earning my degree in art at Georgia Highlands College. From the moment I could draw shapes, I knew I as an artist. I know now that I’ll only be happy in life by chasing my dreams and expanding my experience. To study abroad is to be inspired and truly learn. This trip will provide my young mind with sparks of creativity that will inspire me to continue to chase my dreams into reality. A rolling stone gathers no moss!

I am a huge dork.  And as a huge dork, I love learning about the history and politics of other countries.  I have always been a passionate global learner and self-proclaimed sociologist, so having the chance to travel to Europe will instantly expand my view of the world and how other cultures interact within their home countries.  

Also, as an international affairs major, grasping the realities of both world wars is essential to understanding how our modern world has developed. Traveling will be essential for my future job.  As a diplomat of the government or of a non-government organization, one key aspect of my job will be traveling, exploring and learning about other cultures and their way of life.   I have never been outside of the country, and I cannot wait to go to Paris!  When you contribute, you are setting the stage for this future American diplomat to better represent his country!

I got lucky when I found Georgia Highlands, it's a school that works for me just as hard as I work for it. While cycling through jobs and never really reaching my true potential, I was afraid I'd never be able to go back to school and finish my undergrad (which I had so callously left behind when I joined the work force in my early 20's). 

But ever since applying to GHC as a mature student, my world view has changed, I realize that anything is possible for me and that I am in charge of my future! Not only does Europe and the UK have so much to offer culturally, but traveling and exploring abroad will give me a chance to see how I fit into the global market, and give me firsthand experience with different and exciting ideas. By contributing to our campaign, you will be investing in a young entrepreneur who, after experiencing the larger world, will be better equipped to understand the relationships we all share, and to work with small American businesses to compete in the global market. 

Through your help, a future nurse, computer science major, artist, diplomat, and an entrepreneur can learn how to make the world a little bit better place.
story_txt:
We are five college students with very different goals and very different dreams, but we all have one dream in common: We want to study abroad this summer!New experiences unleash potential, and the London/Paris study abroad trip will expand our dedication to learning and will drive us to reach out, try new ideas, and pay it forward! You can help unleash our potential by making a donation today. 5 students, 5 lives, 5 new chances to pay it forward. Even $10 helps!Donate today!
A LITTLE SOMETHING ABOUT US:  We are learners for life!  All five of us attend Georgia Highlands College, which has five campuses spread across Northwest Georgia.  Also, we are undeniably passionate about school, and we are just infinitely stellar people.  More about us below!
YOU CAN CHANGE OUR LIVES:  This campaign goes a long way in helping us with funds.  Unfortunately, it costs a pretty penny to travel to Europe and back. Fortunately, your contribution of $10 or $100 will go a long way to helping us reach our goal!  Any little bit helps.  Be sure to check out the fun perks. Grab one before they disappear!
ONCE AGAIN:  We are so lucky to get to go on this trip.  This trip is the end of our Western Civilization II course where we will be on the beaches of Normandy for the 70th anniversary of D-Day!  How cool is that?  To be at the epicenter of such a major modern historical event is a gift in itself.  We want to take you with us.  By donating, you are helping us not only go to Europe, but we will document it that way you can experience the journey, too! Where is the money going?
We are asking for $7,500. All of this goes directly to our trip to help us cover the costs of:
Flight Expenses 
Travel Insurance
Basic Room and board  for the time that we will be there - This does not include a number of our meals
The cost of the course that we will be taking while abroad
Why does it all matter anyway?
This trip will contribute to our education and expand our views on our ever changing global world.  America is falling behind in world leadership, but you can help us change that!  By contributing, you are building future leaders who have a better understanding of our world. 
If you have ever traveled, you know firsthand how it opens up your eyes to new possibilities and expands your view of problems that we still face as a human family.  Help us get out of Rome, Georgia and spread our wings!
Some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Tell your friends and family to join in on the fun.

story:
A Conference on Bohemia in Southern California - A Much Needed Addition to The History of Those Who Followed The Beat of a Different Drummer


JAY RUBY, Conference Organizer   

                             

·        Let me introduce myself. I am the organizer of the conference and art exhibit.  I am an emeritus professor at Temple University in Philadelphia, PA. who has written over 12 books, 75 scholarly articles and organized various conferences since 1968. My recent research has concentrated on Southland Bohemia with a study of Coffee House Positano in Malibu and The Property - a community of creative people also in Malibu.

BEYOND BAROQUE, Host and Sponsor

Beyond Baroque, located in Venice, California, was founded in 1968, and is one of the United States' leading independent Literary | Arts Centers and public spaces.

Why This Conference is Important

The conference represents a rare opportunity for people interested in Southland Bohemia to engage in an exciting and revealing exchange of ideas. The result will be the first overview of Southern California’s alternative creative worlds. When published, it will be available to anyone wishing to know more about what has been a well-kept secret. Southland Bohemia has, at times, been overshadowed by Greenwich Village in New York and North Beach in San Francisco. It is our intention to correct that oversight. The amazing works of extraordinary people will be critically examined and the varied ways in which a distinctive Bohemia was created will be revealed. This is a first-ever event of its kind; it will alter forever how Bohemia is understood. We need your support to achieve this singular goal.

 

The Program and Speakers 

Over a three day period, these speakers will present papers and enter into a discussion with each other and the audience.

1. Print Culture on the Arroyo Seco, 1895-1947 by Jessica Holada, Director of Special Collections and Archives at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo.

                                        

                  Abby San Encino in the Arroyo Seco - founded by Clyde                                 Jackson Browne who was the singer Jackson Browne's grandfather

2. Bohemian Los Angeles, 1910-1925: Artists, Vagabonds, Movie Folk, and Muckrakers by Beth Gates Warren, independent scholar and consultant in the field of fine art photography and formerly the director of the Photographs Department at Sotheby’s.       

                                           

          Margrethe Mather and Edward Weston by Imogen Cunningham, 1922

3. Edendale: The Political Importance of Los Angeles' Bohemian Community by Daniel Hurewitz, an associate professor of history at Hunter College, CUNY, in New York.

                             

                                 Los Angeles' 1st Movie Studios in Edendale

4. Jake Zeitlin and His Circle: The Emergence of Modernism in Southern California, 1920-1940 by Michael Dawson, a private dealer and appraiser specializing in rare books and fine art photography.

                                             

                                                     Jake Zeitlin

5. Topanga Beach: Where the Wild West met Hollywood, surf culture, and psychedelia by Pablo Capra who grew up in Topanga Beach where the Wild West met Hollywood, surf culture, and psychedelia.

                      

                   A Beach Party at Topanga Beach, 1960s by John Clemens

6. Topanga: Bohemia’s Natural High Point by Michele Johnson, author/editor of The Topanga Story  and a 30-year resident of Topanga.

                               

                                  Actor Will Geer and his Topanga Theatre

7. Subcultures Within the L.A. Art World, 1970-1980 by Richard Hertz a beachcomber, citrus farmer, educator, and writer who was a dean at the Arts Center College of Design, Pasadena and author of Jack Goldstein and the Calarts Mafia.

                                 

                                           Tetra by Elyn Zimmerman

8. Bohemianism and the California Surfer by Kristin Lawler, an assistant Professor of Sociology at the College of Mount Saint Vincent in New York City.

                                 

                                    Legendary Surfer, Miki Dora, 1964

9.  In the Shadow of Los Angeles: The West Coast Contribution to the New American Cinema  by Josh Guilford, Brown University.


                                              

                                        Ron Rice,Avant Garde Filmmaker

10. Salka Viertel and the Old Bohemians by Chris Freeman, a professor of English and Gender Studies at the University of Southern California. by Josh Guilford, Brown University.

                                           

                                                     Salka Viertel

11.  Women and Bohemia: The Southern California Example by Lois Banner, a Professor Emerita of History, University of Southern California and a founder of the field of women's history in the 1970s.

                                 

                                    Judy Chicago, The Dinner Party

12. Bohemia as Neighborhood, Symbol System, and Practice: The Case of Venice, California by Andrew Deener, an assistant professor of Sociology at the University of Connecticut.

                               

13. Bruce Boyd – Zen Poet of Venice West by William Mohr, an associate professor of English at California State University, Long Beach.          

                           

               Photo by Bill Margolis, Jim Morris (left) with Bruce Boyd (right)

14. Space/Time and the Radical Image: Wallace Berman’s Semina by Harry Polkinhorn a psychoanalyst and professor of English and Comparative Literature at San Diego State University.

                            


15.   Yesterday is Tomorrow is the Mirror: Dennis Hopper's Photography or the Actor Behind the Camera by William A. Nericcio  a cultural studies professor at San Diego State University

                       


Concluding Remarks by Lionel Rolfe, a working journalist since he was 19 has worked for the Pismo Beach Times and San Francisco Chronicle, the Los Angeles Times, the Los Angeles Free Press, Psychology Today and several other mostly California publications over the years.               

        

An Art Exhibit: Scenes from the Property - 1965 - 1979 

 The Exhibit “Scenes from the Property” features the work of three artists who lived at a Malibu arts community -  the Property – Steve Kahn, Lita Albuquerque and Jim Fiorito. The realist photographs of Kahn contrasts nicely with the impressionistic paintings of Jim Fiorito and the work of Lita Albuquerque offers yet a third way of representing this place. 

                             A Sample of the works to be exhibited.                              

                                       

                               Piano under a tree, Steve Kahn, 1970s 

                                 

                                      Back of Positano, Jim Fiorito, 1973

                           

                          Malibu Line, Lita Albuquerque, 1978

A Performance 

Poet William Mohr will present Beat poet Stuart Perkoff's poetry and jazz play, Round Midnite.  A  five-scene, one-act play, set in Venice West, where it was given its first and only set of performances in the late 1950s. 

Publication

The speakers will edit their presentations into publishable papers that will be published as Southland Bohemia: The Conference Proceedings. San Diego State University Press has expressed a strong interest in publishing this book.

WHY THIS CONFERENCE IS IMPORTANT TO ME AND OTHERS

Funds are needed to pay for the costs of the conference and art exhibit – travel, lodging and meals for the speakers and administration costs necessary to mount the event.  The art exhibit costs include producing exhibit prints and framing.  As state and federal governments are slashing the budgets that supported the arts, social sciences and humanities, traditional ways of funding have almost completely dried up. If the production of knowledge about understudied topics such as Bohemia in Southern California are to be supported, non-traditional sources of revenue such as Indiegogo must be utilized.  I believe this is the first attempt to fund such a conference through crowd funding. During the last few years while I was researching a Bohemian coffee house in Malibu, Coffee House Positano and a Malibu arts community, The Property, I became acutely aware of how hidden was the history of Bohemia in the Southland.  My  intention is to seek publication of the conference papers so that a wide audience can become more aware of the 140 year old history of those who followed the beat of a distant drum.

WHAT THIS CONFERENCE WILL ACHIEVE

Those who contribute to this campaign will make it possible for people well versed in many different aspects of Southland Bohemia to meet and present their ideas and engage in a productive exchange of ideas, points of view and even new hypotheses about the unconventional. The results of the conference will be published, thus making available to the public a much needed overview of Bohemia in the Southland.

I am seeking funds to pay for:

1. The transportation and housing costs of some of the speakers who live outside of Southern California - only four out of thirteen speakers - and a modest meal allowance.

2. The facilities fee needed to use Beyond Baroque and a fee to administer the monies.

3. A very modest honorarium for the speakers. The organizer receives no compensation.

4. Union fees for the musicians necessary for the performance of the Stuart Perkoff play

5. Costs for assembling the art exhibit – frames, transportation of the art, etc.

We offer people who contribute:

Recognition as a CONTRIBUTOR, ANGEL, or BENEFACTOR as well as some new books, some ebooks and some vintage publications and some DVDs.

Should we fail to reach our entire goal, we will attempt to use the funds to attract new investors to make up the difference.  If after 60 days, we fail, all of the monies collected will be refunded.

The Impact

The conference on Southland Bohemia will expand our knowledge of the unique contributions Southern California made to the history of Bohemia. It will explore how Bohemia was fundamentally altered by the climate, the geography and culture of Southern California and, of course by Hollywood.

This is my first experience funding a conference with crowd funding.  I have organized over ten conferences at universities since 1968, using granting agencies such as the National Endowment for the Humanities.  To my knowledge, this is the first Indiegogo campaign designed to fund a conference.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can’t contribute, please let others know about this campaign. Encourage them to both contribute and spread the word. LIKE us on Facebook. Send a notice to any groups you belong to. Mention us on your blog. The more people know about this campaign, the more likely it is that we will get the funding we need.

it possible for people well versed in many different aspects of Southland
Bohemia to meet and present their ideas and engage in a productive exchange of
ideas, points of view and even new hypotheses about the unconventional. The results of the conference will be published, thus making available to the public a much needed overview of Bohemia in the Southland.
I am seeking funds to pay for: 

1. The transportation and housing costs of some of the speakers who live
outside of Southern California - only four out of thirteen speakers - and a modest meal allowance.
2. The facilities fee needed to use Beyond Baroque
and a fee to administer the monies.
3. A very modest honorarium for the speakers. The organizer receives no compensation.
4. Union fees for the musicians necessary for the
performance of the Stuart Perkoff play
5. Costs for assembling the art exhibit – frames, transportation
of the art, etc.

We offer people who contribute: Recognition as a CONTRIBUTOR, ANGEL, or BENEFACTOR as well as some new books, some ebooks and some vintage publications and some DVDs.Should we fail to reach our entire goal, we will attempt to use the
funds to attract new investors to make up the difference.  If after 60 days, we fail, all of the monies
collected will be refunded.
The ImpactThe conference on Southland Bohemia will expand our knowledge of the unique contributions Southern California made to the history of Bohemia. It will explore how Bohemia was fundamentally altered by the climate, the geography and culture of Southern California and, of course by Hollywood. This is my first experience funding a conference with crowd funding.  I have organized over ten conferences at universities since 1968, using granting agencies such as the National Endowment for the Humanities.  To my knowledge, this is the first Indiegogo campaign designed to fund a conference.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you just can’t contribute, please let others know about this campaign. Encourage them to both contribute and spread the word. LIKE us on Facebook. Send a notice to any groups you belong to. Mention us on your blog. The more people know about this campaign, the more likely it is that we will get the funding we need.

story:
Join the March

Want to March for Kids for 2015? Find out how!

Mercy Home for Boys & Girls relies almost exclusively on donations from caring people everywhere to save kids in crisis. Join us in our March for Kids by making a donation that will provide the 40 young women living in our girls home in Chicago with a safe and stable home.

Without you, more girls may be lost to the streets. You can help us make sure that tonight, a girl has a roof over her head, clothing, meals and a warm bed. Even more, you can give her the safety and security she needs to be a child again. The encouragement she needs to dream big. And the tools she needs to build a bright future.

Read more at http://marchforkids.org

story:
What is Global Voice?

Global Voice promotes youth leadership and development through cultural exchange and service-learning—a concept where learning takes place through volunteer service projects that benefit communities at home and abroad. The founders (the Griffin family) created the program in 2003 where they performed a cultural exchange with a group of Northern Ireland youth and youth from Lyon and Storey counties. Community projects were targeted around hunger and homelessness as well as religious divisions and beautification projects at two youth centers.

Global Voice has continued this model with yearly
trips to locations in Costa Rica and Mexico including Ajijic, Teacapan and
Loreto. We have worked with schools, orphanages and other organizations in
practicing the cultural exchange through service model.  Trips usually last 2 weeks in duration and involve fundraising, planning, post trip reflections and continued service projects at home.  

Global Voice programs are sponsored through Community Chest, Inc. This organization strives to promote community building, youth leadership and social justice programs in Northern Nevada. CCI’s methodology regarding its youth programs places service-learning at its core; using this methodology, youth learn about themselves, their communities and the world in which they live by working together.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This year our Global Voice team will be traveling to Galway, Ireland. Our high school students have been working hard to raise $25,000 to pay their expenses. They need to cover transportation, lodging, food and supplies for their service project. To date the kids have been able to secure $7,000 and are still working! We need your help to continue!

                                         How can you help?

                 $30........One night of accommodations for one student

                 $100…..Will allow the group to experience some Irish culture

                 $288…..Full trip accommodations for one student

                 $500......Will help to pay for the supplies needed for the service project.

                 $1,000…...A plane ticket for one student

                 $1,500….Meals for the group for the trip

                 $3,500...Lodging for the group for the trip

What will you get in return? Well, apart from helping develop the leadership skills of youth and bettering communities in Ireland and Nevada...

1. For a donation of just $25 you will receive a handwritten thank you card including a picture of our completed service project!

2. 15 lucky donors will receive a personal service project for only $100! Our group of 12 Global Voice participants will be made available.

3. One of our Global Voice youth is a very talented artist. For only $200 she will create a one of a kind masterpiece just for you!

4. Have you ever wanted to visit Ireland? For only $500 you can - in spirit! We will take a picture of you with us. You will visit some famous sites in Ireland, help to complete our service project and partake in the fun! We will also create a picture book of your journey for you to share with all of your friends and family. There are only two of these, so act fast!

The Impact

By participating in Global Voice youth learn to...

  • Think about issues globally.
  • Become strong community leaders.
  • Realize the importance of giving.
  • Understand and value the contributions of different cultures.
  • Learn the value of service.
  • Actively engage in the life of their communities.
  • Develop a love for learning through hands-on experience.

These skills will follow the participating youth from Nevada and Ireland for life, and will lead to stronger communities!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, it doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out about our campaign.
  • Visit our website: http://www.communitychestnevada.net/

Thanks for taking the time to check out and support the work we've been doing.

story:
To my community members,

I'm Sammy Granquist and I need your help. I'm in my third year of French Language studies and have applied for a school trip to France that only a handful of kids get to go on. Nearly half of each eligible grade level applied for this special trip with 15 slots. I was one of 4 eighth graders to be chosen.

The teachers and administrators who evaluated the students not only looked at our grades and language ability but also our volunteer contributions to the school community, the larger community and if we would represent our school and nation well.

Next May my classmates and I will go to France for 2 weeks where we will tour Paris for 2 days then take the train to Tours in the Loire Valley. In Tours we will each go off to stay with a family for French immersion studies -and to experience French countryside living! We are there for about a week then back to Paris for more sightseeing and then off to home.

This is very exciting but I need help paying the $3600. it will take to get me there. So far, I've applied for a scholarship which might help with up to $500. (I find out about this in mid-December). I'm looking for baby sitting jobs and using my savings for this trip. My parents made the down payment and are saving as much as they can. And I've received a lot of help so far from many of my community members but I still have a long way to go to make sure that I get there!

Can you help me with a contribution? It all helps!

Thank You!!!!!!

story:
Riley's Kids

Hi! I'm Riley, a 17 year old girl, on a crazy mission lead by God to open a 60 bed orphanage in Kibwezi, Kenya in June 2014. I was blessed with the opportunity to fill "Gail's House" with 60 orphaned kids.  I am currently speaking at churches and doing other fundraisers but as you can see I have a lot to raise in a little time.  We are working towards shipping a container, finishing the kitchen, buying a car in Kenya, and many other necessities to make Riley's Kids feel safe and loved. 

"Gails House" is the only 100% solar powered orphanage in Kenya.  It also already has a  bore hole. The orphanage has yet to have sweet Kenyan kids in it.  The building has been complete for a couple of years. Hopefully with everyone's help we can get the doors open.  I am so excited for the opportunity to make a lasting impression on these kids lives.

I have been to Kibwezi the last four years where in June 2013 I opened my first school called Pamoja.  We built and are funding the school.  Pamoja has 50 students that attend primary school there.

As you can see my heart is definitely in Kibwezi as I plan to make this my home after college.  

Keep up:

  • Facebook (Generation Next)
  • www.generationnextcares.org
  • rileysfaith.blogspot.com


Other Ways You Can Help!

  • Praying
  • Cribs, bottles, clothes, diapers, lotions, shampoo

story:
WHAT IS THE LAKEFRONT LITERACY PROJECT (LLP)?

Thanks in part to grants from Neighborhood Connections and Cleveland Neighborhood Progress, in summer 2015 The Lakefront Literacy Project is bringing literature and a love of learning to Cleveland’s Euclid Beach Park’s lakefront with a custom-crafted mobile library, part of the renowned “Little Free Library” network.

Reading material donations from Cleveland Public Library, local book sales, in kind donations and YOU will be free for anyone visiting the park to borrow. Interactive bookmarks designed by The LLP team encourage anonymous discussions amongst our readership and a book club is in the works!

We believe the fun of reading on the beach will translate into increased traffic at our local public and school libraries, a win-win for everyone!


WHEN CAN I CHECK OUT A BOOK, MAGAZINE, OR NEWSPAPER?

Join us for the library’s Kickoff Celebration on Saturday, May 30th from 11:30-2pm and be one of the first to borrow a book!

In Summer of 2015 this FREE library staffed by neighborhood volunteers will appear at the Beach during weekends, holidays, and special programmed events and house a rotating collection of books, magazines, and newspapers catering to both children and adults and our English and Russian speaking North Collinwood neighbors.

THE TEAM


Ali, Emily, and Robert (left to right, respectively) are residents of North Collinwood, a narrow slice of Cleveland tucked in between I-90 and Lake Erie on the east side of the City. In addition to social activism, all three are actively engaged in the neighborhood scene: Ali and Emily sit on the Board of Directors of Northeast Shores Development Corporation (Fiscal Sponsor for The Lakefront Literacy Project) and Robert is the Marketing Chair of the “Euclid Beach Blast!”, an annual, homegrown community event on this same Beach. Each member comes to the table with a diversity of experiences and talent including architecture, engineering, public art, and design… and apparently grant writing! We came together to fill the literacy gap in our community and turn a community hub (Euclid Beach Park) into an educational asset for people of all ages and reading levels!


WHAT WE NEED:

The bulk of the work for this project is organizing and a lot of volunteer hours, but we still need cold, hard cash to make our vision a reality!

-  MONEY… Most of our funds will go to purchase a safe and sturdy book cart and racks for magazines, as well as marketing materials to let people know about our project and the big kickoff.  Of course, we also will need to buy books and periodical subscriptions and sustain the library’s collection throughout the summer. Above and beyond our $500 goal and we can amp up the awesome (think: free food, giveaways) at our Kickoff Celebration at Euclid Beach Park on May 30th!


INCENTIVES FOR YOUR HELP!

See sidebar… every dollar helps! THANK YOU!!!

RISKS & REWARDS

-  While we don’t anticipate a shortage of reading material, some of the donated books may be duds – something no one would want to read, books not in suitable shape, etc. Help us curate a truly great library by donating books – from your own collection or select our $25 Incentive Level and we’ll pick up a copy for the library in your name!

-  Borrowing a book is free and the return date is flexible. We anticipate some books will walk away to be well read and loved, never to return again. We’ll frequently replenish our stock and curate new themed shelves (think: science fiction, Cleveland History, healthy habits) and permit only one book per person per visit.

-  This is a volunteer-led initiative. While we received two small grants to initiate this project, not one contributor is getting compensated for our time. For the first summer, the library will appear on weekends, holidays, and during special events. Due to the Cleveland Metroparks’ master planning, we do not have permission at this time for the library to become a permanent fixture, accessible 24/7. We sincerely believe the community will love this amenity on Lake Erie and volunteers will emerge to staff the mobile library, allowing it to roll out more frequently throughout the summer and for summers to come!

- Funds raised will help us maintain our membership in the "Free Little Library" network, which opens us up to wide-reaching press and... more books! 


GET MORE INVOLVED:

Does this project sounds great to you? Would you like to get even more involved above and beyond supporting the campaign?

- VOLUNTEERS… Have an hour to spare? Email us @ read.euclidbeach@gmail.com and let us know of your interest and availability for staffing the library. The position is fun and easy… and yes you can sit down and read a magazine on the job! 

- BOOKS… and more books (and magazines!). Spring clean your bookshelves and donate the books your children outgrew, the bestseller you read once and never will again, the magazines collecting dust on your coffee table. Email us @ read.euclidbeach@gmail.com and let us know you’re happy to purge and donate! We’ll be accepting books on May 30th, but if you’re in Cleveland, we’d be more than happy to make your load lighter sooner!

story:
Short Summary

Dare 2B Digital's mission is to re-define the image of CS/STEM globally.  Our goal is to increase digital fluency of young women through student engagement and mentoring.  By supporting us, you will play a vital role in changing the gender dynamic in STEM fields, particularly in computer science.

Since 2009, our highly successfully Dare 2B Digital conference has excited, engaged and educated young women with support from industry mentors, parents, government and academia. 

We have exciting plans to expand in 2015!  We are introducing the Dare 2B Digital Innovation Challenge on February 28, 2015, which allows conference attendees to serve as ambassadors, recruiting co-ed team members from their community to solve a global problem.  We will provide knowledge, technology tools and industry mentors to support the competition.  Teams will submit their solutions via video and will be invited to share their results at the Dare 2B Digital Film Festival taking place on May 2, 2015, where they will be awarded scholarships, internships and prizes.

Don't wait. Get on board! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need financial support for the Innovation Challenge and Film Festival. We also need funding to include more young women from low income communities.

  • Our goal is to raise $10,000 to provide scholarships, internships and prizes
  • All funds raised will go toward delivering the Dare 2B Digital program
  • Perks include VIP complimentary tickets, gift packs, recognition on website and at events

Be part of the solution!  Help develop our future talent pipeline.

The Impact

The U.S. Department of Labor estimates that by 2020, there will be more the 1.4 million job openings in the computing-related fields. With current graduation trends, only about 30% of those jobs will be filled by U.S. bachelor's degree. At approximately half of the population, girls are currently the most valuable talent pool.
If the technologies continue to be developed by only half of the population then we are all missing out on the creativity, innovation and possibilities that savvy technical women can bring.

With your support we can increase the gender balance in computer science and STEM.

Risks & Challenges

Delivering a quality program is a significant financial risk. Although we have a strong five year track record of support from industry partners, we need additional funding to scale this program and reach a wider audience.
  • We have the experience, passion and commitment to deliver a world-class program
  • By leveraging technology, such as Live Streaming and Intelligent Mentor Matching, we can reach more students with fewer resources

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for sticking with us to the end. If you cannot support Dare 2B Digital monetarily, we would appreciate if you share this project and campaign with your social networks via the Indiegogo share tools.

We would like to reach as many potential donors as possible and every share, like, and tweet will have an impact.

Let's make some noise and really dare to be digital!

story:
The School of Hope Project will provide 50 Odisha children with a school––Kindergarten through Grade 10.  Hindered by caste discrimination and social inequality, these children are left without hope of ever gaining a quality education.  The School of Hope Project will help break this vicious cycle of poverty.

About our Project

The School of Hope is a boarding school that cares for, clothes, and feeds the children of Odisha. It is a home-away-from-home where children, either orphaned or placed by a widowed mother too poor to provide, can find comfort and love while gaining an education that will change their lives forever. 

Our goal: $15,000 to educate 50 children currently enrolled for the academic year 2014–2014.

Would you like to share our vision?


Changing the Life of a Child

Women widowed by the horribly violent riots in 2007 and 2008, were left destitute. They needed help with their children’s immediate needs, and they worried about their children’s future. With the nearest school a 6 hour drive away, the younger children had to stay with their mothers who worked in the fields as daily wage laborers. The older children, often left alone during the day, were open to involvement in drugs and petty crime. The future of the children of Kandhamal region, Odisha, was in jeopardy. Having a local school in the region became imperative.

The school will be accessible to children in remote areas as a beacon of hope for a bright future to a large number of Odisha’s children––forgotten until now. Your gift will make a tangible, lasting difference in lives of many people.

Today 50 children, 4 to 6 years old, are enrolled. Our goal of $15,000 will cover room and board, uniforms, books, and tuition for up to 50 children for one school year. The cost to support one child is $300/year or $25/month. 


Our Future Goals

  • Continue “The School of Hope” as a grade school, and as children advance, to begin high school classes with the same excellent standards of education.
  • Increase student capacity to 100 each year for the next twelve years.
  • Expand to a high school as the children advance through middle school.
  • After graduating from high school, the children will then have the option of attending a college or a technical school, thereby becoming self-sustaining.

Developing the Community

Education is the only way to provide hope for the future. With strong bonds to their family and community, the students will return to their villages and contribute to the prosperity of the community with leadership, better job opportunities, and new programs like this. The School of Hope will affect the lives of generations to come… Knowledge builds bridges of tolerance and friendship and will diminish riots/violence in the future.

What you do today can change the lives of entire villages and communities, a ripple effect for years and generations to come…


Where Your Money Goes

Divine Word Missionaries is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization that serves as the fiscal agent for the School of Hope Project, officially run by the Sisters of St. Joseph of Annecy. The funds collected for this project will cover educational expenses for the children enrolled in the School of Hope in Kandhamal, Odisha, India. We have partnered with the Sisters of St. Joseph of Annecy in India because of their solid track record of building schools and growing school attendance. 

Please visit our website at www.svdmissions.org/our_work/odisha_india.aspx


Matching

If your company does charitable matching, we encourage you to submit your generous donation to accelerate our fundraising. Your donation could do twice as much! You can e-mail OdishaChildren@gmail.com for the Tax ID number for your paperwork.


Everything Helps!

If you are unable to help financially, we would truly appreciate your help in passing this campaign on to family and friends. Use the awesome Indiegogo share tools or just forward the link. Together we can turn despair into hope and make a life-changing difference for children, families, and communities!

Make sure to follow us on Facebook at www.facebook.com/odishaschoolofhope

Thank you for everything you do.

Total amount to be raised for the academic year 2014–2015 is $15,000

story: .

Short Summary

My name is Sara Bakay, and I am an aspiring actress. I've been doing this since I was about 5 years old (nearly 20 years), and I finally have the chance to be seen by some VERY important people! I auditioned for a talent association, and they selected me to go to New York, representing their company, to audition in front of many agents, managers, and casting directors who are looking for new faces.

  • This convention is how Katie Holmes, Josh Duhamel, Sean William Scott, and many other stars were discovered!
  • I'll be taking part in 6 competitions, including acting, singing, and songwriting!

I have been fighting so hard for my dream, and now I feel as if it is at my fingertips. I will be working on my end to get as many hours as possible at my current jobs to pay for everything, but my minimum wage salary does not allow me to make the goal in the afforded time.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I need $6,000 total.
  • This pays for 6 days/nights in the hotel, 10 competitions, a personal stylist for the competitions, a photo shoot (with stylist), prints from the photo shoot, the banquet, workshops, 4 months of training (including private acting coaching), and so much more!
  • There are some great perks for donating!
  • For every $150 we raise, you'll get to hear a new song played by the band, "We Ain't Them" and sang by me!

The Impact

All it takes is for one casting director or agent to notice me. I am ready to show them my passion for this career. Last year, I made 4 independent films, a commercial, and recorded music. I've also been in 8 professional plays with Jenny Wiley Theatre, including tours. You can find me on IMDb, youtube, and Facebook, and Model Mayhem. Your donation is very important in helping me take the next step to further my career. Even if you can only give a few dollars, those few dollars can make such a difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not afford to help, there are other things that you can do!

  • Share this with your friends, family, business partners.
  • Save your spare change, and make a goal to donate it 1 day every week.

Thank you so much for your support and encouragement. I'm so glad I have people in my life that I can depend on who have faith in and love me.

story:
Kendel wrote this himself in English.

Before I came to the orphanage, my life was not good, and for my family too.  Before I came to the orphanage I lived with my mother, father, three sisters and two brothers in the countryside (Labegue).

My father and my mother did not have big possibility.  They could not help me with school.  We had a small garden and sold produce, but we did not have enough to eat.  This meant that there was no possibility for school.  But I had a chance.  I was in a small primary school in Labegue, and was intelligent.  When a Belgian Catholic Sister (Sister Rosa) visited our little school, my teachers spoke with her about me and she said that I want to help him in school.  She started paying for me in the seventh grade through the ninth grade at St. Martin, but got breast cancer and could not stay any longer in Haiti.

When I was in the ninth grade I was sad because I like school so much but could not pay.  I heard some people talking about the Orphanage where they accept those who do not have the possibility, those who do not have a mother or father who can help them

I did not then know M. Jean-Louis, but when I was at the cathedral church one day they showed me an American, Brother Harry, from the orphanage.  I asked him, “Please can you help me to go to the Orphanage?”  He said that he could not, but that he could speak with M. Jean-Louis for me.  He helped me to meet M. Jean-Louis I explained to him a lot about my life, and he said “OK, you can come to the orphanage.”

When I arrived at the Orphanage my life changed.  I continued to attend school at St. Martin.  I completed my philo year (the terminal grade), and passed the exam that will allow me to apply to go to university in Haiti.

I have a dream for my future life and for the future of Haiti as well.  We know that Haiti is the poorest country, but I think that if we have good national productivity for our families, we will not need to buy food from other countries.  For that I would like to become a wonderful agronomist for Haiti, and after I finish learning agronomy, I will like to return to the orphanage to provide service, help with food production, and make a big garden to grow bananas, corn, beans….  I thank you for all you do for me.

 

Kendel was selected by the director of the orphanage, M. Jean-Louis, as the student most deserving of receiving a university education because of his dedication to others, his scholarship, and his service to the orphanage. The orphanage does not have the funds to send Kendel to university, particularly after the population almost doubled following the tragic earthquake. $1500 will pay for a year at a university in Haiti. Agriculture is the primary occupation in Haiti and rekindling the once vibrant farms will go a long way towards enabling the people of Haiti to support themselves.

Visit our website: MFOFoundation.org

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

And that’s all there is to it.

story: My high school funds all sports and almost all clubs but refuses to fund the chess team. This leaves the team i'm on with no money to even compete in some tournaments AND WE CAN'T AFFORD TIMERS! Timers are a necessity and if we cant afford any we can't practice as well. We need to raise 1,000 to keep the team going and i'm asking for the person reading this' help. Please donate any sum to keep my chess team going.

story:
Bring a Child to the Listening Playground

By donating you are directly sponsoring another seat for a child to join the musical event.

The children we work with are the most marginalized in their society. Because of their status, they must fight stigma and fear. This event, part of an ongoing project in Rwanda, will help them connect with each other, with their families, make them stronger, and bring them some joy and relief. Please donate today.

Rwanda Youth Music / Musicians without Borders

In 2012 Musicians without Borders initiated a yearlong music project for 25 youth leaders in Kigali, Rwanda.

They were trained to use the power of music to bring joy and healing to hundreds of underprivileged children.

Now, a year later, on March 2nd, the youth leaders will receive a diploma for their training. There will be a ceremony with all of the children and families the youth leaders have worked with in the program. It will be a beautiful event that the youth leaders are organizing themselves.

For this music event we have invited Keren Rosenbaum, an interdisciplinary composer from New York. She will work with the youth leaders for one week, preparing and guiding them to produce and run the event. Your donation today will help us reach our goal so we can include 800 people. Youth leaders, children, parents, elders, even babies, will be actively engaged in a huge musical score/performance, creating music together, following a musical game that the youth leaders are designing and will guide themselves.

Communication practices are one of the key factors in maintaining a healthy, supportive community, which these children and their families need the most. Authentic creativity in an art form can result in one of the highest levels of self-expression, stress release, and an immediate inspiration that quickly spreads. Music brings healing and establishes bonds that ensure a more peaceful future. You can make a lasting difference in Rwanda.

Please, take a moment and consider how you can help. Even a small donation of $5.50 will cover the cost of one guest.

The Goal: 800 Children and their Families

Here's a breakdown of the costs:

  • Rent - $238
  • Chairs for 800 - $304
  • Transportation City for 650 - $541
  • Transportation Suburb for 150 - $284
  • Food and Water for 800 - $2794
  • Sound System - $244

Total: $4405
Per person: 4405/800 = $5.5

What about transaction/commission costs?

The organization pledged to cover 100% of these costs, so all your donations go directly to sponsoring the participation of a child.

What if we don't reach the goal?

In any case this event will happen. We will invite as many children as we manage to raise funds for.

What if we raise more than the goal?

The amount we set as the goal is the bare minimum we need in order to invite and care for all children in the program and their families. We hope to be able to raise much more so we can also invest in material, simple music instruments, and in the end, support the ongoing project that continues yearlong and reaches so many children who deserve to experience the joy of music.

The Listening Revolution / REFLEX

All members in REFLEX, from various artistic forms, are dedicated to promote and encourage innovative compositions and performances inviting those who believe music and art can change the world.

Our mission is to inspire and explore forgotten listening tools and create new situations to communicate using innovative ideas.

The Reflexive Listening Playground is one of the main tools to create situations for active listening. We believe in independent thinking and the empowerment of the experimental self. In listening revolution playfulness becomes a goal not just a mean of expression and then by composing it carefully inspires a different communication between individuals and within a community.

The listening playground is a safe environment which inspires an authentic listening experience. Each individual can experience their personal contribution to the community while being inspired to contribute more. It’s a process of growth. It introduces tools of listening and presents new or other ways to communicate, understanding others and being understood by one-self.

Each of us has the power to create and make our community and this world a better place. We simply need to know how to give each one the space to be heard.

story:
On August 25, 2013, two women decided that they had to do something about the Christians who are suffering and dying daily for their faith. The women were an Armenian lawyer, Rita Mahdessian, and an American professor, Siobhan Nash-Marshall.  They recently established the Christians in Need Foundation USA with the intention to safeguard and support the lives and culture of members of the ancient Christian communities of the world. 

Christians in Need Foundation USA seeks to help these persecuted brothers and sisters by utilizing an innovative, grassroots approach.  We seek to stem sectarian conflicts through education.  We recruit young men and women who belong to Christian communities in peril, and facilitate their entry into American liberal arts colleges and universities. This ensures the physical safety of these young people, it helps broaden their intellectual horizon, and acquaints them with the dynamic of Western democracy and religious tolerance. These students return to their communities when it is safe for them to do so, equipped with intellectual tools that will enable them to promote the continuance of their Christian faith and culture.

To accomplish this goal, WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT TODAY.  Please give generously to help us save our persecuted brothers and sisters in Christ! May He bless your generosity, and remember than what we do for the least of His children, we do for God Himself.

story:
You have probably heard about STOP’s fight to save the mental health clinics. We’re in this struggle for people like Diane Adams. After Diane lost her son to violence in 1996, she sank into a deep depression. The only way she was able to find the will to survive was through the free services at the Auburn Gresham mental health clinic. That’s why, when the city threatened to close her clinic, she knew she had to do everything she could to stop it.

STOP was there to support Diane to become one of the leaders of the fight to save the clinics. I’m asking you today if you can be there to support STOP.

For nearly 10 years STOP has been at the forefront of resisting the war on the poor. We have:

Built the Mental Health Movement, which saved 4 Southside mental health clinics in 2008 and is fighting to reverse the recent closure of half of the city’s mental health clinics.

Organized 7 tenants associations in subsidized housing, one of these is Grove Parc, which in 2008 halted the displacement of over 500 families and prevented the elimination of half of Woodlawn's subsidized housing.

Preserved the Kimbark subsidized buildings and won the hiring of residents to work on the rehab.

Developed Fearless Leading by the Youth, which helped improve conditions in the juvenile detention center, by ensuring access to clean clothes and cleaner facilities. FLY also leads a campaign for a Southside trauma center.

STOP’s mission is to advance economic and social human rights by organizing and developing leadership among people most affected by economic and racial oppression. Our base has grown from an initial group of tenants from a single housing complex to include over 1,200 tenants from 5 complexes and 800 homeowners, youth, mental health patients, homeless and unemployed people, and community allies.

With active campaigns around housing, mental health, trauma care, and juvenile justice STOP is steady growing and deepening our roots. STOP is developing into an organization that can engage in this work for the long haul. But we need your support to help sustain STOP and build this movement.

Please send your gift of $10, $30, $50 or whatever you can afford. Know that your gift will go towards tools to help organize: from pens and clipboards for canvassing, to fliers and buses for actions, your contribution will go to the bricks and mortar of movement building. We thank you!!!


P.S. Helen Morley, a leader of the Mental Health Movement, always said, and sometimes shouted, “If you close my clinic I will die”. Sure enough, two months after they closed her clinic she passed away. Helen died a martyr of our movement. She fought for the rights of people with mental illness for decades and was never afraid to speak truth to power.

Helen Morley loved the struggle and inspired many with her fierceness. It is in her spirit that we continue to fight without fear for a world that respects and supports everybody and their human rights. We need your help to grow this struggle and continue her legacy, please make your donation today!

story:
The poor state of education in Haiti is one of the most critical challenges facing this island nation, which is only an hour’s flight from Miami. While hundreds of thousands of young Haitians aren’t afforded the opportunity for quality education, the wonderful programs at St. Joseph’s Home for Boys and Trinity House have been providing a complete education and family life for former street boys and child slaves for nearly 30 years.  However, this year, these two mission centers are in critical need of funds to support back-to-school related expenses and all donations collected through this appeal will help ensure these special young men can continue to develop into young leaders through quality education.

Current State of Primary and Secondary Education in Haiti

Unlike the universally available public education available in the United States and other developed nations around the world, the public education system in Haiti is unable to serve the needs of the Haitian population.  Only 67 percent of eligible students are enrolled in primary and elementary schools and the vast majority of these students are enrolled in private schools funded by NGOs or paid for out-of-pocket by parents who are likely struggling to even put food on the table. Of these students, less than 1/3 successfully complete 6 years of primary school education. And, as kids get older, success and enrollment rates drop to the point where secondary schools enroll only around a fifth of all of eligible children.

Moreover, not only is it difficult to find and pay for school in Haiti, it is extremely difficult to complete schooling without proper guidance and a stable home life. As is the case for students the world over, a support system outside of the classroom from parents, tutors, and peers is vital to achieving success in the classroom.

A Vision for Better Education in Haiti

Founded with a vision of empowering Haiti's young people to empower eachother, The St. Joseph Family was founded in 1985 to bring homeless boys off the streets of Port-au-Prince and provide them with a Christian home and family. From these humble beginnings, this Family has grown to include several mission centers, which care for and educate the disabled and disadvantaged children of Haiti.  Among these mission centers are the St. Joseph's Home for Boys in Port-au-Prince and Trinity House in Jacmel, which together provide a family life and education for 23 boys.


Leaders of St. Joseph’s Home for Boys and Trinity House have always felt that education is a crucial part of long-term success for boys when they graduate from the program and leave the homes. For that reason all boys are enrolled in private schools near the home, receive tutoring on weekday evenings, and have access to a computer lab with controlled Internet access. These opportunities, combined with their hard work, give them an excellent chance to succeed in the classroom and be part of the small number of youth in Haiti that have access to secondary vocational education or matriculation to other university programs after completing their secondary schooling.  The programs of the St. Joseph's Home for Boys and Trinity House provide the kind of all-encompassing support that only a family can offer and, as a result, graduates have gone on to further education, careers, and have become responsible parents themselves.

How You Can Help!

You can help send these youngsters back to school and improve their odds for the future by contributing to this campaign, which was created to represent the minimum costs to provide best quality education for the 23 boys at both homes during the 2013-2014 academic year. An estimated breakdown of these expenses for the upcoming academic year is:


$5,000 school registration when classes begin
$7,000 tuition
$4,000 for books and materials
$4,000 for 3 tutors
$7,000 for Internet access and other technology support during the school year
$3,000 for uniforms and other supplies, field trips, and events

How is my contribution getting to Haiti?

Contributions to this campaign will be accepted by Hearts with Haiti.  Hearts with Haiti is a US 501(c)3 non-profit organization founded in 2001 and invested in fostering a brighter, more sustainable future for the young people of Haiti. One way we see this vision fulfilled through the remarkable work of the St. Joseph Family. 100% of the funds collected during this campaign will go directly to fund a request from the St Joseph Family to cover these educational expenses during the 2013-2014 academic year.

For more information on Hearts with Haiti visit http://www.heartswithhaiti.org
For more information on the St. Joseph Family visit: http://www.sjfamilyhaiti.org
OR, join the over 4,000 supporters who are already friends of the St. Joseph Family, Haiti on Facebook.

What you'll receive in return?

Aside from the knowledge that your contribution is making an immediate impact on education for youth in Haiti, you can receive a number of wonderful perks in exchange for your giving.  We are happy to offer a selection of handmade Haitian art and collectibles available to donors at various levels.  Below are images of various Haitian art available through our organization. More information about these offers is available on the sidebar of this page.

campaign_city: Port au Prince and Jacmel, Haiti

story:
Little Jazz Man  

Extraordinary Learning Institute

Pledge of $22,000 goal

Little Jazz Man is a new book series for young children written by T. Lawrence Layton and illustrated by Seno Muminovic.  It has repeated lines, interactive characters and toys, and fun to read.  This is the first of a planned series of four books about Little Jazz Man.  ELI and the author will be donating 200 copies of Little Jazz Man free to families of children with special needs.

The author: T. Lawrence Layton Ph.D. has worked in the area of literacy and language for over 40 years.  He has been a University professor, researcher, author, and speech-language therapist serving children with autism, Down syndrome, language impairment, and developmental disorders.  He uses literacy and reading for his treatment.  Although he has published numerous professional books, articles, and tests, this is his first children’s book. 

The illustrator: Senad Muminovic is from Bosnia and Herzegovina.  He credits his father, Mahmut, for passing his talent for drawing on to him as a child. As young boy in school he would enter art competitions and win first place. During and following the Bosnian War (1992-1995) that resulted in the breakup of Yugoslavia, Senad did not have access to art supplies.  In 1997 he met volunteer relief workers from North Carolina who donated supplies to him so he could begin to paint again. In 1999 some of his friends organized an exhibition of his work and he began to take his art more seriously. Senad says he is grateful to his father for teaching him, and to his American friends for giving him the motivation to resume painting.   He is an accomplished illustrator and has illustrated two children's books for a Croatian author and one in the US.  Besides painting, Senad composes music for the piano and enjoys playing all styles, but particularly enjoys jazz, gospel, and classical music.

Senad says that music gives him the motivation and inspiration for everything he does.  


 

The story:

With your help, ELI will be able to print the story Little Jazz Man for families and other interested readers.  We also will be able to produce the characters for the Literacy Box and the miniature toys.  Profits will go toward writing and illustrating the second planned story, “Little Jazz Man Runs Away to the Circus.”

  

Little Jazz Man asked, “Can you teach me to play the saxophone?” 


Grady Grasshopper tried, but Little Jazz Man could not play the saxophone.   His lips were too small.  Little Jazz Man “sighed!” and continued to look.

story:
Lompoc Fusion

We are the Lompoc Fusion

  • We are a diverse group of folks, raising funds to help our daughters get to the Oregon Nationals
  • We need your support to have our girls experience the importance of teamwork, dedication and pursuing your dreams at the National Level
  • You can help these young ladies achieve their personal, as well as their academic goals

We are asking for your support, no matter how small the amount, you can help our girls believe in reaching for the stars!

We Need to Hit $20K

This is what your money will help us accomplish:

  • Every single dollar will go to secure the players activities and one (1) parent for one week
  • This includes; lodging, food, equipment repair, tournament costs
  • Even if we don't meet our goal of $20k, the money will be used in conjunction with other fundraising efforts, i.e. BBQ's, bake sales, sponsorship request from local businesses

The Mission

For some of our daughters, this event is directly correlated to their academic ambition; getting to the Nationals will represent the springboard that catapults them to a successful higher learning field

  • Giving young women support to pursue their dreams and validating their feelings of self-worth and accomplishment
  • We have all been there: We Needed Help, and Someone Stepped In
  • For some young ladies, the opportunity to experience this level of exposure is very narrow. We want to give them that additional boost to see it for themselves. Your support may be the difference in ONE young lady's life to pursue their academic or personal dream.

We May or May Not Hit The Mark

That's O.K! Any amount of support will help us achieve our goal. Remember: We Are Joining Forces to Get These Ladies Soaring!!!

  • Some Parents Are Military Service Members, Accustomed to High Pressure Problem Solving
  • Again, Not Meeting Our Mark is NOT A DETERRENT!!!

Can't Donate? That's O.K, Too!!!

We understand, times are hard! Other ways you can help us:

  • Please! Please! Please! SPREAD THE WORD!!!
  • You Can Share Our Campaign On IndieGoGo!!!

story:
As promised, a beautiful poem from our head coach...

You saw us play at summer games,
now we’ve had a change of face.
We’ll ensure you know our names,
so you’d better watch this space!


With every perk over £5 you shall also receive a TeamUK wristband!! 

We all wish we were Luke Twist or Ben Morton don’t we? Well, now’s the chance. We are now taking orders from the quidditch community so you can have your very own replica TeamUK shirt with your favourite member of the 42’s name and number. Pick an option containing a teamUK shirt from our list of perks and we'll get an order sorted with you as soon as possible. 


Over 100 players tried out. 42 players were shortlisted. Only 21 will get the opportunity to represent their country.

Global Games is a chance for National teams to compete against one another. These teams are made up of a selection of the strongest players from each country. Global Games 2014 will take place on July 19, 2014, at Burnaby Lake Sports Complex West in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada. Taking part in a tournament of this magnitude is not only a huge honour but also the chance to show the world just how much Quidditch has grown as a sport in the UK.

All players taking part will have trained with each other over a series of training weekends to ensure that they work as a unit and incorporate all things we UK players love best: teamwork, friendship, dancing, singing and hugs. Each player is hugely competitive, athletic and highly skilled. These are a selection of the best players the UK has to offer.

What is Quidditch?

Quidditch is a co-ed full contact sport with a unique mix of elements from rugby, dodgeball, and hide and seek. A quidditch team is made up of seven athletes who play with brooms between their legs at all times. A tournament squad can be up to 21 players as players require substitutes throughout a game.

There are seven players on pitch at any one time: three chasers, one keeper, two beaters and a seeker. Chasers play with the quaffle (a volleyball) and score goals worth 10 points each by throwing the ball through any one of three hoops at the other end of the pitch. The keeper’s job is to defend the goal hoops. Beaters use bludgers (dodgeballs) to “knock out” opposing players; any player hit by a bludger is out of play until they touch their own hoops. The seeker tries to catch the snitch. The snitch is a ball attached to the waistband of the snitch runner, a neutral athlete in a yellow uniform who uses any means to avoid capture. The snitch is worth 30 points and its capture ends the game. 

What You Get

Transporting 21 players overseas is not the easiest or the cheapest of feats. With each player looking at expenses of around £1000 or more, fundraising is key to helping reduce costs for our players. Flights to Canada are not cheap, and accommodation will be required once the team land.

We in the UK Quidditch community pride ourselves on our generosity and community spirit. We all like to help each other out so now is your chance. How would you like to help Team UK get to Canada? We have included a large range of perks. Adopt a player, buy a drawing from our wonderful artistic players, receive photos and handwritten messages and much more.

 

This is our chance to show the world what we can do. We have a lot to prove and the guts and tenacity to go all the way and win. Every £1 will get us closer to victory. Watch out world. The British are coming.

                                   

Other ways to support us

Follow our Facebook page for updates on how our fundraising is going and for more information on training and events that are taking place.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/QUKWearethe42


................. _ 
..........._...(....)...... _ 
.........(...)....|......(...)
...........|......|........ |

Amongst Mr Morton's many other duties and time constraints, he has managed to find the time to fit a little interview with myself. Without further ado:

Me: What led to your decision to be the head coach for Team UK? 

Ben: As the previous captain of team UK (2012 summer games) my passion for the new team UK has always been high. As an injury prone player I figured that trying for the team would be futile. Having maybe the best understanding of European (especially UK) teams I decided it was for the best that I take on the Head Coach role. 

Me: What experience do you have that best qualifies you for the position?

Ben: In my 3 years I have seen the development of European quidditch, and being at the summer games 2012 I picked up a few things from US, Canada and Australia too. There aren't too many teams I haven’t seen play (outside of America). Therefore I think I (and hence team UK) have a good idea of how to handle the majority of teams.

Me: What led to your decision on the format for the first selection trials? 

Ben: Global games are going to put a lot of players out of their comfort zones. So we wanted to judge how well people could play in strained circumstance. QuidditchUK already knew who the best ‘individuals’ were- but that isn’t what wins the big games! We needed to know who could develop into a team quickly whilst also being a fantastic stand out player. 

Me: What was the hardest part of that process in choosing the 42? 

Ben: There are too many good players in the UK to narrow them down to only 42! Let alone a further narrowing to 21…. A lot of amazing players have missed out. I hope just missing out inspires them to only push harder to become better and make the squad on the next review.

Me:(I'm sure I am not alone here when I say that this will be a strong motivator which will ultimately lead to a vastly improved quidditch game in the UK overall)

Me: What are your hopes and expectations for Global Games?

Ben: Under my management and Ashley Coopers captaincy and coaching I already know that by the time GG comes along, team UK will be a dream team. We will do everything in our power to win. However as I cannot stress enough, we are also there to have the time of our lives.

Me: (Amen (or Awomen) Its going to be an amazing experience for all involved and I am sure everyone will make friends for life) 

Me: What has been the most challenging experience so far? 

Ben: Getting players to gel enough with the rest of team UK so that they play to the same standard they are able to play with their home team. What do you think is going to be the biggest challenge to overcome? 2 simple words- Fund raising

Me: And on that note show your support and help the team to get there and show the world what the UK can offer! 

Share like and donate on the right hand side... whatever you can, no matter how small, every little helps. 

Another interview with Team UK captain Mr Ash Cooper on Monday
