The snitch is worth 30 points and its capture ends the game. What You GetTransporting 21 players overseas is not the easiest or the cheapest of feats. With each player looking at expenses of around £1000 or more, fundraising is key to helping reduce costs for our players. Flights to Canada are not cheap, and accommodation will be required once the team land.We in the UK Quidditch community pride ourselves on our generosity and community spirit. We all like to help each other out so now is your chance. How would you like to help Team UK get to Canada? We have included a large range of perks. Adopt a player, buy a drawing from our wonderful artistic players, receive photos and handwritten messages and much more. This is our chance to show the world what we can do. We have a lot to prove and the guts and tenacity to go all the way and win. Every £1 will get us closer to victory. Watch out world. The British are coming.                                   Other ways to support usFollow our Facebook page for updates on how our fundraising is going and for more information on training and events that are taking place.Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/QUKWearethe42................. _ ..........._...(....)...... _ .........(...)....|......(...)...........|......|........ |Amongst Mr Morton's many other duties and time constraints, he has managed to find the time to fit a little interview with myself. Without further ado:Me: What led to your decision to be the head coach for Team UK? Ben: As the previous captain of team UK (2012 summer games) my passion for the new team UK has always been high. As an injury prone player I figured that trying for the team would be futile. Having maybe the best understanding of European (especially UK) teams I decided it was for the best that I take on the Head Coach role. Me: What experience do you have that best qualifies you for the position?Ben: In my 3 years I have seen the development of European quidditch, and being at the summer games 2012 I picked up a few things from US, Canada and Australia too. There aren't too many teams I haven’t seen play (outside of America). Therefore I think I (and hence team UK) have a good idea of how to handle the majority of teams.Me: What led to your decision on the format for the first selection trials? Ben: Global games are going to put a lot of players out of their comfort zones. So we wanted to judge how well people could play in strained circumstance. QuidditchUK already knew who the best ‘individuals’ were- but that isn’t what wins the big games! We needed to know who could develop into a team quickly whilst also being a fantastic stand out player. Me: What was the hardest part of that process in choosing the 42? Ben: There are too many good players in the UK to narrow them down to only 42! Let alone a further narrowing to 21….
A lot of amazing players have missed out. I hope just missing out inspires them to only push harder to become better and make the squad on the next review.Me:(I'm sure I am not alone here when I say that this will be a strong motivator which will ultimately lead to a vastly improved quidditch game in the UK overall)Me: What are your hopes and expectations for Global Games?Ben: Under my management and Ashley Coopers captaincy and coaching I already know that by the time GG comes along, team UK will be a dream team. We will do everything in our power to win. However as I cannot stress enough, we are also there to have the time of our lives.Me: (Amen (or Awomen) Its going to be an amazing experience for all involved and I am sure everyone will make friends for life) Me: What has been the most challenging experience so far? Ben: Getting players to gel enough with the rest of team UK so that they play to the same standard they are able to play with their home team.

What do you think is going to be the biggest challenge to overcome? 
2 simple words- Fund raising
Me: And on that note show your support and help the team to get there and show the world what the UK can offer! Share like and donate on the right hand side... whatever you can, no matter how small, every little helps. Another interview with Team UK captain Mr Ash Cooper on Monday

story:
Community Building

EarthWorks and FoodScape have teamed to to build an Earth Oven at the Chestnut Garden. And we are almost finished with the project. We already have community events planned and pizza parties scheduled.

This oven is made of pure clay. What we have is a 27 inch oven, as measured on the inside. This size is ideal for community events. It fits 4 pizzas at a time, but the great thing is that this oven stays hot for 8 hours, so many dishes and meals can be prepared.

Organic Building

Our earth oven is an example of the way most things were built in the past. It serves as a teaching example for building and living in harmony with Nature.  In the past most structures were built out of clay and there was no need to refine or import material. Clay is ideal; it has infinite uses. But we have replaced clay with cement and materials even more toxic, and these materials don't even work as well. 

So our goal is not only to have community pizza parties, but to teach the community the benefits of building in harmony with our planet, Mother Earth.

What is Needed

What we are asking for with this Indigogo Campaign is for the funds for completing our oven. In addition we are asking for funds to begin more joint projects like this one to spread the word of natural building. About 100 hours have already been spent through community workshops and workdays but we still need materials to give a final clay coating and then apply various finishes. We also need to finish the 20 foot cob bench in front of the oven.

Normally such an oven would cost about $3000-4000, but because this began as a workshop and turned into a volunteer project, the total cost will come to about $1000. This is for the clay, sand, straw, bricks, and perlite we have already bought, and for the gas to get it all.

Investing in our Shared Dream

Finally we want to continue doing these projects together, and there are many operating costs associated with keeping it all going. So we will need another $500 to cover overhead and be able to plan future oven and bench building projects.


What we are really asking is that we surpass the minimum goal of $1500. Please donate generously so that we may make this oven look beautiful and so that we can begin another teaching project, either an oven, or a bench or a small shelter. All donations are warmly accepted no matter how small.

Abundance

Finally, for those who can’t give financially, your helping hands, your food and snack contributions, your vehicles are so greatly appreciated. This is not about asking people with limited finances to stretch themselves even more. No. That’s stressful. We don’t want that. But if you happen to be working out there in the world and you have a good job that pays well, then feel free to donate more. If you happen to have savings or investments that give in abundance then please donate liberally. These workshops and community projects are very important invests too.  We want to have strong positive and lasting impact on the way we all think about building our future.

story:
Hello everyone, my girlfriend Laura moved to the United States from Colombia 4 years ago, and sacrificed many things in order to have an opportunity in this country. She is a very intelligent, diligent, and goal oriented person, and is a very hard worker, currently working full time as a nanny. Between all of the bills and rent, there is no money left for her to continue to go to college. Her dream is to finish the rest of her credits and become an anthropologist. However, the cost for the remaining classes she needs to take is over $9,000, ergo, we are asking for anyone out there to help. Literally every dollar counts and is greatly appreciated.

As a reward for your generous donation, I am willing to offer something in return for those of you who donate certain amounts. As many of you know, I am a published poet / spoken word artist / musician who writes / performs under the pen name Dakota Darkhorse. I have had 2 books published and 2 CDs recorded, and for the past 10 years, have traveled the entire country, doing readings and shows in many states and opening for several famous bands and fellow poets. I have sold hundreds of copies of my works, and have thousands of followers and fans on all of the major social networking sites. Below are the different perks you will receive for different amounts of money you are willing to donate. Check out www.facebook.com/dakotadarkhorse to check out my work and learn more about my poetry, music, and spoken word.

So once again, back to my girlfriend, who is trying to go back to college. Here is the story in her own words:

"Hi my name is Laura and I need help to make my dream come true. When I was 11 years old I came across with a National Geographic magazine featuring an article about human evolution, what led me to read and learn about anthropology. Ever since that moment my interest has been growing and I have been working hard to pursue a career as an anthropologist to work with and help communities. Four years ago I was finishing the third year of my bachelor degree in anthropology in my home country, Colombia when the opportunity to come to the US for one year to learn English came across and I saw it as a great way to learn about another culture, another language, and expand my opportunities to continue my education going to grad school in another country. After five months being here in the US a petition made by my dad in 2001 to make him and his family permanent residents came current and I had to take the unexpected and hard decision between giving up the opportunity to become a resident and live in the US with my family in order to go back to my country and finish my studies, or put my school aside for some time and wait to get the permanent residence in the US. I decided to follow the second option, and stayed in this country trying to start a new life in order to get a better future. The wait for the residence has stretched for more than three years now and all this time I have felt extremely frustrated for not being able to finish school. I have been working full time as a nanny since I came to the US, and have taken some classes at a community college, but with all the expenses of paying rent and being responsible for my younger brother I have not been able to finish more than one course per year, as I have to pay international student fees. I need to finish my degree and keep working on my career, but in order to do that I have to take 52 more units at the community college to finish the general education courses and being able to transfer the classes I took in my country to finally get my B.A in anthropology. I really want to work with communities and for humanitarian organizations after I finish my studies, all I need is a hand to make this big dream come true. Thank you!" 

thanks again everyone, and every dollar is greatly appreciated!

story:
Hello!

I am a vegan bicycle mechanic, Woman of Color, and passionate explorer of multi-ethnic identity: my name is Rosa, and I’m learning to code. In a month of study, I've had a blast building Tic-Tac-Toe in Ruby and a Twitter bot that translates the Bible into, like, Californianized American youth-speak. In the future, I want to create websites that celebrate solidarity between People of Color and promote sustainable ways of life.

Your contribution is makes a huge difference as I raise funds to attend an immersive code school program that trains students in 12 weeks to work as web developers. 95% of graduates find employment as programmers within 3 months after graduation.

With inspiration from my passion for repairing bicycles, I’m aiming to build really cool things and solve complex puzzles with computer programming. When developers I know talk about writing code, I know that’s what I want to be doing - creative problem-solving that builds technological bridges between people.

Because I’m serious about learning, I want to focus all of my energy into getting good at this.That’s why I’m reaching out.

Including living expenses and the $11,500 tuition, I need a total of $12,060 to follow
my dream of code. To express my deepest gratitude for your help, I’ve made you these perks (with all my love):

$5:  A warm and sincere “Thank You” from the bottom of my heart!
$25: E-book “10 Things I Learned from Getting into Code School,” written by yours truly.
$50: E-book plus a bracelet made from recycled bicycle parts.
$100: The book plus a bracelet and earrings made from recycled bicycle parts.
$500: A Twitter bot that tweets messages of your own design.
$1000: A personal website made by yours truly, before code school begins.
$2000: A personal website made by yours truly, after code school ends.

If you’ve got a moment to give me a shout-out and make a donation (the perks are pretty sweet, just sayin), I truly appreciate the support!

Many thanks,
Rosa

story:
Hey everyone! If you don't know me my name is Ellis Hampton. I am from San Jose, California and I am 23 years of age. This campaign that I am starting is to raise money for my College Tuition. I am a current student at Morehouse College and I am studying Cinema Television and Film. To attend Morehouse College it is approximately $38,000 a year to stay on campus. But, to stay off campus it is near $25,000 a year, which I do stay off campus. All I am asking of those that are willing, to generously give what is in your heart to give. I do not ask for a specific amount, all I am trying to do is reach my goal of $3,020 to help pay for my next semester in becoming a full time student. Any funds that are raised will be going straight to the school to the Financial Aid department to put on my student account. This will fill the rest of the money I will have owed for the semester. 


Lately I have been having a lot of trouble finding financial help to fund my time here at Morehouse and at times I have found myself close to giving up. It has been a long 3 years here and I have recently found out that I may have to be here another 2 years at most to cover the required credit hours of 120 credits. Things seem to continue to build up and new challenges are faced everyday. This semester alone has been a great challenge for me, I have been working 2 jobs and going to school part time just to have a place to stay and to help raise money to pay for school. Everyday I wake up at 4am to be at work and I get off 8 hours later just to go to class, then get out to work at my second job. It has been an continuous struggle and I am trying to press on, but it's getting hard trying to do things by myself. My family tried their hardest to provide for me financially, but they all have their problems of their own. 

I am striving to become a Film Maker which includes; Director, writer, cinematographer and actor. I am very ambitious in my journey of becoming a great film maker and sharpening my skills of becoming a great artist. I used to always ask myself, "what is it you want to do? What are you called to do and what are you passionate about? I realized after my 1st year attending a Junior College at De Anza in Cupertino, CA that I wanted to be a film maker. 

It had never dawned on me that I wanted to be a film maker, but later on I grew on great fondness for film and the arts in general. I however, always loved art and movies, but it wasn't so much the painting and drawing that really intrigued me it was the Film Medium that grabbed my heart. 

I have been doing film for about 5 years now. I have even had the opportunity to start my own film business that acts like my second job. Through my business I work with others that work in film and we create all sorts of film products. 

My dream of becoming a film maker is wrapped in the arms of my education. I am aware that if I am not able to continue my academic career that it is unlikely that I will have a film career in the future. 

It would be the greatest blessing if I were to meet my goal. Most importantly it would be a greater blessing to meet my goal and to become a full time student next semester. I thank you in advance for any help that you can give and I hope you are blessed and live a healthy, compassionate and free life. 

Thank you! 

Ellis Deon Culberson-Hampton

story:
Hi! My name is Aaron Vodovoz, I am 25 years old from Tel-Aviv, Israel, and I am currently completing my third and last year at the prestigious London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts (LAMDA). 

In 2011, Out of 4000 applicants from around the world, I was honored to be picked as one of the lucky 30 who were accepted to study on the three year BA (Hons) in Professional Acting LAMDA.

LAMDA is a world-class drama school, offering exceptional vocational training in the performing arts. Founded in 1861, LAMDA is a leader in its field; alumni include Chiwetel Ejiofor, Benedict Cumberbatch, John Lithgow, Donald Sutherland, Jim Broadbent, Brian Cox, David Suchet, Nigel Planer, Chris O’Dowd and many more. 

Throughout the 3 years I have been paying for my tuition and living costs with the assistance of my parents, who put aside money for my education since I was a child. In addition, I have been working consistently since beginning my education.

I have worked as a waiter and bartender at the Hilton London Kensington Hotel, a steward at LAMDA auditions and examinations. I work as much as I can while allowing time for my education and rehearsals. This is how I have been able to earn additional money to survive and pay the tuition. In addition to working in and outside of LAMDA, I have sent letters and applications for scholarships to countless of organizations. I have received a 1000 pound loan, and at the beginning of previous term a generous bursary from LAMDA.

So far in my last year at LAMDA we have put up 4 shows including "A Few Good Men" by Aaron Sorkin where I played Sam Weinberg, and this upcoming play "The School of Night" where I play Thomas Walsingham. Aside from that I've filmed a part for a BBC 4 series. This last year has been the most beneficial and enjoyable year for me because I have finally been able to tackle exciting and challenging parts with all the knowledge from the previous 2 years, and it has taught me how to do my job to the best of my abilities when I finish my education this coming July. 

Unfortunately with all of that, living costs are so high in London, I am still currently in a position that I need to raise 5500 pounds in order to be able to remain at LAMDA and finish my 3rd and last year at LAMDA. I feel like I have grown so much throughout these 3 years of education it would be such a devastating blow to not be able to finish my education at LAMDA. I am excited about my future and hope that I can get the assistance I need to complete this phase of my life. 

Thank you for considering my request!


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about it!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! Share on twitter and facebook and I'll be in your debt forever!

Unfortunately with all of that, living costs are so high in London, I am still
currently in a position that I need to raise 5500 pounds in order to be able to
remain at LAMDA and finish my 3rd and last year at LAMDA. I feel like I have
grown so much throughout these 3 years of education it would be such a
devastating blow to not be able to finish my education at LAMDA. I am excited
about my future and hope that I can get the assistance I need to complete this
phase of my life. 
Thank you for considering my request!Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
Get the word out and make some noise about it!
Use the Indiegogo share tools! Share on twitter and facebook and I'll be in your debt forever!

story:
Short Summary

This spring, 10 talented students from Tulane University will travel to Washington DC to participate in the Model Organization of American States (OAS). The Model OAS is a 5-day simulation of the General Assembly meeting of the Organization of American States. At the simulation students master the art of diplomacy, as they present policies that they prepared during a semester-long course. Students from all over the Western Hemisphere travel to DC to participate in this prestigious opportunity. This is a great opportunity for Tulane students to meet, connect with, and learn from Latin American students. This year, Tulane will attend the Model OAS as the Delegation of Brazil. In order to attend the Model OAS, we aim to raise $4,500, of which $2,000 will come from this campaign.

What We Need

In order to allow as many students from Tulane's campus to participate in the course and simulation, we cover as much of the travel costs as possible. This year, due to an unexpected increase in hotel prices, as well as increased airfare, we are forced to raise an additional $4,500 to cover our expenses for our 10 students. We aim to raise $2,000 through this campaign. All schools who participate in the Model are required to stay in the same hotel, which is where the simulation also takes place. We feel strongly that every dollar counts and will add up towards us reaching our goal! Also, all donations are tax deductible.  

The Impact

Model OAS is an important class for Tulane undergrads because its interdisciplinary nature allows students from any major/minor to participate and to put into action what they have learned in their classes. Students practice writing and researching policy as well as learn about the art of diplomacy. Contributing even the smallest amount towards this class will help these talented Tulane students to put what they have learned in the classroom into practice. This is an experience that students are not likely to forget! The quotes below show the students' excitement to participate in this course! 

"Model OAS is a unique opportunity to not only learn about issues pertinent to the Western Hemisphere, such as human rights, sustainable development, and public health, but also apply that knowledge to a practical setting. I am looking forward to meeting other students from all over the Americas and working with them to solve some of the most challenging problems." Jennifer Rosenthal

"As the Portuguese Department's Research Assistant on Transitional Justice in Brazil, it's been my job to research and report on how the nation has been recently confronting its military past. This opportunity to pass policy in the Model OAS—as Brazil—to further its Transitional Justice process, is the most exciting application of my research that I could have dreamed of." Pat Duffy 

"I see MOAS as an opportunity to engage with nine other highly motivated Tulane students in working to understand an international democratic organization and the history of Latin American diplomatic relations from the perspective of Brazil. The opportunity to learn from and work with students and peers from all over the hemisphere at the conference in DC is surely a learning experience I will take with me forever, particularly as a student who will be studying abroad in Brazil within the next year." Tano Trachtenberg 

"Participating in Model OAS will give me the opportunity to learn an abundance about modern Brazil and international diplomacy than I would be able to learn in the classroom alone. Our team is in a neat position representing Brazil this spring, as the country is growing more powerful and prominent every year. The experience gained first hand from the Model will give me a very solid basis of knowledge on the region, which I will put to use when I study in Brazil next fall." Amy Rodenberger   

"Model OAS is important to me because it gives me the opportunity to practice real-world diplomacy, instead of just reading about it in a book. Through this program, I can travel to DC, make friends from all over the world, and learn about inter-American relations." Sophie-Ann Kivett

"Model OAS is an incredible opportunity to learn diplomacy and increase cultural and political awareness, but also represents a globally important method for development and growth in Brazil. As a Portuguese student, I am so excited for the chance for a hands on encounter with a country that I have studied and loved!" Riley Russel 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you don't have a few dollars to contribute, not to worry! It is equally important to us that as many people as possible learn about the great opportunities that Tulane students are partaking in. You can still help by forwarding this to others. We hope to continue to offer this engaging course through the Stone Center for Latin American Studies at Tulane University for many years to come!

story:
What is Meamorphism? 

Meamorphism is a groundbreaking art movement that combines digital and static art to bring art making and curriculum into the 21st century. 

Throughout the centuries, artists have always strived to capture light and movement in their works. But they have always been limited by the static nature of the art of their day. Movement has always eluded even the most gifted of painters and sculptors. Leonardo was so obsessed with movement that he invented a flying machine. Van Gogh’s “Starry Night” is as close as it gets to translating light into painting. Close…but not quite the real thing!

Meamorphism makes Leonardo’s and Van Gogh’s dreams come true. Video, sound and traditional art making come together to emulate life. Suddenly, water flows beneath the Golden Gate Bridge under a sparkling sky. A painting of Beethoven comes to life in multiple explosions of light and motion, to the tune of the 5th symphony.

Why Meamorphism?

Students who attend art classes are 10% more likely to go to a 4-year school after high school, and Meamorphism brings art into the digital age making schools, parents, and students more excited and willing to expand their curriculum. 

In today’s world, business, engineering, math and science are the main focus of young people’s education, at the expense of “less productive” disciplines such as art and the humanities in general.

In recent years, drastic budget cuts have also led to the reduction of art classes throughout the school system.

Finally, the internet and digital technology have taken the visual world to a whole new dimension. Today’s young people march to a much faster pace than their predecessors; they look for excitement in video games and other visual forms of entertainment that match that speed. Traditional art, motionless, is boring and unexciting to them. Even without budget cuts and the current emphasis on business oriented curriculums, art classes would be mostly empty.

That’s where Meamorphism comes in!

Meamorphism is vibrant, colorful and alive. In art classes, kids will be able to create a multidimensional work of art using the same digital technology they use in their everyday lives.

Help us make this dream a reality! Meamorphism can make it possible for kids to be excited about art classes all over again, and you can make it happen by contributing to our campaign!

We need $16,000 to begin our program by implementing it in a couple of schools. The money we are able to raise will alow us to purchase digital canvases, tablets for kids, and hire a program manager.

THANK YOU!!!

The Meamorphism Team
Meamar, Tina, Guy, Pascale, Kathryn, Elen, and Ali

story:
A MESSAGE FROM OUR FOUNDER

Dear friends and supporters,

In 2006, I founded BLACK GIRLS ROCK! to combat images that I felt insulted the integrity of Black women and girls. In addition to our award show, I started a local youth enrichment program, which has blossomed into an international leadership camp. As a mentor and youth advocate, I’ve seen the tremendous benefit of mentoring our girls through holistic art education, critical cultural literacy, leadership development, civic engagement and entrepreneurship workshops that empower them to know and love themselves, to imagine their futures and to be active agents in creating a world where the next generation of girls can be shot callers in diverse professions.

I am excited to announce that we will host our annual BLACK GIRLS ROCK! QUEENS’ CAMP FOR LEADERSHIP & EXCELLENCE for the fourth consecutive year! The camp is a two-week intensive designed to fortify dynamic girls from around the world who are in good academic standing, who exhibit strong leadership capabilities, and who have a vested interest in their personal and professional development. The summer camp will be held at BARNARD COLLEGE and COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY from July 18-August 2, 2014.

BLACK GIRLS ROCK! hosted the first global summer leadership intensive in 2011 because I knew it was essential to nourish and mentor the next generation of young women who desire to be world leaders. I wanted to affirm our girls by surrounding them with like-minded peers aspiring to be trailblazers, to help girls see the depth of their intrinsic power, and to demonstrate that a girl’s value is amplified (not weakened) by international sisterly bonds. 

The BLACK GIRLS ROCK! QUEENS' CAMP FOR LEADERSHIP & EXCELLENCE cultivates and supports this budding generation of female global thought leaders through programs that reinforce the talent, integrity, and knowledge needed to lead successfully. Our diverse participants come from various socioeconomic backgrounds and geographic areas, yet share a foundation of cultural pride, a deep determination to excel, and a will to use their brilliance to impact the world! Our innovative camp curriculum is designed to help participants overcome fears that may hinder them from owning their power and enables participants to refine their skills in writing, public speaking, project management, and creativity.

Our program participants leave our intensive camp as empowered leaders and altruistic individuals! Camp alumnae have expressed feeling a deeper commitment to academic excellence, creative integrity, ingenuity, professional goal setting, humanitarianism, and the principle of collective responsibility.



BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Developmental Philosophy:

•  We believe a summer camp intensive should provide workshops and activities that foster team work, community service, personal growth and active leadership

•  We believe that our unique all-girls environment helps to raise self-esteem, fosters open/honest discussion and encourages lasting bonds of friendship and sisterhood.

•  We believe that girls make educated decisions and become independent thinkers when encouraged to develop critical problem-solving/thinking skills

• We believe in fostering a girl's intentional pursuit of excellence, integrity, self-discipline, and collective accountability so that she may be prepared for her future as a leader.


"After attending BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Queens' Camp I’ve been inspired to not only better myself but my community and peers by setting a good example. Good enough no longer satisfies me. As a Black girl who rocks, I’ve now dedicated my life to exceeding the expectations of others. I am smarter, stronger, and I rock harder. This camp experience has changed my life and my perspective. The world seems so much bigger!"  -Travia Gallon (2013 camp participant)


You can help us continue to mentor dynamic girls, like Travia, and make a meaningful difference in a girl's life by supporting our campaign today! There are several levels to giving and we appreciate your gift, for no amount is too small to make a tremendous difference.




WHAT WILL YOUR FUNDS BE USED FOR?

Your funds will help BLACK GIRLS ROCK! provide dynamic master classes that promote the active leadership, intellectual, social, emotional and positive identity development of teenage girls from around the globe. Our leadership intensive emphasizes the importance of teamwork, community building, entrepreneurship, problem solving, critical cultural literacy and healthy decision making skills.

Our goal is to raise enough money for 25 girls to attend the BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Queens' Camp for Leadership and Excellence. Please help us reach our campaign goal, by making a contribution!


HOW CAN YOU HELP?

  • ROCK! THE CAMPAIGN: Please donate to our crowdfunding campaign today! Help a participant attend camp free-of-cost.

  • AFTER YOU DONATE, SPREAD THE WORD!: Help us share information about the BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Queens' Camp for Leadership & Excellence! Please pass information about this campaign to your friends via Facebook, Twitter, email, G+, in-person, over the phone, and any other methods of communication to help ensure that we reach our fundraising goal!

  • BECOME A TITLE/PARTICIPATING SPONSOR: If interested in becoming a title sponsor or making a donation greater than 10K please contact BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Inc. directly by emailing Glenda Smiley at queenscamp@blackgirlsrock.org.


BLACK GIRLS ROCK! is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization and all donations are 100% tax deductible. Your contribution is an investment in the enrichment, empowerment, and education of our girls. Together, I believe we can continue to inspire girls to be leaders, trailblazers, and dynamos. Please help us reach our capital campaign goal by making your donation today! We cannot succeed with out you. Thanks for your support. YOU ROCK!


In service and sisterhood,

Beverly Bond

Founder/Executive Director

BLACK GIRLS ROCK! Inc.

story:
Hello! 

My name is Susana Blanco, but you all can call me Sus. I am 18 and I recently became a high school graduate a few weeks ago, and the reason why I created this campaign is because I need all the help I can get.

I got accepted into a really good and really amazing art school, Laguna College of Art and Design in Laguna Beach California, to get my bachelor's degree in fine arts and I receive financial aid and also plan on paying the rest of my tuition/supplies/housing fees with scholarships, work studies and a job (possibly two). Ever since my seventh grade year of junior high, I decided to pursue in the art field to become an illustrator.

But the thing that has been nipping me in the bud is my family. They do not approve and support with what I want to do with my future. My mum expects me to stay with her and take online courses and my father expects me to apply next year for a "better" course. Ever since I was little, they have tried to convince me to be either a lawyer or a doctor, but that never interested me. The reason why I made this campaign is because I need to pay the tuition and housing deposit, which is $1050.00 in total. My parents refuse to help me with it and do not allow me to get a job to pay for it. 

I will be able to go to art school and achieve my dream of becoming a professional illustrator for children's books, comic books and many other things.


All I'm asking for is $940.00 for the Housing and Tuition deposit before July 15th of 2014 for Laguna College of Art and Design. If I don't reach it by the deadline, then I would have to forfeit my scholarship and cancel my acceptance to the school... 

If I don't reach my goal fully, I would save what I have received for next year (which I hope it doesn't come to that.).

I plan on entertaining people of all ages, from all over the world- to make them happy, sad, angry etc. with my art in the future.


The art field is a tough and merciless career to aim for these days, but I am willing to try and  try harder to aim for my future and achieve it. I know I can do it; I am confident in my art. This isn't going to be a cake walk, i know it isn't. But I am willing to take my chances and achieve.


For anyone that wants to help me but can't, there isn't just one way! You can help me out by spreading the word out to other people! Do you have a blog? Mention it. Do you have friends and  family? (Of course you do) Tell them! If you see your mail man, tell him too!

Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools! 

Thank you!

story:
UPDATE: With all the momentum you've helped us build, we're aiming to double our goal to $10,000, which would cover all of the plane tickets for our 16 Silicon North Stars to come to California. To make it happen, we'll do a DOLLAR-FOR-DOLLAR match for every donation made, doubling the impact of your donation! So please consider donating and spread the word -- we need your support!

Silicon North Stars

Hey everyone,

We're Steve and Mary Grove, and we're passionate about giving Minnesota youth the opportunity to imagine exciting careers in technology through experiential learning in Silicon Valley. That's why we started Silicon North Stars, a one-week tech camp that brings a select group of high-potential eighth and ninth graders from Minnesota to California's Silicon Valley from July 13-19th to learn about technology and the Internet directly from some of the top tech companies and startups in the world. 

And we'd love your help to make it happen!

The 16 students from Minneapolis and St. Paul, MN, come from a diverse set of backgrounds, and share a passion for technology and the web and a desire to one day pursue a career in those fields. During the week, they'll meet with Internet and technology leaders from top companies, startups, and venture capital funds. The week will begin with an intensive series of lectures, tours, discussions, and group activities at companies throughout the area, and will end with a culminating group project in which the students will pair up to pitch their own tech startups. Fun evening activities will give the students a chance to learn more about the Bay Area and bond with one another.

Here's a picture of the kids who are coming:

We started Silicon North Stars because we believe that exposure to possibility at a young age can fundamentally change the course of a person's life — giving them a new vision for their future and something to work for. Your donations will change the lives of these students - thank you for your help!

Yours,

Steve and Mary

http://siliconnorthstars.org


What We Need 

We are funding Silicon North Stars 100% - which means the students won't spend a dime to make the trip to California. We're on Indiegogo because we're looking to offset a portion of the student's travel costs to Silicon Valley. $5,000 will help us with the travel costs of flying the students to California and back.


The Impact

We're specifically working with eighth and ninth-graders because this is a critical age when students' decisions about high school have long-lasting effects on their college and career prospects.

The week's activities will include but not be limited to:

  • Campus visits and talks at Google, Facebook, Apple, Stanford University, TaskRabbit, Indiegogo, the Target Innovation Center, and more.
  • A day spent with early-stage startup companies at Galvanize SF, a local tech incubator and co-working space for entrepreneurs.
  • Career coaching and mentorship from a series of technology professionals at participating companies.
  • A series of "fireside chats" with accomplished technology executives.
  • Team-building activities and group projects.
  • A design-thinking workshop — teaching brainstorming and creative thinking at Google
  • A culminating project, where students will use everything they've learned to create their own startup companies, and then pitch those companies to a panel of judges at the end of the week.
  • Fun activities to explore the Bay Area!


Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love your help in spreading the world about Silicon North Stars - please share our Indiegogo campaign, or our website, with your friends and family!
story_txt:
UPDATE: With all the momentum you've helped us build, we're aiming to double our goal to $10,000, which would cover all of the plane tickets for our 16 Silicon North Stars to come to California. To make it happen, we'll do a DOLLAR-FOR-DOLLAR match for every donation made, doubling the impact of your donation! So please consider donating and spread the word -- we need your support!Silicon North StarsHey everyone,We're Steve and Mary Grove, and we're passionate about giving Minnesota youth the opportunity to imagine exciting careers in technology through experiential learning in Silicon Valley. That's why we started Silicon North Stars, a one-week tech camp that brings a select group of high-potential eighth and ninth graders from Minnesota to California's Silicon Valley from July 13-19th to learn about technology and the Internet directly from some of the top tech companies and startups in the world. And we'd love your help to make it happen!The 16 students from Minneapolis and St. Paul, MN, come from a diverse set of backgrounds, and share a passion for technology and the web and a desire to one day pursue a career in those fields. During the week, they'll meet with Internet and technology leaders from top companies, startups, and venture capital funds. The week will begin with an intensive series of lectures, tours, discussions, and group activities at companies throughout the area, and will end with a culminating group project in which the students will pair up to pitch their own tech startups. Fun evening activities will give the students a chance to learn more about the Bay Area and bond with one another.Here's a picture of the kids who are coming:We started Silicon North Stars because we believe that exposure to possibility at a young age can fundamentally change the course of a person's life — giving them a new vision for their future and something to work for. Your donations will change the lives of these students - thank you for your help!Yours,Steve and Maryhttp://siliconnorthstars.orgWhat We Need We are funding Silicon North Stars 100% - which means the students won't spend a dime to make the trip to California. We're on Indiegogo because we're looking to offset a portion of the student's travel costs to Silicon Valley. $5,000 will help us with the travel costs of flying the students to California and back.The ImpactWe're specifically working with eighth and ninth-graders because this is a critical age when students' decisions about high school have long-lasting effects on their college and career prospects.The week's activities will include but not be limited to:
Campus visits and talks at Google, Facebook, Apple, Stanford University, TaskRabbit, Indiegogo, the Target Innovation Center, and more.
A day spent with early-stage startup companies at Galvanize SF, a local tech incubator and co-working space for entrepreneurs.
Career coaching and mentorship from a series of technology professionals at participating companies.
A series of "fireside chats" with accomplished technology executives.
Team-building activities and group projects.
A design-thinking workshop — teaching brainstorming and creative thinking at Google
A culminating project, where students will use everything they've learned to create their own startup companies, and then pitch those companies to a panel of judges at the end of the week.
Fun activities to explore the Bay Area!
Other Ways You Can HelpWe'd love your help in spreading the world about Silicon North Stars - please share our Indiegogo campaign, or our website, with your friends and family!

story:
UPDATE: The campaign is successfully reached its goal and the chosen priority for May is: "Sound Support". Congratulations and much thanks to all contributors!

UPDATE 2: We have launched a new fundraising campaign to fund Synfig development for next month. Please check it out here.



Short Summary

Hello, my name is Konstantin Dmitriev. I am running this campaign to fund the development of Synfig - the free and opensource animation software.

I am mentoring a full-time developer Ivan Mahonin, who is working on Synfig code. We have funded his work in previous months by running similar fundraising campaigns for October, November, December, January, February, March and April.

Thanks to success of those campaigns, Ivan have implemented following features for Synfig:

- Frame-by-Frame animation (bitmap)


- Bones tools


See other demonstrations at our YouTube channel...

The success of this campaign will allow Ivan to work full-time for a whole month in May 2014.

Also, this campaign allows our users to directly influence the Synfig development by choosing development priorities. 

How?

Please read below.


"Choose Priority" perk

For a donation of fixed amount (see the perks on the right)  we offer to the donor an exceptional privilege to choose a priority of development.  So, we will spend next month working on the priority you defined. Of course, we can't promise any thing, so please select from the list below:

  • Frame-by-frame bitmap animation support (continued, see current status)
  • Rendering speed optimization
  • Sound support
  • Improve user interface

NOTE: We don't guarantee the feature from a selected priority to be completely finished within a month. Such promises are not compatible with development realities. What we promise is to dedicate no less than 85% of our working time to developing this priority for a full month. Though, one month is a  significant period and such dedication would lead to significant changes in selected direction. Many our users are aware that we used to publish development snapshots regularly, so you will be able to benefit from development results as soon as possible.

EXAMPLE: As result of our earlier fundraising campaign, we got sold the "Choose priority" perk for October. The priority chosen by donor was "Single-window UI". You can see results in this video.

"Development OS" perk

By default we use Linux operation system (OS) for daily development (because we love Linux). As result, the Linux version of Synfig is the most polished, because it goes through daily proof.

But, for a fixed-amount donation (see the perks on the right) you can make us shift to other OS for next month. So, if we will use the OS of your choice in our daily development, then obviously  the Synfig version will be especially polished to work on it: daily proof => more testing => less bugs => better stability.

No worries, this perk doesn't mean we drop support for other operation systems. It's just a question of choosing the OS for daily development.

At the moment the only OS available for choice is Windows.

Other perks

We understand that there are people who would like to support our efforts by other means. Specially for them we prepared other rewards to express our gratitude:

  • Synfig Training Package. You can get our Synfig training course at exclusively low price. Comparing to regular "pay-what-you-want" download, you get a direct assistance from the course instructors and all future updates are also included. We will ship a coupon code for you which you can use to access the training by yourself or present as a gift to someone.  The package is available in English and Russian.
  • Tutorial video. A tutorial video about Synfig for ANY given theme. Length is limited to 5 minutes.  Languages can be English or Russian. Video will be publicly available for everyone. The tutorial video will be produced by Nikolai Mamashev, who was in charge for producing Synfig Training Package.
  • Report sponsor. You can track the progress of the development by reading my weekly reports. If you claim this perk, then one of my weekly reports will be indicated as sponsored by you with an (optional) link to your website. The mention will look as "This report is sponsored by: ..." text at the top of the report text.
  • Sponsor logo. Your logo displayed for one month at the front page of Synfig website.

Who is behind this campaign

Konstantin Dmitriev. This is me. I am the person who is responsible for distributing collected funds and  mentoring the development process. I am an open-source activist with a special profile for animation. The range of my activities include expertize, development and popularization of free software animation solutions.


You can see following my works made as animator purely with free software:

  • Morevna Project: Demo
  • “Persona” Tomato Paste commercial
  • Morevna Project: Production Cuts

Also I have a profile in education by teaching animation to kids using libre and opensource tools. Here are some of the works made by my students:

  • The Adventures of Boris Munchausen
  • Amazing Sentence

The sources for many of the works above are freely available under the Creative Commons license.

Ivan Mahonin. He is a professional C/C++ developer, hired to work on Synfig code. You can track current Ivan's contributions to Synfig on this page.

Nikolai Mamashev. He is a "wizard of Synfig", awesome artist who use free software only. If you are user Synfig, then you know at least one his work - the current splash screen is created by him. He is known as lead artist in Morevna Project: Demo, also it worths to look at his portfolio. Nikolai is in charge for providing artistic support for us, proof testing and tutorials production.

The Impact

With this campaign we would like to provide a way to control the direction of development and support vitality of Synfig development at the same time.  Users can choose the priorities and all collected funds will go to support further sustainable development of Synfig. It's fair and benefit is for everyone - we all get better free animation software.

You can track the results of our work by reading my weekly reports.

Also, we are open to consider other models of funding for Synfig. If you are would like to sponsor the implementation of particular feature - please contact us (see the comments tab at the top).

Other ways you can help

For the people, who would like to give as direct and regular support there is an option to subscribe. Please check out this page for details - http://www.synfig.org/cms/en/news/taking-one-step-away-from-crowdfunding/.

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Pamela. I recently graduated with a B.A. in International Studies with the hopes of working with international nonprofits. Recently, I was invited to go to a conference in Washington D.C. and present a research project I worked on while I was in school alongside one of my professors. This campaign will help fund this amazing opportunity to meet people who are influential in the Political Science field and with whom I would love to work some day.

    The Impact

    The conference I plan to attend is the APSA Annual Meeting & Exhibition. The American Political Science Association is an international network that connects scholars from all over the world. It encourages the sharing of ideas and solutions about current issues. 

    For me, this is an incredible opportunity. I will be able to meet the experts and learn from them. I can ask questions and challenge opinions. At my age, these opportunities are practically unheard of. I want to take advantage of this and learn as much as I can from this experience. I have the chance to not only be among experts, but to be one as well. Through this experience, I can continue on my journey to reach my full-potential by chasing one of my dreams. 

      What I Need & What You Get

      I need $650. This will cover everything from airfare to transportation while I am in DC.

      Perks will include postcards and souvenirs, as well as letters with stories from my trip and pictures.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Thank you for reading my story. Please share this with your friends and keep me in your hearts and prayers for the remaining funding and my trip there.

This campaign will help fund this amazing opportunity to meet people who are influential in the Political Science field and with whom I would love to work some day.
  The Impact The conference I plan to attend is the APSA Annual Meeting & Exhibition. The American Political Science Association is an international network that connects scholars from all over the world. It encourages the sharing of ideas and solutions about current issues. 
For me, this is an incredible opportunity. I will be able to meet the experts and learn from them. I can ask questions and challenge opinions. At my age, these opportunities are practically unheard of. I want to take advantage of this and learn as much as I can from this experience. I have the chance to not only be among experts, but to be one as well. Through this experience, I can continue on my journey to reach my full-potential by chasing one of my dreams. 

  
What I Need & What You Get


I need $650. This will cover everything from airfare to transportation while I am in DC.
Perks will include postcards and souvenirs, as well as letters with stories from my trip and pictures.
Other Ways You Can Help Thank you for reading my story. Please share this with your friends and keep me in your hearts and prayers for the remaining funding and my trip there.

story:
Short Summary

Camp GLOW (Girls Leading Our World) was started by Peace Corps Volunteers in Romania in the 90s and has spread across the world. In St. Vincent and the Grenadines, the camp had it's first year last year and was very successful in building a bond between 30 young women from across the island based on HIV/AIDS education, building leadership skills, and having fun. 

What We Need & What You Get

OK, the dets: We received a grant to cover the cost of food and lodging but we want to the best for our girls so your money will help with....

  • Camp T-shirts
  • Transportation
  • Art Supplies

    What You Get:
  • Depending on how much you spend you will receive:
  • a hand-written thank you card from one of our campers or counselors
  • a GLOW t-shirt
  • a GLOW calendar 

The Impact

The Eastern Caribbean has the highest rate of HIV/AIDS in the world next to sub-saharan Africa. Educating young women about healthy sex habits and relationships is vital in reducing these numbers.

  • Rarely do these young women have opportunities to get together in a safe environment to discuss gender issues that affect their everyday lives, you will have a part in providing that.
  • Last year at the closing ceremony the girls all expressed their love for each other and Camp GLOW and their promise to take the knowledge they gained from camp into their communities

Risks & Challenges

Camp is secluded, it feels like worlds away from everyday life, all we can do is try our hardest to spread knowledge and awareness but it is up to the individual girls to go back to their communities and keep strong within themselves. They come from all over the island so as soon as camp is over, their support network isn't as easy to connect with.

  • We hope this year we can help the girls after camp start 'GLOW' clubs at their schools
  • We hope to offer enough outside support for the girls that they will have a place, or multiple places, to turn in trying times. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can donate, will help, even if it's just one dollar. But if you absolutely can't spare anything please...

  • Get the word out and make some noise about Camp GLOW!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for all your support and love for these future leaders.

story:
Taungana

On 23 August 2014, 30 high school girls from rural Southern Africa will bravely travel from their communities (and countries) to Johannesburg for a 7-day STEM Career Expo!

The Expo theme is - Decoding STEM Careers!.

Africa is a developing continent with a great need for development in the STEM fields. Access to information and exposure to STEM education and careers is extremely limited for students in rural schools in Africa.  And, statistics continue to show the underrepresentation of females in STEM fields and sub-Saharan tertiary institutions.

This premier event will see a targeted 30 girls from rural South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe come to Johannesburg to get real-life exposure to STEM careers from high fliers in South African STEM giants, access to STEM career advancement opportunities and most importantly - they will be equipped to be STEM ambassadors in their own communities. Taungana Ambassadors will be visiting world-class STEM giants in and around Johannesburg. We cannot wait to announce our industry hosts in the energy, petrochemical, food, research science, aviation, mining, health sciences, pharmaceutical and STEM entrepreneurship segments.

Three Southern African Non-Profit Organisations all led by women have come together from the three countries to organise this event. STEM-IT-Forward from South Africa, Asikana Network from Zambia and Techwomen Zimbabwe.

What We Need & How You Can Help

With the Taungana Ambassadors selected and 20 of them eagerly awaiting their first ever passport stamps, we need your help to make this a phenomenal life-changing programme for the Ambassadors.

Help us open up doors for 30 future female African leaders this August in Johannesburg! With the bulk of the programme costs covered including transport, we need funds to meet:

•Accommodation: For 8 nights (with dinner and breakfast included) for our 30 Ambassadors and 5 volunteers.

  $10, 700

By demonstrating your commitment to a worldwide initiative you will enable us to build capacity in STEM which is a part of the UNESCO strategic initiatives.

Your generous sponsorship would be featured along with our current domestic, global and government sponsors taking part in bridging the gap within STEM fields.

We thank our current sponsors who have supported us in cash and in kind: TechWomen, Black Girls Code, Global Connections for Women, Subz Washable Pads, Sci Bono Discovery Centre, South African Agency for Science and Technology Advancement (SAASTA), Lil-Lets, Nuclear Energy Corporation of South Africa (Necsa) and our awesome individual sponsors.


Our WOW Factor!

"Empowering future African Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) leaders.

One girl at a time.”

Taungana is a regionally integrated approach to tackling the socio-economic and gender hindrances to STEM involvement for rural high school girls in sub-Saharan Africa with an initial focus on Southern Africa. Through its flagship annual STEM Expo and STEM Evangelism programmes in participating country rural communities, Taungana gives girls from rural South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe the opportunity to:

  •   Explore world-class education and career paths in STEM
  •   Connect with real women champions and role models in STEM sectors
  •   Become STEM promotion Ambassadors within their communities
  •   Receive the same access to STEM opportunities as their peers in advantaged communities
  •   Become part of a mentored STEM network supporting their individual journeys in STEM
  •   Be at the forefront of bridging the gap in technology access, literacy and usage at the grassroots level


"An estimated 2.5 million new engineers and technicians are required in sub-Saharan Africa alone to achieve the Milleniun Development Goals of improved access to clean water and sanitation. To achieve such aims, we need to attract every young mind to engineering, especially in the developing world, where attracting more women to fields in which they are underrepresented must be part of the solution."-unesco.org


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us make some noise about the campaign. Tell all your friends to help make a difference to a rural African schoolgirl with a passion for STEM.  Use the hashtags #taungana ; #1000@10
  • Remember you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

“More than half of the achievement gap between lower- and higher-income youth can be explained by unequal access to summer learning opportunities.”

                                                        — National Summer Learning Association

The Academy Street Firehouse is a distinct environment for children and teens living in Newark. Our students are proud of their communities and want to improve neighborhoods, family relationships, and their own health and well-being. Youth in our program face the effects that make many underserved communities vulnerable to violence, unstable housing, drug abuse, and health-related issues. Firehouse kids know the reality. We encourage their passion to learn more, do more, and achieve.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to continue our summer program beginning in July 2013, we are asking for your assistance {and generosity}. Of course, we want to give you a special gift for your investment!  We have a plan to raise $700 before June 28th.  And that plan includes you, our kids, and some very enticing incentives.

All of your contributions (whether we meet our goal or not) will go towards the operating costs of the Academy Street Firehouse summer program.  But of course we WILL meet our goal... with your help.

 

The Impact

Initiatives like the Firehouse Summer Enrichment and Summer Teen Apprenticeship Programs address the achievement gap by offering youth a fun, targeted opportunity for learning and practicing skills.

We give young people opportunities that build resilience and life-long healthy behaviors.  And we do this through an afterschool program {with a summer initiative} designed just for our unique population.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Because we know that your social capital can bring meaningful support to a very special cause, we are asking for your help.

1.  SHARE this page with friends, colleagues, and family to let them know that you thought of them, and they may be interested in helping kids achieve.  www.igg.me/at/firehouse

2.  TWEET about us!  "Invest in Youth - Fund the Firehouse! Receive a special gift for making a contribution. www.igg.me/at/firehouse"

3.  UPDATE your Facebook status. "Join my effort to raise awareness and funding for a very special youth program in Newark.  Fund the Firehouse!  www.igg.me/at/firehouse"
story_txt:
Short Summary
“More than half of the achievement gap between lower- and higher-income youth can be explained by unequal access to summer learning opportunities.”
                                                        — National Summer Learning Association
The Academy Street Firehouse is a distinct environment for children and teens living in Newark. Our students are proud of their communities and want to improve neighborhoods, family relationships, and their own health and well-being. Youth in our program face the effects that make many underserved communities vulnerable to violence, unstable housing, drug abuse, and health-related issues. Firehouse kids know the reality. We encourage their passion to learn more, do more, and achieve.
 


What We Need & What You Get
In order to continue our summer program beginning in July 2013, we are asking for your assistance {and generosity}. Of course, we want to give you a special gift for your investment!  We have a plan to raise $700 before June 28th.  And that plan includes you, our kids, and some very enticing incentives.
All of your contributions (whether we meet our goal or not) will go towards the operating costs of the Academy Street Firehouse summer program.  But of course we WILL meet our goal... with your help.
 
The Impact


Initiatives like the Firehouse Summer Enrichment and Summer Teen Apprenticeship Programs address the achievement gap by offering youth a fun, targeted opportunity for learning and practicing skills.
We give young people opportunities that build resilience and life-long healthy behaviors.  And we do this through an afterschool program {with a summer initiative} designed just for our unique population.
 


Other Ways You Can Help

1.  SHARE this page with friends, colleagues, and family to let them know that you thought of them, and they may be interested in helping kids achieve.  www.igg.me/at/firehouse

story:
Employing Youth And Helping Guide Tomorrow's Leaders. Today.

Having grown up after the evolution of the Internet and with technology permeating through every aspect of their lives, youth are the first generation of "digital natives". They are tech-savvy and have the skills and comfort with technology beyond most adults today.  For youth growing up in economically challenged areas, facing the high costs of college, the challenging job market, or youth dealing with mental health issues such as autism, ADHD and depression, the future can look bleak.  But the power of hope and opportunity has a tremendous impact on changing the dynamic, and while most businesses aren't setup to manage large groups of youth employees, we are and exclusively hire 14-25 year olds! 

Supporting Youth Like Mom & Dad Would

As a group of parents, aunts and uncles, we've built a technology services company that aims to change the dynamic facing today's youth, harness their untapped skills and revolutionize what business and youth employees can achieve.  If you think it, we can do it.

From the start, we've considered what, when, why and how to provide youth with best environment to succeed, earning us the moniker of being "Office Mom & Dad".  Our patent pending model provides youth with the opportunity to work from home, gain work experience, learn life skills and help set aside funds for future higher learning regardless of where they are located.  Where youth come to us with autism or other challenges, we embrace the opportunity to integrate them into YP-IT and provide an environment that maximizes their skills and potential. 

In our short existence, we've garnering tremendous interest from businesses wanting to make a difference, empower youth and get some of their needed work done.  

What Your Help Means

For youth: 

  • Valuable work experience and insight into different careers
  • Paid salary and a contribution to a post-secondary education savings fund
  • An environment that supports their strengths to help gain confidence in their abilities and preparation for their future career 
  • Teach life lessons in areas such as financial literacy and business acumen that are needed to succeed in today's world 

For businesses: 

  • High-quality technical services for work that needs to be completed but seems too burdensome to tackle 
  • Access to digital content instead of warehouses of paper files that don't yield real information
  • Better prepared new recruits and access to a well-trained young workforce

For society: 

  • YP-IT contributes to a school technology fund for every hour worked by a student, thus each student actually helps to support improving the technology within their school
  • Students are more aware of career options and come out of school with just that amount less debt
  • Youth are better stewards of their future by learning about budgeting, credit scores and how lives are impacted by a lack of financial literacy

Help Us Get To 200!

The initial interest from companies has been great and so we want to ramp up our systems to support more students and handle larger projects.  We are looking to raise $50,000.  Your help will allow us to add servers so that more youth can work simultaneously.  This will help expand the number of youth we can take on throughout the USA and Canada to 200 youth employees!!  

Our Unique Perks

We've come up with a number of unique perks that we believe give those interested in showing their support for the youth of today something that can really help them make their mark.  These include (subject to approval):

  • Get the naming rights to the technology fund donation going to your son or daughter's school for two (2) or four (4) years
  • Become a Youth Ambassador or Champion and have your name and/or company logo displayed on our website 
  • Join the YP-IT Founders Wall and have your name and/or company logo included in all our announcements for three (3) years

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand no everyone can help financially, but there are plenty of other ways you can:

  • Look around your office and identify documents to digitize, data to entry or other work that could be shared and make your company more productive
  • Share our campaign with everyone you know and get them to share the news
  • Like us on Facebook and share our news with your friends
  • Follow us on Twitter and tweet all about us
  • Visit us at www.yp-it.com

We thank you so much for your support!

story:
We rarely think of spam this way, but it has become a human development problem for several areas of the world, prohibiting citizens from fully realizing the potential of the Internet. With your help, we are determined not to let Spam continue to be a barrier to free trade, educational opportunities, and access to information for developing countries.

The Internet Society’s Combating Spam Project aims to educate policymakers in developing countries about the problem to come-up with innovative solutions. But we have not yet been able to take the project off the ground: 70% of the funds needed to get the project running are already available.  

This means we need to raise $20,000 in the next days to make it a reality. This is why your contribution is so extremely important.

==> This is an official Internet Society project, learn more about it on our website

You can help fund this fight!

With your help, we are determined not to let Spam continue to be a barrier to free trade, educational opportunities, and access to information for developing countries.

Building on more than 20 years of experience defending an open and global Internet, our goal is to inform and educate those who can act to solicit change and help to minimize the negative impacts of Spam on quality of life.

We believe the best way to do this is by bringing together policymakers, technical experts, and civil society organizations to discuss and create innovative solutions.

== Update: our first seminar on Combating Spam for Policy Makers, in Nairobi, Kenya will happen October 7th, 2013. More about it soon.


Your support will help ensure that (see detailed breakdown below):

  • materials on the topic are created and shared in several languages, and
  • as many policymakers as possible are able to attend,
  • conversations will continue beyond the workshops, disseminating the outcomes of each of these events with those who can create change.

Full Project Breakdown

Substance, documents and materials
  • Leverage existing technical materials and developing new white papers prepared by experts from within the industry
  • Create training videos that showcase technical experts speaking on a specific topic related to Spam to reach new audiences and for others to use to refresh knowledge base
Workshops for Regulators
  • Workshops will be held in conjunction with a scheduled regional regulatory meeting, such as the Inter-American Telecommunication Commission (CITEL) or Advanced Packaging Tool (APT), so that the maximum number of regulators, policymakers and government advisors can attend.
  • Outlining roles (policymakers, technical community, experts, tools) and relationships
  • Dialogue with Industry experts regarding tools, techniques, risks and on-going partnerships
Sustainable Partnerships
  • Promote an exchange between experts and technical communities through Technical Workshops held in conjunction with regional Network Operator Group (NOG) and Regional Internet Registry (RIR) meetings
  • Encourage on-going connections between these developing and expert communities to ensure that mentors and resource ” backups” are established that can address issues as they arise

Who We Are and What We Do

By connecting the world, working with others, and advocating for equal access to the Internet, the Internet Society strives to make the world a better place. We believe that the Internet is for everyone. 

We are an international non-profit organization with 98 chapters worldwide. Founded in 1992 by Internet pioneers, we have tens of thousands of members across the globe and regional bureaus in Africa, Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean, North America, South Asia, and Southeast Asia.

We are committed to:
  • Fostering an open, innovative, and trusted Internet worldwide
  • Advancing policies and strategies that strengthen the Internet’s growth and evolution
  • Enabling a vibrant and vital global community to advance the Internet’s future
  • Empowering people to achieve human potential through unencumbered Internet use

Can't donate right now? No worries, click below and help by sharing:
