story:
Becoming a Midwife

It wasn't until 5 years ago, when my sister got pregnant for the first time, that I was exposed to the profession of midwifery. I had always planned on entering the medical profession, and being present at my sister's prenatal visits, and the birth of my niece, helped focus my attention towards this specific field.

In September 2010, I began studying midwifery through a US based school that offers distance education. I was a full time student for over a year. Since starting this program, I have worked two jobs while helping to care for my nieces. Unfortunately my old school is not accredited (though I was assured it would be when I enrolled) and it's almost impossible for Canadian students to relocate and get adequate clinical training in the US. I began brainstorming about different educational options, and looked into studying in New Zealand.

Tauranga, New Zealand has been my home for much of my adult life, and returning there is obviously appealing. Studying midwifery in New Zealand has advantages; it is a country that is spearheading midwifery care worldwide and they offer 3 year bachelor programs. Not wanting to wait any longer, I applied for a program at the Waikato Institute of Technology that begins on January 19, 2012. And I was accepted!

The Help I Need

Everyone that knows me agrees that I will make an excellent midwife. There's nothing I've felt more confident about. I'm passionate about caring for women in western nations as they explore their pregnancy and birth options. I'll also use my training to help women in areas of the world with poor maternal care. Developing nations account for 99% of all maternal deaths. I want to be involved with expanding women's maternity care around the world.

I have set up this fundraising page to ask for help. Because I will be an international student at the Waikato Institute of Technology in New Zealand, my tuition is drastically raised. I have applied for a student loan, but even with that, my tuition and living expenses will not be fully covered.

I am trusting that those who have a relationship with me know my character; I am hard-working, generous, and always looking out for the well-being of others. A lot of you are Christians who donate money to missionaries. Although this is not a traditional request, you can think of it similarly. Think of how effectively I can love and care for others if I'm LITERALLY qualified to save lives!

A Message from My Sister

"Kimberly is one of the most caring people on the planet. How many of you reading this have been deeply impacted by her fierce commitment to relationships? Was she in your wedding party? Do your children call her "Auntie"? Has she flown in an airplane to visit you? She's always gone above and beyond for us, so I hope we can do the same for her now, when she needs our help.

If you don't know her, I can vouch that Kimberly is a worthy investment. She'll take the skills she'll learn and do good in the world. And we all know that we need more good in this world.

Please, give generously."

- Lindsay Bradford-Ewart

Related Links

Why We Need Midwives

My Bachelor of Midwifery Program

New Zealand Midwives

A Wikipedian Definition of Midwifery

More Maternal Health Information from the World Health Organization

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with anyone who might be interested.

Spread it around for me! If you have any questions, email me.

I'll be moving to Tauranga, NZ with nothing. If you know of any places to live, free furniture or other necessary items, let me know!
story_txt:
Becoming a Midwife
It wasn't until 5 years ago, when my sister got pregnant for the first time, that I was exposed to the profession of midwifery. I had always planned on entering the medical profession, and being present at my sister's prenatal visits, and the birth of my niece, helped focus my attention towards this specific field. In September 2010, I began studying
midwifery through a US based school that offers distance education. I
was a full time student for over a year. Since starting this program, I have worked two jobs while helping to care for my nieces. Unfortunately my old school is not
accredited (though I was assured it would be when I enrolled)
and it's almost impossible for Canadian students to relocate and get
adequate clinical training in the US. I began brainstorming about different educational options, and looked into studying in New
Zealand.


Tauranga, New Zealand has been my home for much of my adult life, and returning there is
obviously appealing. Studying midwifery in New Zealand has
advantages; it is a
country that is spearheading midwifery care worldwide and  they offer 3 year bachelor programs. Not wanting to wait any longer, I applied for a program at the Waikato Institute of Technology that begins on January 19, 2012. And I was accepted!


The Help I Need

Everyone that knows me agrees that I will
make an excellent midwife. There's nothing I've felt more
confident about. I'm passionate about caring for women in western nations as they explore their pregnancy and birth options. I'll also
use my training to help women in areas of the world with poor
maternal care. Developing nations account for 99% of all maternal
deaths. I want to be involved with expanding women's maternity care around the world.
I have set up this fundraising page to
ask for help. Because I will be an international student at the
Waikato Institute of Technology in New Zealand, my tuition is
drastically raised. I have applied for a student loan, but even with
that, my tuition and living expenses will not be fully covered. 
I am trusting that those who have a
relationship with me know my character; I am hard-working,
generous, and always looking out for the well-being of others. A lot of you are Christians who donate money to missionaries. Although this is not a traditional request, you can think of it similarly. Think of how effectively I can love and care for others if I'm LITERALLY qualified to save lives!


A Message from My Sister

"Kimberly is one of the most caring people on the planet. How many of you reading this have been deeply impacted by her fierce commitment to relationships? Was she in your wedding party? Do your children call her "Auntie"? Has she flown in an airplane to visit you? She's always gone above and beyond for us, so I hope we can do the same for her now, when she needs our help.
If you don't know her, I can vouch that Kimberly is a worthy investment. She'll take the skills she'll learn and do good in the world. And we all know that we need more good in this world.
Please, give generously."
- Lindsay Bradford-Ewart
Related Links
Why We Need Midwives
My Bachelor of Midwifery Program
New Zealand Midwives 
A Wikipedian Definition of Midwifery
More Maternal Health Information from the World Health Organization

Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this campaign with anyone who might be interested. 
Spread it around for me! If you have any questions, email me. 
I'll be moving to Tauranga, NZ with nothing. If you know of any places to live, free furniture or other necessary items, let me know!

story:
How do we inspire the next generation to consider stewardship of the Earth in a new way? How do we encourage compassion for the living world and develop cooperation between people who seem "different?" We do it by singing a new song!


     The Daisyworld Project is an interdisciplinary program that facilitates the exploration of nature; plumbs attitudes regarding consumption and our role in the world; encourages cooperative effort and promotes self-expression through writing, spoken word and making music.


     We bring two unrelated groups of middle school students together and, using internet-based technology and communications tools, allow them to record their thoughts on the living world around them and explore a cooperative approach to creating music. The Daisyworld Project team will combine their musical efforts with the musical contributions of professional musicians and the spoken contributions of scientists, philosophers, elders, and artists (unless, of course, they'd rather sing!) The final production of music becomes fundraising tool for the schools and charities in both their hometowns and abroad. 


     The Daisyworld Project introduces middle school children to the value of expression and the idea that creative work can indeed be a force for change in the world. The 2011-2012 pilot program will be held in middle schools in Ithaca, NY and Brooklyn, NY

story:
Within 12 months, three young people were laid to rest in Smithville, TX.

The town needed to do something to honor them, console their families, and reach out and pay tribute to the countless veterans who have served our great country. 

Smithville, TX (population 3,817), decided to build a park. A place to pay tribute... A place to pray for peace...

The centerpiece is a 15-foot tall angel sculpted by world-renowned and local resident Bill McGlaun, which is dedicated to seven brave service members in all who made the ultimate sacrifice between 2006 and 2011, and to their family and friends who remain.

Other areas in the park are dedicated to the veterans from every era since the Texas Revolution in 1836. Plaques are up for over 1,000 veterans already, with more planned for about another 4,000.

We have been able to fund almost all of the park with the resources we have – time, labor, materials, some money… what’s left is the cost of the foundry for the angel. We need to raise about $60,000 to get the angel off the ground. Please help us!

The Impact of your Gift

This park will be a place for the grieving to find solace, a place for children to learn about our history, and a place that pays an important tribute to the men and women who have sacrificed their time, their limbs, and sometimes their lives to protect and ensure our freedoms.

With the angel lifting the dog tags of the seven fallen heroes as she rises, the park will help to lift the spirits of the people who come to visit this place to pay homage to our many veterans.

Donations of cash, labor, materials, and other in-kind contributions have already amounted to about $650,000. People from this small town have done a lot to make it happen in Smithville. This is the final piece to completing the park. The angel needs your help.

What you get

With donations of any size, you get our heartfelt thanks and a tour of the park if you are able to visit Smithville (a great place to be!).

With any donation over $25, we will include the name of a service member on the memorial plaques posted in the park. 

With donations over $100, in addition to the name on the plaques, a paver that can be dedicated to that service member will be placed in the park.

To claim these perks, you will need to provide Jill Strube with the name, rank, branch of service, and conflict or years of service of the veteran--click on Jill's icon at the top of this page to send her a message with the details.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us make this go viral! Forward this to as many people as possible to help us reach our goal. "Like" us with the Facebook icon!

If you can’t contribute at this time but live in Bastrop County, we are currently seeking people who can help post the plaques on the wall as they come in, as well as for more help in researching the Bastrop County Veterans and developing the archive. 

And if you are ever in Central Texas, come on out to visit us! We’d love to meet y’all and show you our beautiful park and the rest of this magical area!

Our many thanks to everyone who has already contributed to this project, and our deepest gratitude to the brave men and women who have served this country.

story:
So Who Is This Girl? 

Despite being a writer, trying to decide what to say in the first few lines of something to “catch someone’s attention” is never easy for me--especially when those first few lines are supposed to be about myself. I suppose that’s something I need to work on, so if you are still reading I’ll simply start off this introduction the way I start off every introduction to anyone I’ve ever met--Hi, I’m Kimmee.

If you want to know about my story and why I’m here on Indiegogo asking you to help me go to my dream school I’m not sure how to concisely tell you that, so bear with me if you will. Ever since I was a little girl growing up in my little rural community in southern Michigan, I have been captivated by stories. I feel this sense of connection to the world around me that is hard to describe. When I look at a person I see more than just a face. I see this complicated, beautiful messof possibilities, possibilities to share and create together something incredibly powerful, a story.

I believe storytelling is one of the most powerful tools humanity has. It’s how we connect. It’s how we share. It’s how we understand the people and the world in which we live. This world is a complicated one; everything is always changing. Throughout all the changes in the centuries of this world, however, one thing has not changed. Everyone loves a good story.

The love of a story is something deep within us that connects us all. It’s in our blood. I know it’s in mine because I feel it pulsing through me every day. I live, breathe, and dream stories because I believe with everything in me everyone has a story to tell. True, all stories may not be life changing, Pulitzer Prize winning, stories that impact a whole country, but everyone does have a story to share. Even if that story may only affect a person or two isn’t it worth it to try to share it? That’s why I want to dedicate my life to being a documentary photographer/writer.

This summer, after I finished up my undergraduate studies at Spring Arbor University in Spring Arbor, Michigan I was accepted into my dream school, The Salt Institute for Documentary Studies in Portland, Maine to begin my graduate studies in documentary photography. I had everything fairly well figured out at the start of the summer when I was accepted. I was given a very generous scholarship from Salt, and I thought by working full time at my summer job and using my savings I would be able to take out a small loan and be okay. However, in the beginning of July, I injured my arm, and I’ve been unable to work since. I still thought I might be okay with the scholarship, using all my savings, and taking out a larger loan, but I’m short the money I need.

What We Need & What You Get

I am short around $2,000 to pay for the rest of my housing and tuition and to get the books and equipment I need not only for school this fall, but to set me up for what I need to further my studies and career when I’m done at Salt. Whatever funds I raise first will be going directly toward my housing and tuition, and then I’ll use the rest for books and equipment.

What I can offer as far as perks go are listed in the sidebar; I realize they are small, but hopefully there will be something there that sounds good to you if you’re able to help me.

The Impact

Most writers want to create something that will have an impact, that will be remembered, but I suppose you could say I’m not looking for the “greatness.” If it happens to come my way, then that’s fine, but I’m not trying to seek it out. My goal in life has always aligned with a poem written by one of my favorite poets, Emily Dickenson, “If I can stop one heart from breaking/I shall not live in vain/If I can ease one life the aching, or cool one pain/Or help one fainting robin/Unto his nest again/I shall not live in vain.” The impact I hope to have with the knowledge and experience I’ll gain from Salt is simply to help the people I meet along the way. I’m hoping by getting to share their stories, no matter what they may be, I’ll be able to make even a small difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

I don’t know what made you stop on this campaign. Maybe it was the title, the photo of some random girl on top of a cathedral roof in Italy, or you just happened upon it. Whatever brought you by and whether you were able to donate to me or not, thank you for taking the time  to get to know me a little bit. If you weren’t able to donate, but you still want to help me there are a couple ways you can do that.

  • Let people know about me and what I want to do!
  • Make use of the tools Indiegogo has for social networking to let people on social media sites know about me.

Thank you again!

Let people know about me and what I want to do!
Make use of the tools Indiegogo has for social networking to let people on social media sites know about me.

Thank you again!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Colleen Hudson, and I am a teacher in the small rural town of Thorp, Washington.  We are so small that the whole school district sits in two buildings besides each other.  The high school and middle school boasts a grand total of fifty-four students.  Two years ago I started a History Club call P.A.S.T.-People Actively Seeking the future Through history.  I work with kids grades 6-12 in this club. 

My goal is to teach the importance of the history of this small community and the impact it has had on our state, country, and the world.  One may say, how can such a small town have an affect on the world?  Actually Lt. Col. Claude Thorp originally led the guerilla movement in the Philippines during WWII before being captured and executed. We can also boast about having a four star general graduate from this small school.  You see, this little town has produced men and women that helped change history.


Okay, I bet that you can tell that I live and breathe history.  My goal is to pass at least a bit of my enthusiasm on to the next generation.  This is why I would like to take my kids to Washington D.C. and Williamsburg, Virginia.  We will spend five days touring these two historic cities.  It will be such an exciting time and for most of these kids, this will be a trip of a lifetime.   You see, about 60% of my kids are at poverty level, and one student lost her home to the forest fires that swept through our state last summer.  With your support, these students will travel beyond this little valley and experience events that will remain with them their entire lifetime.  You will also help expose fifteen future voters to the civic duty represented in Washington D.C.

We are going through the Smithsonian’s Education First Student Travel tours.  Everything is included in the package, air flight, tours, meals, and lodging.  This program also offers kids the opportunity to earn one semester credit of history.  My students-especially the middle school kids-are excited to earn an extra credit for high school. The cost for this is 1,829.00 per student and at this time fifteen students want to go.

At the present time, the club has raised approximately $1,400.00 through bake sales.  These kids are amazing and willing to bake our way there.  That is why I've decided to use their skills as perks for your donations.  If you donate, we will bake goodies and send post cards to you from our trip.  We will even make sure that our club sends generous sponsors specially made t-shirt designed for the trip.  You will share the excitement and see the sights that we will see.

If you can't contribute, please help us find other ways in which we can work toward this trip or share our campaign with your friends.  We are grateful for your participation!

story:
CULTURE STOCK

Culture Stock, created by non-profit organization L.I.F.T. Aurora, is a social venture that will operate as a hub for cultural activities and community programs while serving as a used book and media reselller.  We're making our home in downtown Aurora this fall!!  Culture Stock will open up in the Vargas Building at 43 E Galena in downtown Aurora but WE NEED your SUPPORT! 

What We Need to Purchase:

  • Bookshelves
  • Retail Software
  • Utility Deposits
  • Paint
  • Insurance
  • Chairs and Couches
  • Display Shelves

We are a completely volunteer run organization so all money raised goes directly into setting up the space and for supplies needed for our programming.

The Impact

Yes, we're a used bookstore ... but we're also so much more!  We intend to host a variety of programs, activities and events in the heart of downtown Aurora:

  • Mentorships
  • Local Musician Showcases
  • Teen Events
  • Book Clubs
  • Foreign Language Clubs
  • Theater Programs

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word!
  • Follow us on Facebook.com/CultureStock
  • Donate Books, Records, CDs, etc.
  • Donate Office Supplies
  • Attend Future Events
  • Volunteer to Work in our Store!

<3

story:
This Indiegogo Campaign is Over...Please Contribute Here: http://www.givengain.com/cause/2457/projects/11...

The Sibanye Story

Sibanye is the result of two people from South Africa dreaming together.  Randy could neither read nor write but dreamed of becoming a chef.  His friend Nathan had always wanted a place for people from the country’s divided communities to come together.

 

 


Together, in 2008, Randy (then 19) and Nathan (then 21) built Sibanye, which means “together we are one”.  From a humble base in a shack of corrugated iron and ceiling boards in a township near Cape Town a team was built to create and serve delicious traditional South African food. 

 

 

 

 

Since its beginning Sibanye has served over 15,000 meals to local and international guests who come to visit this most unique restaurant: people who can’t afford it eat for free (subsidised instead by willing international guests). 

 

 

Tragically, at the age of 22, Randy passed away in June 2011, leaving an unfillable gap in the Sibanye Team. 

 

 

Faced with the decision of whether to stop or carry on Nathan, Terra and Nosamkelo decided they would relentlessly push on. Together the team wants to take Sibanye to a whole new level, making it a lasting and fitting legacy to Randy’s dream.

 

 

What difference will your help make to Sibanye?

From the Sibanye Team:

We need your help to establish Sibanye as a unifying force that will create the much needed change for this community.  Our expansion from a 25 seater restaurant to a 60 seater restaurant will provide employment to 3 additional community members.  The upgrade of our restaurant will coincide with the launch of Sibanye’s first trailer franchise in Cape Town:

    • We will invest in a mobile unit (a trailer) so that we can serve MORE MEALS to MORE PEOPLE
    • We will RE-FIT and UPGRADE the original restaurant
    • We will RE-VAMP our brand and our marketing
    • When we’re ready we will RE-LAUNCH our revitalised venture 

What’s in it for you?

By investing in us you will be helping to keep our dream alive.  Most importantly you will be making a direct difference to the lives of people living in South Africa.  Also, look to the right to understand how the level of your contribution is incentivised!  Become a part of our Sibanye family – become an official Legend!

The Impact

You will be able to monitor the progress of the project as it unfolds through blog postings that you can follow via the Sibanye website and facebook page, to see the impact for yourself.

Tell the world about Sibanye!

Put Sibanye on your Facebook page, your Twitter account, on your website and on your favorite forum - blog about the project and this campaign and tell your friends, family and co-workers about Sibanye – here’s the link - www.indiegogo.com/POY-Sibanye - THANK YOU!!

The Sibanye Story
Sibanye is the result of two people from South Africa dreaming together.  Randy could neither read nor write but dreamed of becoming a chef.  His friend Nathan had always wanted a place for people from the country’s divided communities to come together.
 

 
 Together, in 2008, Randy (then 19) and Nathan (then 21) built Sibanye, which means “together we are one”.  From a humble base in a shack of corrugated iron and ceiling boards in a township near Cape Town a team was built to create and serve delicious traditional South African food. 
 
 

 

 
Since its beginning Sibanye has served over 15,000 meals to local and international guests who come to visit this most unique restaurant: people who can’t afford it eat for free (subsidised instead by willing international guests). 

 

 
Tragically, at the age of 22, Randy passed away in June 2011, leaving an unfillable gap in the Sibanye Team. 
 

 
Faced with the decision of whether to stop or carry on Nathan, Terra and Nosamkelo decided they would relentlessly push on. Together the team wants to take Sibanye to a whole new level, making it a lasting and fitting legacy to Randy’s dream.
 

 
What difference will your help make to Sibanye? From the Sibanye Team: We need your help to establish Sibanye as a unifying force that will create the much needed change for this community.  Our expansion from a 25 seater restaurant to a 60 seater restaurant will provide employment to 3 additional community members.  The upgrade of our restaurant will coincide with the launch of Sibanye’s first trailer franchise in Cape Town:

We will invest in a mobile unit (a trailer) so that we can serve MORE MEALS to MORE PEOPLE
We will RE-FIT and UPGRADE the original restaurant
We will RE-VAMP our brand and our marketing
When we’re ready we will RE-LAUNCH our revitalised venture 
 What’s in it for you?  By investing in us you will be helping to keep our dream alive.  Most importantly you will be making a direct difference to the lives of people living in South Africa.  Also, look to the right to understand how the level of your contribution is incentivised!  Become a part of our Sibanye family – become an official Legend! The Impact You will be able to monitor the progress of the project as it unfolds through blog postings that you can follow via the Sibanye website and facebook page, to see the impact for yourself. Tell the world about Sibanye!  Put Sibanye on your Facebook page, your Twitter account, on your website and on your favorite forum - blog about the project and this campaign and tell your friends, family and co-workers about Sibanye – here’s the link - www.indiegogo.com/POY-Sibanye - THANK YOU!!

story:
Short Summary

Living Fountain (LF) Orphanage is a Christian haven for children who have either lost both of their parents or have been abandoned. Living Fountain is dedicated to providing a loving environment where the children can grow with dignity and safety, supporting them physically, mentally, emotionally and spiritually to become the future leaders of Cambodia.

Living Fountain is supported primarily by the Young Nak Presbyterian Church, which sends annual volunteer teams to assist the staff and workers of LF, and serve the children with various programs such as day camps and supplement the existing tutoring programs.

This year, the Young Nak Presbyterian Church will be sending a team of ten members to Cambodia on a two-week trip.  We aim to raise funds to deliver an engaging vacation bible school (VBS) retreat for the children at Living Fountain. Money raised will go towards accommodations, food, and ministry supplies.

Please help make this year's camp a reality by donating. 

 

What We Need  

  • Any dollar amount is greatly appreciated
  • Donations of $20 or more are eligible for an official tax receipt by Young Nak Presbyterian Church

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need your prayers!! Please pray for the team (unity, safety and impact) BUT ALSO for the children, for their openness and readiness for the Gospel.

story:
Who We Are 

         Hello! Our names are Daniel Warren Bartlett and Antonio Luke Thompson. We are from Santa Maria, California, where we are both actively involved in our church and our youth group. We are both college students who have a passion for people. We both love our Savior, Jesus Christ, and we both want to live our lives proclaiming the good news of Jesus to the world. 

Where We Are Going

           We have been accepted to Joshua Wilderness Institute, a Christian mentorship program in the Sequoia National Forest at Hume Lake Christian Camps, for the 2012-2013 school year. Joshua is difficult to get into, and we feel very fortunate to have been selected. It is designed to help students grow and change. Every year, more than 250 young people apply from all over the world, and only 56 people are accepted each year; 28 guys and 28 girls. JWI's mission statement is: "Transforming the life effectiveness of God's people," and we want this to be evident in our own lives. 

 

Why We Want To Go

          We want to go to JWI because we know people who have gone through the program, and how their lives have been changed and the passion to serve God has been lit in their hearts. We want to go to Joshua because we know that the lessons we learn and the experiences we share will be life changing. We want to learn what it takes to be a modern-day disciple of Jesus Christ, and how we can live for Christ every day. We want to learn the path set out for us and to trust God to lead us there. We want to go to Joshua because we know that it will be something that we will never forget, and that we will learn lessons, have experiences, and make friends that we will never forget. We want to learn what it means to be a Christ-follower, and not just a Christian. 

 

What We Will Do At Joshua

          While at Joshua, we spend much time devouring and studying God's word. we have many different guest speakers form all over the country come and teach us. we have assignments due and work to be done. We take classes on Elements of Bible, the Pauline Epistles, Major Prophets, Christian Life and Ethics, and many more. We will be taking accredited classes through Moody Bible College, and the classes that we take are transferrable to Moody Bible and San Diego Christian.

          During the year, we will take a total of 6 mission trips; 3 domestic and 3 international. We travel to inner city LA to spread God's word and love to those who are less fortunate. We go to Heartland, a nearby camp, and help with whatever service projects they need which can range from cleaning toilets to raking pine needles, and we go twice in one year. Internationally, we go to Mexico, The Dominican Republic, and finally, Israel. In Mexico, we work at Rancho Sordo Mudo, which is a school for the deaf. We assist with work projects, and learn about the Mexican culture. In the Dominican Republic, we help to teach participants about how to understand God's will for their lives, and how they can pursue it. While there, we also do various work projects to help out the local people. Finally, at the end of the year, we travel to Israel, where we will learn to bring all of our Old Testament learning that we did throughout the year and relate it all. We spend 2 weeks hiking all over Israel, and experience the very rich religious history that the country has to offer. We walk where Jesus walked, and experience the place where our Savior lived and breathed.

 

How You Can Help

           While we are working our hardest and pinching every penny to save for tuition, we only so far have about $4,000 each. Antonio is working this summer at Hume Lake to help pay part of his tuition. Daniel has also worked to pay part of his tuition. We need to raise about  $13,000 more to be able to pay the whole tuition. Our desire to go is huge and our desire to learn is even larger. JWI is not cheap, but it is worth every penny spent. 

COST BREAKDOWN:

$15,000 Tuition Total

-$4,000 Scholarship Worked off Next Summer at Hume Lake

-$4,000 Attendance Guarantee 

-$500 Spot Confirmation                                                                            ________________________________________

$6,500 Tuition Amount Remaining                                                                     x2                                                                                                         __________________________________________

$13,000 Left to Raise

 

All money raised will be applied towards tuition. Any surplus funds raised will go towards helping other students who cannot pay all their tuition. For me, (Daniel) my monthly payments can be covered if i do not raise support, but for Antonio, most of the tuition money is still needed. Any and all contributions will bring us closer to our goal and are much appreciated. THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!!!!

story:
Our Story

I cannot quite describe this school to you, but I have never before appreciated what a community can do when it comes together with a shared purpose...The central part of what makes this school so special is the art program run by two artists-in-residence.

--Peralta parent


Please help Peralta Elementary in Oakland, California save its nationally recognized model arts program!

We are a small, economically and racially diverse school that defies the the stereotypes of an urban public school. Peralta is a place where: 

  • Fourth-graders worked with a UC Berkeley mycologist to create a hand-drawn animated video that will teach Spanish-speaking communities how to use fungus to clean up oil spills.
  • Fifth-graders worked with students and teachers in Bangalore, India on a multifaceted exploration of the meaning of shelter, building a conceptual art installation that makes a statement about slums and the unequal distribution of wealth globally (visit website).
  • Second- and third-graders take regular walks to a community senior center to collaborate with elders on art projects.
 
 
  • First-graders told the cultural history of their neighborhood, the Temescal, through a cut-paper stop-motion animated video (watch it).
  • Every child makes regular visits San Francisco's de Young museum, and begins to think of it as their museum.
  • Student films recently won recognition from Disney Planet Challenge, Stopwaste.org, and prominent directors who judged the Albany Film Festival.
  • Every student works on Peralta's famous quilts, which have been shown internationally, including at the embassy in Moscow.
  • Murals created with artist Jamie Morgan cover every surface of our buildings, organic gardens fill every corner of our cramped schoolyard, and student self-portraits beautify busy Telegraph Avenue.
  • Each of our art projects touch on the big ideas of community and environmental stewardship.

 

Educators from all over Oakland, the Bay Area, and the state have visited Peralta to learn how its arts program has enriched the educational experience of our own students, and sparked the imagination of others who refuse to let public school arts die. We are a designated Oakland Unified Arts Anchor School, and an Alameda County Arts Demonstration School. We have also been honored as a California Distinguished School and a Title I Achievement School, which recognizes the success of our students from all socioeconomic backgrounds.

"These projects have spurred some of the deepest thinking that takes place in my classroom," says 1st-grade teacher Pam Lucker.

 

The Impact

Without your help, Peralta's art program will all but disappear this fall.

For many years, our two artists-in-residence, Ellen Oppenheimer and Trena Noval, have secured grants from a broad patchwork of public and private sources. Sadly, despite their hard work and the sweat equity of our parents and caregivers, many of Peralta's funding sources have dried up. Public arts funding—from the city, the county, and the state—has been cut way back, and many of our foundation grants have run dry as well.

Like every other California public school, we are also facing severe overall budget cuts, which means the loss of a classroom teacher and much larger class sizes. In this difficult environment, the arts are more critical than ever to keep students engaged in school.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $15,000 in online donations, plus an additional $30,000 from events and a large-donor gift campaign. This money will close our funding gap, allowing us to keep our two longstanding artists-in-residence and maintain the art programming that has influenced the lives of so many Oakland children. Recognizing that there are many schools in need, we also plan to donate $1,000 to another Oakland public school art program if we reach our goal.

Please join us in supporting arts education for Oakland kids, and helping others to see how art can be a powerful teaching and learning tool! All donations will be administered by the Peralta Parent Teacher Group, and are tax deductible (EIN # is 94-2831259).

When you make your donation, consider rounding it up by a few dollars to cover the processing fees for the online campaign (click "other amount," round $100 to $106; $50 to $53). You can also save us credit card processing fees if you have a PayPal account linked your bank account. Please make sure to include your name and address so we can thank you and send you your perk!

Also take a moment to share a story about Peralta's arts program, or about why art education is important to you.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the story of Peralta's unique art program with all your friends and colleagues! Share this link on Facebook and Twitter and include it as part of your email signature. The more we spread the word, the better chance we have of reaching our goal.

story:
Short Summary

I will be in Kenya for 3 weeks to providing counselling services to children and families in the slums of Nairobi. I will be working along side social workers with the Chosen Children of Promise organization If you would like to know more about this organization, here is the link http://www.ccpkenya.org/ Our counselling services will include spiritual integration, a very important value to the people of Kenya, and also to myself:

I am a first year Clinical Psychology Graduate student with the opportunity to enhance my counselling skills while providing services to those in need in Kenya.

The experience of providing services to families who are in severe need will be a once in a lifetime opportunity for me. The people of Nairobi will be extremely grateful for my visit and offer to help them. The experience will enhance my beginning therapeutic skills and help me become an empathic, well-rounded budding therapist.

 

What I Need:

  • My entire trip cost is around $7000
  • Your donations will help me pay for my travel expenses, lodging, meals, and tuition expenses to join this opportunity.
  • Donations will also be used to buy teaching materials for the therapy sessions, such as crafts, games, and helpful hand-outs.

I have some financial aid to cover part of my expenses but am a couple thousand short, so any donation will be greatly appreciated.

Although I am leaving for Kenya July 5, 2012 for 3 weeks, I have until mid August to pay the remaining balance in my school account, so at least I have a little extra time to fund for my trip.

THANK YOU!!!         THANK YOU!!!         THANK YOU!!!           THANK YOU!!!

story:
Why create permaculture schools for children? 

Our Story

We begin our story by painting the picture of our dream school.  This story takes place in the near future, likely three to four years from now.  Let's imagine ourselves at the Earth Arts School;  you walk into morning circle to find a mixed group of children and adults practicing in unison a routine of movement, meditation and song in the warm sunlight. 

Afterward, students split off into groups of 7 or 8, and follow their teachers to various classrooms, indoor and outdoor.   One group goes into the garden to prepare a bed for spring greens, others enter the art studio to make mugs for the community kitchen, while a third goes off to read historical stories in a woodland setting, a fourth is practicing compassionate communication, and a fifth is installing windows in a dwelling  built from recycled materials. 

After morning classes the group gathers with the rest of the community to eat a healthy feast of food grown on the land and prepared through the collaboration of students, community members and visitors.  Students at Earth Arts School in addition to learning core subjects such as math, reading, and science, learn how to live sustainably on the earth through courses in permaculture, organic gardening and natural building.  They learn self care through yoga, dance, and nutritional education.  We will teach how to live in harmony with the community around them by learning social studies AND social skills. 

The classroom teachers will not only be their educators, but also their neighbors, parents, aunts, uncles, and friends.  This is a school where a student  will graduate eighth grade as a functional member of his or her community with a diverse set of  life-applicable skills.  The Earth Arts School will also support high school students actively engaged in working apprenticeships, where they gain real life experience shadowing experts in their chosen fields.  The school will be open to humans of all ages, as we believe learning is a life-long profession.  

Our journey toward creating the Earth Arts School has begun, and we have several beautiful chapters ahead of us.  There are many steps to reaching our ultimate goal and we are happy to do the work that it takes to get there.  As a wise friend said, dream big, then do the work that is in front of you.


Chapter One; The Exploration

Chapter one is gathering wisdom through this question; HOW ARE CHILDREN EDUCATED IN ECO-VILLAGES AND RURAL INTENTIONAL COMMUNITIES?  We have experienced living in intentional community and have experienced working in inspiring educational institutions, and now we are looking for living models that encompass both.  Our journey is to visit communities who educate their youth internally, creating a system where students are given a nurturing environment to learn the values and arts of living communally and in sustainable relationship with the earth. There are certainly great examples out there, and we will gain wisdom by visiting, living, working and playing directly with intentional communities across the United States and Europe.  We are choosing communities who either already have schools or systems for internal education or are seeking to create educational systems. 

Communities we will visit;

River Farm and the Three Rivers Co-operative, Deming, WA; http://www.evergreenlandtrust.org/

Alderleaf Farm and Wilderness College - Monroe, WA; www.WildernessCollege.com

Finney Farm - Concrete, WA; www.finneyfarm.org

Dancing Rabbit Ecovillage - Rutledge, MO; www.dancingrabbit.org

The Possibility Alliance - La Plata, MO;
http://www.motherearthnews.com/nature-community...

Twin Oaks Community - Louisa, VA www.twinoaks.org

Acorn Community - Mineral, VA; www.acorncommunity.org

Tamera - Healing Biotope I, Monte de Cerro, Portugal; www.tamera.org

La Borie Noble, Community of the Ark, Lanza del Vasto, France;
http://www.arche-de-st-antoine.com/anglais/fram...

Findhorn Foundation and Community, Forres, Scotland; www.findhorn.org

Les Amis de la Douceur et de L'Harmonie (Gentleness and Harmony) - Eastern Pyrenees, France; http://douceurharmonie.wordpress.com/

Matavenero - Vale de Bierzo, Spain; http://thatroundhouse.info/matavenero.htm

Valle de Sensaciones, Yator, Spain; http://www.sensaciones.de/

Damanhur, Valchiusella, Italy; http://www.damanhur.org/


We believe that the success of the Earth Arts educational model is dependent on the school being integrated into a supportive community; one created through the mutual intentions of the residents to live sustainably on earth. 

Want to learn more about intentional communities?  visit www.ic.org for more information.

How does intentional community relate to permaculture?
According to Jillian Hovey, a seasoned permaculture teacher, "Permaculture is a philosophy that informs an approach to planning, designing, building and maintaining sustainable systems,"  not just in the realm of food production, she says but also in human culture, "the ultimate expression of which would be sustainable communities".  We attest that if we want to set the stage for future generations to live sustainably on this planet, we must create educational models based on sustainable lifestyles.  We must teach them to co-create not only with the natural world but with other humans; Our vision is of a school at the heart of intentional community.

Chapter Two; Further Education

The completion of the US and European tour leads to the next chapter.  Chapter two is to further our career as educators through the Taruna College or equivalent Waldorf teacher training program (for more info visit http://www.taruna.ac.nz/). 

We love the Waldorf educational model and, after completing the teacher training, will incorporate many of their methods into the Earth Arts curriculum.  Learn more about Waldorf at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waldorf_education

Chapter Three; Creating the School

We will now have lived and experienced some of the best models and examples of communities with inspiring schools and are ready to create the Earth Arts School, freshly infused with the wisdom gathered from our journey.

We are proud to be alive on this beautiful EARTH with you.  We feel inspired to work toward creating a heavenly world where COMMUNITY and EDUCATION thrive together, holistically, as one.  Our life calling is to create the Earth Arts School, and we hope you feel called to collaborate.

The Impact

We will create a school that will serve as an educational model for a generation of earthlings who will grow up truly connected to their ecosystems AND be skilled in the basic arts of living gently and creatively on earth.  We (with your help!) will serve much the same purpose as bees do, buzzing from community to community to collect and share our ideological pollen and germinate more successful varieties of human culture.  We are determined to follow this mission no matter how much financial energy we receive to fuel our endeavors. 


What We Need & What You Get

We will tour from community to community via train and BICYCLE, therefore reducing our dependency on the oil industry.  Also, since we will be visiting communities in the spring summer and fall, our focus is to eat almost entirely locally grown organic produce at each community.  We are frugal by nature, so we can be sure that the majority of the donations for this campaign will go toward supporting the communities and schools directly.  At each community we will also donate our personal human energy, skills, and creative qualities through a work trade, reducing even more the financial cost of this odyssey.  We look forward to practicing our skills by really walking our talk when it comes to living ever more sustainably.  


We do need help in crossing the Atlantic ocean!  It's just not possible to bike across  :)

We want to take a boat over Europe to encourage slow travel, just like the slow food movement.  Prices for a sailing or cruise ship are comparable to air fares.


What do YOU get?

There is that yummy universal feeling you may experience in your whole being if you donate, just like that tingling feeling of knowing you are aligning with the good forces of life.  Perhaps you will laugh with that infamous cosmic giggle that is contagious to those living their hearts' desires.


We will also be compiling our research through photography, visual art, writing, and song and will be updating our website with our findings.


We currently own the domain EarthArtsSchool.org, but are still working on the web design.  We will notify you as soon as it is up and running.  In the mean time you can email us any questions or comments at EarthArtsSchool@gmail.com


Other Ways You Can Help

Email us your comments, questions, and suggestions to EarthArtsSchool@gmail.com

Support Intentional Communities and alternative education

Buy a subscription to Communities magazine

Visit www.ic.org

Visit or volunteer at intentional communities

Support your local farmers!


Stay tuned for more updates.  THANK YOU for your support in whatever way possible.  We hope you will breathe deep, laugh often, and go for your dreams too :)
story_txt:
Why create permaculture schools for children?  Our Story
We begin our story by painting the picture of our dream school.  This story takes place in the near future, likely three to four years from now.  Let's imagine ourselves at the Earth Arts School;  you walk into morning circle to find a mixed group of children and adults practicing in unison a routine of movement, meditation and song in the warm sunlight.  Afterward, students split off into groups of 7 or 8, and follow their teachers to various classrooms, indoor and outdoor.   One group goes into the garden to prepare a bed for spring greens, others enter the art studio to make mugs for the community kitchen, while a third goes off to read historical stories in a woodland setting, a fourth is practicing compassionate communication, and a fifth is installing windows in a dwelling  built from recycled materials.  After morning classes the group gathers with the rest of the community to eat a healthy feast of food grown on the land and prepared through the collaboration of students, community members and visitors.  Students at Earth Arts School in addition to learning core subjects such as math, reading, and science, learn how to live sustainably on the earth through courses in permaculture, organic gardening and natural building.  They learn self care through yoga, dance, and nutritional education.  We will teach how to live in harmony with the community around them by learning social studies AND social skills.  The classroom teachers will not only be their educators, but also their neighbors, parents, aunts, uncles, and friends.  This is a school where a student  will graduate eighth grade as a functional member of his or her community with a diverse set of  life-applicable skills.  The Earth Arts School will also support high school students actively engaged in working apprenticeships, where they gain real life experience shadowing experts in their chosen fields.  The school will be open to humans of all ages, as we believe learning is a life-long profession.   

Our journey toward creating the Earth Arts School has begun, and we have several beautiful chapters ahead of us.  There are many steps to reaching our ultimate goal and we are happy to do the work that it takes to get there.  As a wise friend said, dream big, then do the work that is in front of you.Chapter One; The ExplorationChapter one is gathering wisdom through this question; HOW ARE CHILDREN EDUCATED IN ECO-VILLAGES AND RURAL INTENTIONAL COMMUNITIES?  We have experienced living in 
intentional community and have experienced working in inspiring 
educational institutions, and now we are looking for living models that 
encompass both.  Our journey is to visit communities who educate their 
youth internally, creating a system where students are given a nurturing
 environment to learn the values and arts of living communally and in 
sustainable relationship with the earth. There are certainly great 
examples out there, and we will gain wisdom by visiting, living, working and playing directly with intentional communities across the United States and Europe.  We are choosing communities who either 
already have schools or systems for internal education or are seeking to
 create educational systems.  Communities we will visit;River Farm and the Three Rivers Co-operative, Deming, WA; http://www.evergreenlandtrust.org/Alderleaf Farm and Wilderness College - Monroe, WA; www.WildernessCollege.comFinney Farm - Concrete, WA; www.finneyfarm.orgDancing Rabbit Ecovillage - Rutledge, MO; www.dancingrabbit.orgThe Possibility Alliance - La Plata, MO; http://www.motherearthnews.com/nature-community...Twin Oaks Community - Louisa, VA www.twinoaks.orgAcorn Community - Mineral, VA; www.acorncommunity.orgTamera - Healing Biotope I, Monte de Cerro, Portugal; www.tamera.orgLa Borie Noble, Community of the Ark, Lanza del Vasto, France; http://www.arche-de-st-antoine.com/anglais/fram...Findhorn Foundation and Community, Forres, Scotland; www.findhorn.orgLes Amis de la Douceur et de L'Harmonie (Gentleness and Harmony) - Eastern Pyrenees, France; http://douceurharmonie.wordpress.com/Matavenero - Vale de Bierzo, Spain; http://thatroundhouse.info/matavenero.htmValle de Sensaciones, Yator, Spain; http://www.sensaciones.de/Damanhur, Valchiusella, Italy; http://www.damanhur.org/We believe that the success of the Earth Arts educational model is dependent on the school being integrated into a supportive community; one created through the mutual intentions of the residents to live sustainably on earth.  Want to learn more about intentional communities?  visit www.ic.org for more information.How does intentional community relate to permaculture?According to Jillian Hovey, a seasoned 
permaculture teacher, "Permaculture is a philosophy that informs an 
approach to planning, designing, building and maintaining sustainable 
systems,"  not just in the realm of food production, she says but also 
in human culture, "the ultimate expression of which would be sustainable
 communities".  We attest that if we want to set the stage for future 
generations to live sustainably on this planet, we must create 
educational models based on sustainable lifestyles.  We must teach them 
to co-create not only with the natural world but with other humans; Our 
vision is of a school at the heart of intentional community.
Chapter Two; Further EducationThe completion of the US and European tour leads to the next chapter.  Chapter two is to further our career as educators through the Taruna College or equivalent Waldorf teacher training program (for more info visit http://www.taruna.ac.nz/).  We love the Waldorf educational model and, after completing the 
teacher training, will incorporate many of their methods into the Earth 
Arts curriculum.  Learn more about Waldorf at 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waldorf_educationChapter Three; Creating the SchoolWe will now have lived and experienced some of the best models and examples of communities with inspiring schools and are ready to create the Earth Arts School, freshly infused with the wisdom gathered from our journey.We are proud to be alive on this beautiful EARTH with you.  We feel inspired to work toward creating a heavenly world where COMMUNITY and EDUCATION thrive together, holistically, as one.  Our life calling is to create the Earth Arts School, and we hope you feel called to collaborate.

What We Need & What You GetWe will tour from community to community via train and BICYCLE, therefore reducing our dependency on the oil industry.  Also, since we will be visiting communities in the spring summer and fall, our focus is to eat almost entirely locally grown organic produce at each community.  We are frugal by nature, so we can be sure that the majority of the donations for this campaign will go toward supporting the communities and schools directly.  At each community we will also donate our personal human energy, skills, and creative qualities through a work trade, reducing even more the financial cost of this odyssey.  We look forward to practicing our skills by really walking our talk when it comes to living ever more sustainably.

story:
Our Story

Project Icarus is an International Interstellar Spacecraft Design Team. Our project started in September 2009, as a volunteer project conceived as the successor to British Interplanetary Society's influential 1978 Project Daedalus.


As such, Project Icarus - Son of Daedalus is a modern engineering design challenge for a fusion propelled based robotic spacecraft capable of exploring a solar system within 15 light-years from Earth.


You can donate and read more about us at http://www.icarusinterstellar.org.

The Impact

What started as a scientific question has now become an engineering challenge for Project Icarus. Project Daedalus proved that Interstellar Flight was FEASIBLE. Project Icarus is now focused on proving Interstellar travel is REALIZABLE within our lifetimes. 


We have set strict limitations for our design. The Icarus spacecraft would need to reach a its target star within 100 years - ideally much less. For example, we would need to achieve speeds of approximately 10% of the speed of light to decelerate at Alpha Centauri within 75 years. Contrast with the Voyager-1 spacecraft will approach another star in 24,000 years.


We have 35 researchers - all dedicating thousands of hours of their time to understand the scientific constraints and spread the world to people like you - "The technology is within our grasp. All we need is focus and a good plan!" 


Project Icarus has an active Student Designer program - the only interstellar spacecraft design program in the world! We intend on training current and future generations in interstellar spacecraft design. By doing so, we believe we can also drive current solar system and planetary space exploration. A starship capable of going to Alpha Centauri in 50 years can make it to Mars in 3 weeks!


Project Icarus has now founded "Icarus Interstellar" - a non-profit research organization with aim to foster research into those necessary technologies which can make interstellar research a reality:


- Fusion,

- Advanced Ultra-light, ultra-strong materials,

- Nanotechnology

- Advanced power sources

- Artificial or Machine Intelligence for space exploration

- ... and many more


A complete breakdown of our (20) research modules can be found at http://www.icarusinterstellar.org/currentresearch.php


What We Need

Project Icarus is made up of volunteers around the world. We work remotely and only a small fraction of us have ever been in the same room together. Our main purpose for this fund-raising effort is to allow out students and researchers present the DARPA / NASA 100 Year Starship Symposium (http://www.100yss.org).


Many of our designers are highly motivated students without the financial capability to travel across the world to present at this conference. 


** The funds raised here will be used exclusively for travel and board to the 100 Year Starship Symposium (100YSS).**


Priority will be given to our student designers * we believe in investing in the future!


For a list of team members please visit our member page at http://www.icarusinterstellar.org/team_members.php


What You Get

$5 - You have contributed towards space exploration.


$10 - You have made an impact on interstellar exploration and the future of mankind.


$20 - Your name will be noted on our website as a Gold donor.


$50 - Honorable Mention on our website by name at the 100 Year Starship Symposium. 


$100 - Honorable Mention at 100YSS and you will receive an exclusive A3 poster of the Daedalus or Icarus Spacecraft, courtesy of Adrian Mann (http://www.bisbos.com)


$500 -  At this donation level you will become eligible to receive our bimonthly internal progress newsletter "The Icarus Pulse", which contains team news, recent publications, Icarus design milestones and news on technological innovations leading to interstellar flight. You will also receive an exclusive A2 poster of the Daedalus or Icarus Spacecraft, courtesy of Adrian Mann (http://www.bisbos.com)


$1000 - You will be invited after review to become a Friend of Icarus. You will be included in internal discussions on the direction of the design project. Friends of Icarus are considered active participants in our research project.


$5000 - Instant Friend of Icarus status and invitation to the Board of Advisors of Icarus Interstellar. This makes you a Steward of Icarus. You will have a voice in our design directions and fund-raising opportunities in the future.  


Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways you can help. Interstellar exploration is an extremely difficult undertaking and we need all the help and inspiration we can get. If you think you can help - you can! 


- Do you have a degree or skills relating to space exploration? Become an Icarus designer!

- Do you have a large circle of friends in social networks? Tell them about us - any contribution to our cause will help!

- Subscribe to our mailing list at http://www.icarusinterstellar.org

- Join our Facebook group at http://www.facebook.com/groups/icarusinterstellar/


Star Trek inspired us to reach for the stars. To become the ultimate explorers of our universe. We want that dream to become a reality for ourselves and our children.   It only takes a few good people with bright ideas... But we need to start now!


For more information contact us at info@icarusinterstellar.org

story: The Bellaire High School 2002 Class Officers are scrambling to make our reunion possible. I opened this campaign in an attempt to make it happen!
story_txt: The Bellaire High School 2002 Class Officers are scrambling to make our reunion possible. I opened this campaign in an attempt to make it happen!

story:
There's only one place to find 600 Mr. Miyagis in the United States

And that's at the Higher Educational Web Professionals Conference. This year, that conference will be in Milwaukee, October 10-12.

It's like the Tri-Valley tournament of higher ed web conferences. Experts in content strategy, programming, social media, information architecture, marketing, brand development, and audience engagement come together for three days of learning, sharing, collaborating, and bonding.

But there's no leg-sweeping going on here. This is the greatest group of professionals you can join. The relationships you make here will be invaluable - a resource to turn to for advice, tips, instruction, collaboration, and just plain old shoulder-to-cry on support when all else fails.

We're looking for Daniel Carusos to bring to the Tournament

As great as this group is, it hasn't reached everyone. And that's where you come in.

We're looking to fund the registration fees for three attendees to come to the conference. Up and coming underdogs who've got the chops and the know-how, but just don't have the resources to come.

Here's the deal. Donate what you can to help us meet our goal. Along the way, we've got some excellent corporate sponsors willing to chip and do their part as a way to show their appreciation to the community. In return, they've provided us with a few perks which you can see listed.

What We Need

We're looking for $1854 from individuals and corporate sponsors to fund three registrations

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

Where does the money go?

If we reach our funding goal of $1800, the money will go directly to three chosen winners from our applicant pool to purchase conference passes. We'll coordinate those funds going on to heweb. The remaining $54.00 will go towards the processing fee for the fundraiser to Indiegogo.

If the funding amount is not reached, we will still retain the funds that have been collected, minus a 9% fee for indiegogo. The amount will be used to purchase conference passes from our winners, up to the number we can.  Any remaining balance will be donated to that winner to cover the costs of airfare or for hotel.

Hey, Daniel-Sans!

Want to come to heweb?

Here are the ground rules:

  • You must never have attended an HighEdWeb national conference before
  • You must fill out this essay on why you want to attend
  • You must agree to write a blog post on your greatest takeaways from the conference (publication site to be determined)
  • You must wax all the cars and paint all our fences, after doing 3,000 push ups over lit candles (just kidding)

We can only guarantee that your scholarship will cover the costs of your ticket to heweb (unless we don't reach our goal - see above). It won't cover getting here or staying in a hotel so take note! (the hotel runs about $149 a night).

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Spread the Word

  • Get the word out and let people know about our scholarship
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to let people know when you have donated!


Perks for all Donors!

A thank you from .EDUguru

At the conclusion of the campaign, we will do a write up thanking everyone by name that contributed, along with a link of your choice, to give you all warm fuzzies and enshrine in eternity that you did something good for all mankind. (good for individuals and vendors)

I Donated Badge

Donate at the $5.00 dollar and higher and receive a badge indicating your donated for use on your site, Facebook, or your forehead in an Instagram photo - wherever! Please use responsibly. 

SWAG from HighEdWeb Syracuse

The School of Information Studies and J.D. Ross have sweetened the donation pot with swag bags from the HighEdWeb Regional in Syracuse! This includes a handy canvas drawstring bag, notepad and pens. 
 
This freebie is available to anyone whop has donated to date and up until midnight on Wednesday, July 25th!

Prove that your karate is strong! No Mercy!

This is a grass-roots, crowd-funded campaign and is not related to the HighEdWeb organization in any way.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Dan Oh and when I’m not working as a copywriter in NYC, I am involved in the annual IYF World Camp.

IYF World Camp provides quality development programs that teach and inspire young people to become agents of change throughout the world. During its infancy in 1995, IYF World Camp first inspired me to serve others and sacrifice myself for the greater good. I have been giving back to it ever since.

Your generous contributions will help offset the costs of executing our array of programming throughout a typical World Camp day. The better quality the programs, the greater chance our attendees emerge having gained the motivation to change themselves and the lives of others.

What We Need & What You Get

Look to your right and you'll see what you get at different levels of donation amounts.

We’ll also draw names out of a hat every 2 or 3 days and feature that person on our website leading up to the start of the IYF World Camp. We’ll notify you once your name, picture, and contribution amount go live on our website. What you will definitely get is a Thank-You letter you can use for tax purposes and a post-Camp report about what we did and how we used your contributions.

  • We are targeting a total of $25,000 for our online Indiegogo campaign
  • We plan to use Indiegogo donations for the following Camp expenditures:
  • Food                             $ 5000
  • Academy supplies          $ 7500
  • Event supplies               $ 7500
  • Venue rental                 $ 5000

The Impact

IYF World Camp currently serves over 35 countries in 41 separate camps per year. Almost 1 million people have already attended World Camps. Through it, we've sent over 5000 volunteers to foreign countries, 560 medical volunteers who have treated a total of 60,000 patients in developing countries, and 1000 volunteer ESL instructors having taught English in places like Russia, Mexico, and Haiti.

Young people are seeing prime opportunities to serve and become leaders through IYF. This ripple effect is bringing about real, lasting change in the near future. But, we want you to be a part of it today.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a gift to IYF World Camp, you can always contact us about getting involved with the IYF World Camp or any one of our volunteering opportunities, both short- and long-term. Visit us at iyfusa.org for more information or reach out to us through Indiegogo and mention that you heard about us through this site. Emails can be sent to info@iyfef.org.
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is Dan Oh and when I’m not working as a copywriter in NYC, I am involved in the annual IYF World Camp.
IYF World Camp provides quality development programs that teach and inspire young people to become agents of change throughout the world. During its infancy in 1995, IYF World Camp first inspired me to serve others and sacrifice myself for the greater good. I have been giving back to it ever since.
Your generous contributions will help offset the costs of executing our array of programming throughout a typical World Camp day. The better quality the programs, the greater chance our attendees emerge having gained the motivation to change themselves and the lives of others.
What We Need & What You Get
Look to your right and you'll see what you get at different levels of donation amounts.
We’ll also draw names out of a hat every 2 or 3 days and feature that person on our website leading up to the start of the IYF World Camp. We’ll notify you once your name, picture, and contribution amount go live on our website. What you will definitely get is a Thank-You letter you can use for tax purposes and a post-Camp report about what we did and how we used your contributions.

We are targeting a total of $25,000 for our online Indiegogo campaign
We plan to use Indiegogo donations for the following Camp expenditures:
Food                             $ 5000
Academy supplies          $ 7500
Event supplies               $ 7500
Venue rental                 $ 5000
The Impact
IYF World Camp currently serves over 35 countries in 41 separate camps per year. Almost 1 million people have already attended World Camps. Through it, we've sent over 5000 volunteers to foreign countries, 560 medical volunteers who have treated a total of 60,000 patients in developing countries, and 1000 volunteer ESL instructors having taught English in places like Russia, Mexico, and Haiti.
Young people are seeing prime opportunities to serve and become leaders through IYF. This ripple effect is bringing about real, lasting change in the near future. But, we want you to be a part of it today.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t make a gift to IYF World Camp, you can always contact us about getting involved with the IYF World Camp or any one of our volunteering opportunities, both short- and long-term. Visit us at iyfusa.org for more information or reach out to us through Indiegogo and mention that you heard about us through this site. Emails can be sent to info@iyfef.org.

story:
UPDATE: 

Thank you all so much for making BiblioWorks' month of literacy events possible. We have successfully reached our goal of $4000 thanks to your generous support. BiblioWorks will happily accept further contributions towards new libraries and our work promoting literacy. Visit our 'get involved' page to make a donation. 

BiblioWorks: Spreading the joys of reading

Help BiblioWorks fund the second annual Literacy Festival in Sucre, Bolivia in April, 2013!

  • BiblioWorks has opened 9 libraries in impoverished, rural communities in Bolivia. We believe in the power of literacy to transform people's lives in a positive way. 
  • The first annual literacy festival held in April, 2012 was a huge success and opened the door to reading to more than 500 students living in the city of Sucre.
  • This year we hope to multiply the reading activities, multiply the students involved and spread the joy of reading to thousands of people living in Sucre, Bolivia!

Literacy has the power to change people’s lives. Literacy has the power to open educational doors. Through literacy we put development strategies into the hands of the people.

What We Need

We need $4,000 in order to put on the second annual Literacy Festival. Here's what the money will be used for:

  • Books!
  • Materials for organizations to carry out innovative literacy activities with children, high-school students and adults.
  • Promotional materials to advertise the festival in Sucre, Bolivia and to advertise the importance of literacy
  • Logistical set-up of the literacy festival  

If we don't reach our monetary goal, the literacy festival will be carried out with the same passion and enthusiasm for educating children, only with fewer organizations and fewer children participating.

The Impact

Your contribution to this important cause will make a lasting impact on:

  • Improving literacy in Sucre, Bolivia.
  • BiblioWorks and our literacy and library projects in impoverished communities.
  • Children, who would not otherwise have the opportunity to improve their situations through literacy and education.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a monetary donation right now, here are some ways you can get involved:

  • Spread the word about this campaign and about BiblioWorks and the great work we are doing in Bolivia!
  • Check out the 'get involved' page of our website to find out more ways to participate.
  • Don't forget to use Indiegogo's share tools to spread the word about our cause!
  • Contact volunteerbiblioworks@gmail.com to find out about volunteering for the literacy festival! Haven't you been dreaming of a "vol-cation"?

story:
Hello, and thanks for stopping by!

My name is Laurence LeBlanc, I am 19 years old, and I am the founder of the non-profit project, Art for Global Health.  Debuting in 2012, www.artforglobalhealth.org sells student and professional artwork to raise funds for three minority villages in Laos and three minority pre-schools in India. Through hunger, medical, and education initiatives, my team and I are working towards a better future for people in impoverished communities. Artwork is donated by artists who want to make a difference, and includes pottery, printmaking, painting, sculpture, jewelry, photography, woodworking, and other varieties. 

Art for Global Health: The Mission

For India: Pre-Schools, Clinic, Smokeless Stoves

Art for Global Health has partnered with Help-Kids-India to support initiatives that allow 3-5 year olds of the "untouchable caste" to attend pre-school. Members of the "untouchable caste" are unable to attend most primary and secondary schools unless they receive a baseline preschool education. Three pre-schools in Kodaikanal allow children to break out of the cycle of poverty, provide three meals per day, provide medical clinics for the children to go to, and install smokeless stoves in their homes. 


For Laos: Village Committees and Board of Directors

Village Committees were established in minority Khmu villages of Ban Boua, Ban Vieng Kham, and Hoify. With 6-10 representatives from diverse backgrounds, and an even number of males and females, various issues are discussed before the Committees decide how best funds can be used. The Board communicates with Committees to confirm that projects are worthwhile. 


Current Issues

This Campaign: $5,000 
(with hopes for $10,000!)

We need your help to make our ultimate goals a reality. 

  • $1000 will pay for 5 years of out-of-pocket maintenance costs and allow us to continue our community projects. This money includes website fees, shipping costs, and publicity. This money grows on itself, because if more customers will go to artforglobalhealth.org, that will generate more funds for community projects. Funds for art fairs will do the same. 
  • $9,000 will go towards community projects in Laos and India. The breakdown is shown below. If we are lucky enough to surpass our goal of $10,000, all extra funds will also go directly to Laos and India.

The "Nitty-Gritty" Breakdown of Your Generous Donations:

$1000 will sustain the project for 5 years
$2500 will send 10 kids to school for a year
$2500 will buy a new well
$1500 will restock a medical clinic to combat disease
$1500 will provide a plow to help with harvest
$500 will buy school supplies for 25 kids
$250 will buy 25 vitamin bottles
$150 will buy 50 pairs of shoes
$100 will provide 4 smokeless stove installations

How will we thank you?

Your donations are meaningful. We understand you have the choice of supporting many other worthy organizations out there. As a token of our appreciation, we have decided on various "Perks" which you can see on the right. Most all of them include artwork, so be sure to check them out!

How did it all begin? Interesting Story:

In 2011 I had the opportunity to travel to Southeast Asia with my high school. Hoify, an isolated village in Laos, is surrounded in all directions by acres of jungle.These people are so wise, and taught me so much, but continue to live without basic human resources. The extreme poverty we witnessed instilled in me a spark. I used my artistic background to create a game-changer. In particular, the idea stemmed from polymer clay figures I began creating in 7th grade (pictured below). 

Join Our Cause and Be Part of Our Revolution of Change.

Use the www.Indiegogo.com share tools

Talk about the project on social media

Visit the website and give us feedback

Donate funds or artwork to the project

Get the word out and make some noise!

story:
SLP College situated in the North of England ,Garforth.

Every year the Third Year Students have fundraising targets to meet in order to make it to a prestigious West End Theatre for our Showcase .Because we are up North it is harder for Agents and Casting directors to view us and hopefully sign us so our Showcase is an amazing opportunity to do so .

We have been very proactive so far in our fundraising by holding events such as our Halloween party and our Christmas fair but we still have a long way to go as our target for this year is a massive £2500 .

We would be eternally gratefull for any help we receive in order to reach our fundraising goals and ultimatley our dreams .No ammount would be deemed too small .

story:
Update*********Help me get pummeled by pies!

WATCH ME GET HIT BY 1 PIE FOR EVERY 25 DOLLARS DONATED IN A VINE VIDEO! STARTING NOW!

Hello Friends!

I have been invited--as one of 60 poets--to attend The Ashbery Home School: a one-week writing conference welcoming poets who seek to redefine their practice through a radical consideration of the other arts--music, cinema, the visual arts, and dance, as well as other media.

At The Ashbery Home School I will study with poets like Adam Fitzgerald, Timothy Donnelly, Dorothea Lasky, Susan Howe, Myung Mi Kim, and Paul Muldoon--as well as artists like Kara Walker and Kiki Smith--and also the film director Guy Maddin.

All this will take place in beautiful Hudson, NY, at the 19th century home of John Ashbery, whose book Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror was awarded the Pulitzer, the National Book Award, and the National Book Critics Circle Award. President Obama presented Ashbery with a National Humanities Medal at the White House in 2012.

As if all of the above were not enough, at the end of this wonderful week I will have the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity of reading my work to--and meeting--John Ashbery himself!

Your donation will help cover tuition and keep me from hitchhiking there and unrolling my sleeping bag next to a can of Beanie Weenies every night.

Thank you in advance for your generosity!
